content:
Posted: October 19, 2013
												With abominations of GFWL and Secu-ROM finally sent to hell where they belong this master-piece has no flaws.Well, almost no flaws. There are still some questionable optimisation issues, owners of newer configurations won't notice them, but still it drags a bit on max DX11 settings on machines on which it shouldn't. Also, in challenge modes, sometimes it happens that your character grabs some invisible wall if he jumps too high from the vantage point, or too close to some wall (grabbing mostly air), ruinning your escape plan offten ending in your death. Or opponents having unestablished attacks, even if you clearly see that someone is rushing to punch you he stops suddenly breaking your combo (which shouldn't concern you too much if you don't chase scores).But that's pretty much everything bad I can say about this game, really. Everything else is pure gold. Its unbelievable that it took only 2 years after first game for Rocksteady to develop the game which is in every way vastly superior to its already phenomenal predeccessor.  Incredible amount of love is invested in every detail: characters, story, gameplay, superior voice acting, writing, story-driven and optional missions, challenges,... Theres so much to do here. When you finish with story campaign you can throw yourself into challenge maps with one of the 4 characters (Batman, Catwoman, Robin, and Nightwing), with their own gadgets, moves, and objectives on every map. Catwoman is satisfying to controll in the fight maps, but in predator not so good because she is lacking gadgets and moves, but you shouldn't have much problems with other characters in that manner.This is definitely one of the best games I've ever played, and a great fan service. The game which Dark Knight deserves.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
Warning: this is a long review from a hardcore fan of the series, get ready to read for a while! Short version is below the long one!!!Long version: Arkham series is one of mine most favorite video games series I've played. Back in 2009 I got addicted to Arkham Asylum and 6 years later I'm still in love with the series. So let's begin.Introduction:Batman: Arkham City is a 2011 action-adventure video game developed by Rocksteady Studios and released by Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment for the PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360 video game consoles, and Microsoft Windows. Based on the DC Comics superhero Batman, it is the sequel to the 2009 video game Batman: Arkham Asylum and the second installment in the Batman: Arkham series. It was released worldwide for consoles, beginning in North America on October 18, 2011, with a Microsoft Windows version following on November 22.Plot The events of Arkham City are set one year after Batman: Arkham Asylum. Quincy Sharp, the asylum's erstwhile director, has taken sole credit for halting the Joker's armed siege, using this distinction to become mayor of Gotham City. Declaring both the asylum and Blackgate Penitentiary no longer suitable to contain the city's detainees, Sharp's administration orders both facilities closed and he purchases Gotham's most notorious slums, converting them into an immense prison enclosure known as Arkham City. This facility is subsequently placed in the care of psychiatrist Hugo Strange—who is secretly manipulating Sharp—and monitored by a rogue private military firm, TYGER Security. Strange permits the inmates to do as they please, so long as they do not attempt to escape. A wary Batman maintains his own vigil over the new project, concerned that the chaotic situation there will get out of hand. Meanwhile, the Joker is suffering from a potentially fatal disease caused by his previous consumption of the Titan formula, an unstable steroid serum which turns men into maddened monsters.At a press conference held by Bruce Wayne to declare his opposition to Arkham City, TYGER mercenaries arrest and imprison him in Arkham City. Hugo Strange discloses his knowledge of Wayne's dual identity as Batman before releasing him into the prison's criminal populace. While Strange prepares to commence "Protocol 10", Wayne obtains his equipment via airdrop from Alfred Pennyworth, allowing him to become Batman. He first saves Catwoman from being executed by Two-Face, who hopes to gain respect by murdering her. After Joker attempts to assassinate Catwoman, Batman tracks him to his hideout in the Sionis Steelmill, believing Joker may know the truth behind Protocol 10.There, Batman learns that the unstable properties of the Titan formula are mutating in Joker's blood, gradually killing him. Joker captures Batman and performs a blood transfusion on him, infecting him with the same fatal disease.Joker also reveals that Gotham hospitals have been poisoned with his infected blood. Desperate to save himself and innocent citizens, Batman seeks out Mr. Freeze, who had been developing a cure but has since been kidnapped by the Penguin. Will Batman cure himself? Will he find out what is Protocol 10? Play this game to find out more!GameplayBatman: Arkham City is an open-world action-adventure game that incorporates tactics from stealth games. It is presented from the third-person perspective, showing the playable character on screen and allowing the camera to be freely rotated around it. The game is set within Arkham City, which is open to the player from the beginning of the game, allowing them to travel freely anywhere within its boundaries.The player can move silently throughout the game, using a combination of gadgets and stealth moves to sneak up on enemies and incapacitate them. Batman can use his cape to glide around the city, diving downward and swooping upwards to extend his flight, and he can use the grapnel gun's retracting rope to attach to out-of-reach ledges. As Batman, the player is able to use "Detective Vision", a visual mode that highlights elements of interest on-screen, such as character status, collectables, and clues; the mode is also used to perform forensic activities such as tracking the source of a sniper rifle round. The player has access to an in-game criminal database which includes forensic puzzles, as well as a network for hacking communication frequencies.Using an improved version of the Freeflow combat system from Arkham Asylum, the player can now counter multiple blows simultaneously, catch hurled projectiles, attack aerially, and administer a succession of consecutive strikes.As you noticed - the combat system is big improvement compared to the Arkham Asylum's one (Which, don't get me wrong, was insanely good too!).Verdict: This game is insanely fun and the plot is filled with action and intense moments, which keeps you interested. 10/10 hands down.Short version: This is a sequel to Arkham Asylum, in which we fight Joker and Hugo Strange at the same time. The plot is mind-blowing and the characters are unique and all of this is support by an insane combat system, that is so pleasing to use, that you will fall in love with it. Must buy for every comic fan / fan of Batman, those who liked Asylum this game is gonna be like a dream - nothing more, rather than an overall improvement. 10/10.EDIT: Since the game is often on sale - grab it, because it's worth your money :D

content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												Batman Arkham City takes the incredibly strong foundation created in Arkham Asylum and builds on it a magnificent skyscraper. Everything that made the original game a great experience has been expanded and improved upon, thus making this game one of the best action adventure games you could ever spend your time playing.The freeflow combat system that was so satisfying the first time around has been majorly upgraded and now features an impressive amount of ways to stun and cripple whoever dares to stand in your way. Batman\'s collection of gadgets has also been expanded, with each one having applications in combat and puzzle-solving scenarios. Predator encounters have also seen a boost in excitement as there are now a more ways to takedown your foes, but also more ways to be caught by them. The addition of more playable characters is also a great benefit, as each one plays slightly differently, yet consistently satisfyingly.You will also find yourself fighting a larger variety enemies this time around too, as the game introduces deadlier foes like snipers, armored goons, and blade wielding ninjas. And even more exciting is the larger variety of super villains that you'll find yourself at odds, and sometimes evens, with. A large portion of Batman's rogues gallery is on display here and the ways in which you\'ll face these enemies are as varied as they thrilling. Sometimes there will be a complex and intense battle that must be fought with hard fists, while other times a sharp detective\'s mind and keen puzzle-solving skills will be needed.The most obvious expansion to the game is of course its world design. Whereas Arkham Asylum saw you making your way through the interesting and somewhat linear titular location, Arkham City sees you gliding through the snow covered streets of Gotham City itself, or at least a decent portion of it. It is amazingly detailed and diverse in its depiction and thanks to all the riddles that need solving, those who wish to explore it will be rewarded with interesting stories that give each location, as well as the entire game\'s story, an impressive amount of context.And when speaking about the story I wish to say is that this one\'s is excellent. It starts with a flawless beginning that doesn\'t directly follow Arkham Asylum\'s ending, but provides enough information that you feel as though it almost does. This level of excellence then continues all the way through to the end of the main story, finishes off with quite the show. The characters, from the good to the bad, are each compelling in their own right and even though it\'s satisfying to be victorious over them, it\'s usually a bittersweet victory because your experience with them is over. Throw in the fact that Catwoman has her own separate storyline that weaves in and out of the main one, and you\'ve got a narrative that is varied in its perspective and tone. My only true gripe is that there isn\'t a concluding story moment that plays out once you\'ve completed every task that you can do. You\'re just left to free roam the map, wondering what to do with yourself. However there is an epilogue chapter which heavily features Robin, and while its inclusion does help relieve some feelings of story abandonment, it ultimately still leaves you wanting more.Batman Arkham City is simply put, a major advancement, in almost every way over its predecessor. Almost every functioning part of this game has been improved from the previous Arkham game, and it is undeniably apparent. It is also obvious that huge amount of hard work and reverence for the Dark Knight that went it to creating this game. And in total, I truly believe it to be a work of interactive art.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												I'll start this review off by saying that this game is my favorite game ever (been gaming since the NES), and that says a lot about it since I'm not huge on anything with superheroes, or Batman for that matter - I don't like the movies, except the hilarious one with Adam West and exploding sharks, I don't watch Batman cartoons, I don't read the comic books, I don't even know Batman's true identity... (one of these is a blatant lie).The Arkham games offer a mix of stealth and action gameplay, and they make both of them work perfectly (at least Asylum and City do). I never played a 3D action game with fighting controls this tight, or stealth this fun, it's just a blast to play the combat challenges and predator encounters in these games (again, talking about Asylum and City), On top of that, the voice acting, music, controls, gameplay, story, everything is as good as it can get.So why is this one my favorite? Well there's just something about open world games with a ton of side stuff scattered around that gets to me, and this game definitely has it.From Riddler trophies/puzzles (440 of them if I remember correctly), to side quests that involve some of Gotham's and DC's famous criminals. These make Arkham City a pretty damn fun playground for our flying mammal.You also get to play some parts of the game as Catwoman. I know some people don't enjoy controlling her, but I personally like it, especially in combat. She's faster than Batman and has totally different fighting animations (I wanna say she doesn't punch as hard as the bat, but don't quote me on that).Not sure if I can say anything about the story without spoiling it, so I'll just say that it's pretty good, and Mark Hamill as the Joker, and Kevin Conroy as Batman did an amazing job bringing their characters to life.Again, I'm not a huge Batman fan outside of these games, and I absolutely love the story in this game, I've beaten the game multiple times, and I never skipped a single cutscene.This game is a clean 10/10 for me, it's just fantastic in every way possible.

Another thing that makes this game more creative are the gadgets. You need think of how to open or do certain things with these gadgets. If you're a mega fan of Batman, you might enjoy this game a tiny bit more than if you didn't. Fan or not, buy this game, you'll have a blast. It's sort of hard to point out the negatives but one of them is some of the random texture popins but it doesn't really bother me. I think one of the things is that you can spam press the counter attack button and Batman will fight for you. I'd give it a 9/10

Posted: February 19, 2016
												Let me start off by saying that this is a fantastic game with tons of replay value. There are tons of memorable characters, and a story that will enthrall you to no end. The artwork in this game is astounding, and some of the characters are even voiced by legendary voice actors like Kevin Conroy (Batman) and Mark Hamill (Joker), The fighting mechanics in the Arkham series are unlike anything you've ever seen before, with tons of options for combos for beating the living crap out of your enemies.After 100 hours, I have completed the game on the three main difficulties and completed the game 100% on Normal. Currently, I'm working on a New Game + playthrough.The music is top notch; composed by Nick Arundel.I would definitely recommend this game to anyone who likes Batman, is a fan of beat-em-ups, or just wants to try something new.

content:
Posted: January 3
												Phew! It's been a long month with Arkham City! Did I enjoy it? Some parts yes, some parts no. Story was great, a decent length for a game and really drives you into itself. It's a continuation game for Arkham Asylum so, make sure you played that one before playing City or there will be dialogues that you won't understand. Unlike Asylum, we have open world in Arkham City. We could explore the island in Arkham Asylum but it wasn't that big and because of it, it didn't feel like open world but in City, you have side quests and over 400 collectibles! Lots of new mechanics have been introduced as well! Another thing is you don't get to play as Batman only, you get to play as Catwoman in some parts of main story and challenges, Robin in challenges and Harley Quinn's Revenge DLC, and Nightwing in challenges only. Combat seems like it's been improved since Arkham Asylum. They added lots of new moves and gadgets to use. Only thing I didn't like about the game was challenges. You have to play them over and over again with 4 characters. Some challenges are not balanced so, get ready to punch your PC while playing them. Long story short, Arkham City was one of the best games I've ever played!

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												BATMAN Arkham City Review! I almost forgot to do it after I beat the story so here it is.The story was pretty short but the fight system is pretty awesome. I kinda wish the fights lasted longer but I was playing on regular difficulty. Apparently the new game plus mode is really intensely hard, but I didn't care enough to go through it all again. I was pleased with the game on my first run through so I didn't really want to go back and collect all the craploads of Riddler trophies scattered throughout the game or finish any of the side quests.The overall story is pretty solid, but I was feeling like something was missing and I can't quite put my finger on it. It's good, but it just seemed a little too... cookie cutter Batman. There wasn't really anything that stood out or blew my mind. I guess that's what some people enjoy about Batman is that he's Batman and predictable. I don't say that in a negative way, just that some people might like that more than me is all. I had a few "what a twist" moments that mainly came from Batman's adversaries rather than himself. Basically Batman just beat the hell out of everyone to get what he needs. I liked how the story was like a few short stories end to end that had an overall theme. It's pretty cool the way Batman works his way through all the scum in Arkham City one by one with the same suit that shows wear and tear as the game progresses. The combat system is by far my favorite aspect of the game. At first I was really not getting it down, but once I realized it's not about button mashing and I have to time literally every hit after the first 2 connect. Basically Batman crits everyone after his second hit, and assuming you're targeting the right thug and not button mashing you can string together some totally mega badass combos. Not to mention the gadgets. They're all there including some new fangled things that wouldn't make it to the movies, but for the purposes of the game it's perfect. Lot's of different configurations of gadget use and combos make for some ridiculous fights. I never got tired of the slow-mo hits either, somehow they were always satisfying. Even if the stealth parts were fun, like hanging some random unfortunate goon upside down of the side of a building, or sneaking around in vents only to bust into the room and knock down a bunch of thugs. All in all the combat is what makes this game worth playing in my opinion.Some of the voice acting is really good and other times it's pretty lame. Sometimes it sounds like people reading to each other off a script with no emotion, then other times it really great and immersive. Joker is by far the best and sounds crazy as you'd expect. Batman wasn't all that great though, but Harley Quinn was spot on as well as a few others.The graphics are outstanding and that's probably my second favorite thing about this game. It just LOOKS really good. The devs really didn't miss much, lots of really fine details are everywhere and really add to the overall ambiance when necessary. If you're not into 3rd person combat, at least play it for the graphics. It's gorgeous. Batman AC: 6.95. Fine I'll round up. 7.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												More expansive and populated than its predecessor, Arkham Asylum, it's also far less focused. I'm taken by the gliding and grappling, as well as the endless array of familiar (and startling!) Batman villains that show up, either for entire levels, or just for a brief cameo. The combat remains untaintedly enjoyable, though maybe the arsenal of new gadgets makes things a bit too complex, and the stealth is a fantastic mix of power fantasy and powerless tension. It's pretty much the best sort of modern sequel you can hope for, adding and refining the formula that worked so well in Arkham Asylum. It's lost the balance that made Asylum a true modern classic, though, which is a bit of a shame, but it's not to City's detriment, by any stretch.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Arkham City is a fantastic game. Great graphics, solid story. Right from the start you are shown Batman, villain after villain, after villain. It hooks you in and keeps you going. It's not an overwhelming combat system lots of typical button mashing for a hand to hand fighter but in this style of game it's enjoyable. The game focuses more on stealth combat not direct fighting. If you are a batman fan, read no farther go ahead and buy it. If you are on the fence read on.The game is solid, like I mentioned before it's some button mashing style gameplay and it's pretty basic gameplay in my opinion. Basic as in you don't have to be a seasoned gamer to figure it out and play. The graphics are great and Batman as always is awesome. Catwoman is a nice addition, I know Robin is supposed to be around somewhere in the game (not sure if I misread or not got to him yet or something) then all the villains all wrapped up into one story line! It's great, any of the new Batman games (Asylum, City, Origins) This one is my favorite so far but I've not got into Origins much at this time to decide. I recommend this game and think you will enjoy it if you buy it.I give it a 88/100

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
Batman Arkham City	* 10/10The old saying about sequels being worse than the first seems less true in these days. In fact Batman Arkham City goes beyond Arkham Asylum.Arkham City takes place right after the ending of the previous chapter. For some reason Arkham has been extended to a large portion of Gotham (reasons can be found during the game and secondary missions of Arkham Asylum) and Bruce Wayne is trapped inside it. The moment he gets safe he can become Batman and investigate the situation of the new Arkham City. I don't want to talk about the story more than I did because I consider this the best until now, and I refuse to make any spoiler to ruin the experience.Gameplay is based on the previous chapter's combat system consisting of a very simple 3rd person action that easily allows you to fight against large quantities of enemies or use a stealth approach, but it has also been improved with moves and gadgets and most importantly, considering now you're in an open city, you can freely plane over the buildings all around the town which is simply awesome and fun.As the story takes place in a bigger ambience like Gotham you will have much more side missions, that will keep you busy for much longer. Once again the riddler will challenge you to retrieve his trophies (some of them are really hard to get), and most importantly in this chapter we see Catwoman for the first time. There are also some missions where you can impersonate her, and in meantime you can catch some riddler trophies specifically for Catwoman.Just like the entire franchise, Arkham City uses the Unreal Engine, wisely used by the developers to build the entire city and amazing closed sections. Besides the whole game is filled with references (subtle or not) to a lot of characters or situations from DC and Batman's story which, together with the incredible main and side stories, demonstrate the care and love for the game and characters by the developers.+++PROs+++ STORY.  It Goes On Exactly from where Asylum ended, and it's so well orchestrated, by involving many characters, old and new ones, and giving them their own situations and fitting context. The story is so great, full of Turning points with one of the greatest ends ever possible. GAMEPLAY. Absolutely fun, following the style of Asylum, this time we can also fly through the whole city... Absolutely the best. SECONDARY MISSIONS. Lots, nice and fun, they have some depth, some story, so you do have a good reason to play them. Especially the Riddler, one of the best villain in these games, in my opinion... Seriously (Why so serious? XD) CHARACTERS. It's amazing how many famous characters are involved in the story: old ones, new ones... And Being a Generic Comic fan And batman reader I admit I didn't know anything About Hugo Strange. This made me read more (and enjoy the game more, somehow) REFERENCES. Endless References, cameos and homages to batman's and DC's universe RIDDLER. Those damn riddles are more difficult in this chapter... XD CATWOMAN. Playable Catwoman Sidestory. It wasn't much, but it was a very nice addition that gave some variety to the game. SOUNDTRACK. This soundtrack makes use of a great title track, and some good support melodies.---CONs--- BINDINGS. Key Bindings in a pre-Game Window only? in 2012? Seriously? Again? This reminds me of Need For Speed... 3... 1998... and that was for graphic selection (software or 3dfx), the keys were editable ingame... 1998... Ridiculous considering the great results of the game itself. RIDDLER. Those damn riddles are more difficult in this chapter... XDI played this game on this machine:Intel Core i7-497016Gb RAM DDR3GeForce GTX 660Windows 10 Professional x64

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												Absolutely fantastic game! Captivating story, great gameplay, and characters that make the expirience even better! It gets difficult occasionally, but only to the extent that when you complete the mission/task/whatever, you achieve a sense of acomplishment. The plot is incredibly well thought out, with twists and turns at every corner. In fact, the only thing better than the story, is the gameplay itself. After a little getting used to, the combat becomes enjoyable. Whether you're taking on a few thugs, a titan, or both at once, i can guarantee that you will find it entertaining. The upgrade system has improved significantly from what it was in arkham asylum. I'm not going to lie, using the cryptographic sequencer was a bit of a struggle, but after more frequent use, became an exellent adition to batman's repetoire of gadgets. And then there's the voice acting. Absolutely amazing. The cast was perfect, and all portrayed the characters brilliantly. The only thing that i dislike about this game was that it ended. Game of the Year is an understatement. This is one of the greatest games ever made. Whether you're a fan of batman, or not, this game will prove to be a fantastic expirience that you will never forget. Thank you rocksteady, for creating the best supehero game ever made.

												I have to say I'm not really fond of Batman, I could see the cartoon on TV but I wasn't interested by it.I started to play and the story gets you right into it like the first (Arkham Asylum), you just can't stop playing until you see the ending scene. This game is just a masterpiece, everything is made up for every batman fan and to make you become one.You can probably see all the characters in this, the story doesn't really follows the previous one in my opinion, maybe only with The Joker.When I was complaining of the lack of combat moves in Arkham Asylum, they added more here to create more techniques to make battles like so EPIC.However, they kept the challenges, they added even more with the Robin, Catwoman and Nightwing packs, the challenges are the same as Arkham Asylum, only the maps and the new moves change. For me, it's not really enjoyable, some challenges are too hard and require 1 hour of play doing nothing to get all the medals. Boring.The DLC Quinn's Revenge is quite good, a bit too short.If you're an achievement master, you will probably end the story campaign 99.50% with 3 Riddler's challenges that you can do only once in the middle of the story.To brief, this game has an awesome story that will get you curious of every single event in Arkham, The Joker is brilliant, I wonder what he's become in Arkham Origins. And if you didn't play Arkham Asylum, buy the triple pack.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												I do not read Batman (or any superhero stuff), nor have I played any other game in the series, yet I still find this game very likeable as an action game. You play as Batman, the ace detective / kung fu master, and fight crime around Arkham City.Most of the gameplay alternates between 2 kinds of actions: flying around and punching people. Then flying around some more and punching more people.The flying parts actually feel very natural. You hold A to run / glide, and push RB to fire a claw and pull yourself to top of buildings. Whenever there is something you can pull yourself to, the game gives you very clear visual cues, and pressing the button always gets me to the place I want to go, which feels great. And the claw has a really long range, allowing you to fly across the city swiftly.The fighting also exceeds my expectations. It starts very easy: mash X to punch, and whenever you see warnings on their heads, push Y instead to counter. However new mechanics keep appearing. There are knife guys that you have to HOLD Y to dodge. There are guys with guns that you cannot take on up front. There are info guys that you don't want to take out so that you can interrogate them. There are armor guys that won't get hurt until stunned. You can unlock critical strikes that require you to push X at precise times instead of mashing it. These mechanics keep the fighting fresh and challenge you to adopt new fighting styles.The tutorials are also done well. In the move list you can actually turn tutorials of individual moves on or off, anytime. If turned on, instructions will appear as soon as you are in the position to use that move. So never worry about forgetting a specific move again.Occasionally you also get to use some cool gadgets, such as a boomerang, a hacking machine, and explosives. I am disappointed to see there being no long range take-down weapons, such as a tranquilizer gun. But then such a gun may make the game too easy and not fun. And Batman probably won't look cool with a gun.Another complaint I have is the inability to pick up weapons dropped by enemies, such as bats. The wood stuff that you hit balls with, not the animal. But again, it would not be fun if Batman could pick up and use guns, so maybe that is intended.As for graphics, since this game is relatively ancient, it runs fluently on my 3-year-old laptop with moderate quality settings. The colors are always darkish and depressing, everywhere, all the time. I guess that's because the whole city and whole game is about darkness so it can't be helped. Think twice before buying if you don't like that.The music is decent and dynamically changes to match the atmosphere. The sound effects are pretty good, expecially the fighting sounds. They make your punches feel much more powerful, and carry information too.The storytelling is also good. Before playing I feared that not knowing Batman characters may prevent me from understanding the plots. However the game helps me by providing brief introductions to every main character, explaining what they do and why. As a result, I still don't fully know what happened before the plot of this game, but everything happening in the game can be clearly understood. The plots are highly straightforward anyway.In conclusion, this is an enjoyable action game. I don't know what Batman fans will think of it, but I find it highly satisfiable as a regular action game on its own. There are minor flaws, something that I think can be designed better, and so far I haven't seen anything that truly amazes me, but with highly fluent graphics, ever-changing fights, and a low price, this game is worth it.=============== Updates after finishing story mode ==================More praises and complaints.Near the end, the fights get much more intense than I expected. The complex formation of enemies force you to use all of ABXY buttons, and thus make it very hard to always push the correct button at the correct time. That's a great challenge and I love it.For additional complaints, first, the story is not complete. At the beginning we saw Joker poison himself, Batman, as well as thousands of people around Arkham. However at the end, only 2 cures are made, Freeze destroyed one, Batman drank the other one and survived, Joker did not get any and died. What about the people? Does Batman just see them die? Or are they already cleared out by Protocol 10? I feel that's an important question left unanswered and I don't like that.Second, Catwoman is much worse than Batman at bouncing around, which makes no sense. In a room with vantage points, with Batman you can pretty much put a vantage point anywhere in the camera, then press RB to hop onto it. With Catwoman this barely works: you have to stand in a specific location or RB does nothing. This difference makes it much harder than it should be to play stealth with Catwoman.Finally, game freezes once every few hours. Sometimes when this happens I cannot even start the task manager and have to sign out from Windows entirely. It's rare, but it shouldn't happen at all.==========================================================+ Play as Batman+ Fly across the city, horizontally and vertically, with ease+ Intense fights+ Variety of enemies+ Collectibles+ Friendly tutorials+ Fluent graphics- Flat plot- Unable to pick up items- Infrequent freezes8 out of 10, excellent.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Batman Arkham City. Well to be honest i had my doubts for this game, didn't like Arkham Asylum all too much but Arkham City really did opened up the series for me. With Arkham City's being a free roamer really caugth my attention being that usually Free Roam superhero games like the Spiderman series really gives alot of potential on games for me. Arkham City didn't fail and in fact sucseeded in suprising me more than i thougth it would. Combat is amazing, free roam never got boring being that you tend to get that Batman feel everytime you leap from one building to another and glide your way to slam over an enemy never gets old. The story is great, intense and the campaign is almost always thrilling. Boss fights are challenging and rememberable. Map size is rather big, but nothing special. Stealth feels rather real compared to most games. A.I feels amazingly intelligent and you get that hide for your life type of feel whenever you're taking the predator approach in a room filled with armed thugs.You can spend alot of time playing this game garrunteed, side missions are fun on thier own, and Catwoman being an editon to the gameplay as a playable character really only makes the experience that much better. I'd give Arkham City a 9/10. Good story. Good combat. Good map and free roam. Spectacular campaign and only some slight character bugs.

Posted: July 10, 2014
												A fantastic game that everybody should try. It improves on everything present in Arkham Asylum to make it fell like a true sequel. No matter if you're just familar with the movies, the cartoons, the comics, or none of the above, there is something to appeal to everybody. I've beat it numerous times on the 360 and the PC and I still come back to it from time to time because of the addictive combat and Riddler Challenges, as you can tell by the number of hours I've put into it. The only negative things I'd have to say about the game would be that not much attention was placed on Nightwing and Robin in the game; an example would be that in the challenge rooms neither of them have any voice acting. But that's more of a nitpick (I love Robin/Tim Drake) becasue this is a game centered around Batman, and in that regard the game is perfect. This is my favorite game of all time, a title I hope will be replaced by the upcoming Arkham Knight. If I had to give this game a score it be 10/10. So go get it :p

content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												One of my all time favorite games. Batman: Arkham City took what Arkham Asylum did good and made it a whole lot better. The one thing that Arkham City does the best is that it makes you feel like you're Batman. It does so in a variety of ways, from giving you a large arsenal of gadgets to use, making the combat feel fluid and responsive with lots of different types of attacks, having you investigate crimes by searching for clues and trying to repiece the moments in your head, and best of all, it lets you glide around the city with your wings. There's no question why this is considered one of the best licensed games next to Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic and The Chronicles of Riddick: Assault on Dark Athena. The GOTY edition really does add to the game. It comes with a few extra challenge maps that are actually fun to play. They certainly are challenging and aren't just tacky add-ons to make the game longer. In fact, the main story is longer than most of todays games, coming in at around 15 hours, not including the side missions (I owned the GFWL version before the Steam version, and I have yet to complete it on Steam). With the side missions, I'd say total gameplay hours would be around 30 hours, since there are tons of extra stuff to do, not including challenge mode.So overall, this game is worth your time. Even if you aren't a Batman fan or don't know much about his character or the world, this game is fun for everyone who enjoys third person action games.My only complaint is that the open world can feel dead at times, with no one in the streets and nothing happening, and also how it takes a long time to travel from one area to another if you didn't unlock it already. Arkham Knight will fix this with being able to freely drive the Batmobile.My personal rating: 9/10 -  Gripping story, fluid combat, awesome graphics, and just downright fun to play.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
												Batman Arkham City is, obviously, the sequel to Arkham Asylum. I already said that Asylum was one of my best games of all time. However, Arkham City improves in every single aspect of the Arkham games. It has more content that is still of high quality, better mechanics, a better story that actually has a couple of twists in it (They will not be spoiled here) and some of the best downloadable content on the market.I'll begin by discussing the improved combat system. It makes the one is Asylum seem extremely outdated even though this was released only two years after Asylum. There are much more combat moves, a bigger enemy variety that includes armored enemies that can only be hit with the new Beatdown move and enemies holding doors which can only be avoided by maneuvering away from them or by pulling off the aerial attack move. Even the titan combat has been improved with two moves you can pull of on them. This makes the game harder, but not by much. Taking away the counter icons will give you a much tougher experience. The system will take a bit of getting used to, especially with the tougher moves like the Blade Dodge Takedown.The stealth has also been improved. There is a much bigger variety of takedowns that Batman can perform such as the Ledge Takedown, Takedowns through glass and walls and Double Takedowns which are very rewarding when you can pull one off. Again, the stealth has also been made harder. You will have to deal with armored enemies that can only be taken down with exotic methods and enemies that will be able to see you on vantage points if you don't have the right upgrade.Most of Batman's gadgets that were in Arkham Asylum have returned for City with a few new editions such as the Line Launcher (Which I believe is the most useful gadget it any game ever) and the Freeze Grenade. All of the gadgets are very helpful in stealth. Most of them are useful in combat and they help keep the variety in your combos.The game now contains not only Riddler Trophies as collectables, but it also has some challenges that are completed by Gliding for a certain length of time or using a certain gadget in a combo for example. Destroyable items are back too.There are also a lot of side missions in this game that each focus on a specific character. You can begin them at random points throughout the game or simply through discovery. Some of them can be completely missed out. They all have a lot of variety and some of them hint at things that could happen in Arkham Knight.Challenge Maps are back as well. The base game had 6 combat and 6 predator challenges with extreme varients. The extreme predator maps have been improved since Asylum. It is quite rare for you to ever be in a situation where the map has the vantage points with proximity mines on them which I think was just a cheap way to increase the difficulty. The maps are not too hard, even if you are aiming for all three medals. The predator ones may require a bit of trial and error for some of the objectives. I don't really see this as a problem as it reminds me of what Batman is: A detective. There are also a set of 12 campaigns which are a series of three maps which you must complete with modifiers that make some maps harder, but you are also given some helpful modifiers. A series of three extreme maps will test your skills to the limits.The port itself had problems and the abysmal GFWL integrated into it at launch. Now those problems are pretty much nonexistant. There are a couple of bugs with the A.I. and combat but these issues don't come up that often.The game runs pretty well after some configuration and it also includes all of the DLC. It wouldn't be a GOTY edition without all of the DLC, am I right?The extra content you are getting for Arkham City is all brilliant. There are a ton of skins that Batman can use from different storylines. Catwoman is playable with 4 extra story missions and two additional skiins. Her ability set is quite limited compared to Batman and she is intented for the more experienced players. Robin and Nightwing are both playable in the challenge maps. They come with some gadgets you will already be familiar with and new gadgets that will give you more unique ways to dispatch your foes. Extra challenge maps are also provided that try to do things differently. There are two survival maps and a sidescroller for example. The Batcave is also a predator map. Finally, there is the Two Hour Story Campaign, Harley Quinn's Revenge. It doesn't do much new, but you are getting more arkham city and extra playtime with Robin. What more could you ask for?You are going to get well over 100 hours completing everything this game has to offer (I played this on the PS3 so I rushed through both of my story playthroughs). If you liked Arkham Asylum, you probably already have this. If you haven't played a Batman Game before, wait for a sale and pick it up. You won't be disappointed as this is an unforgettable experience. The amount of detail put into the world is astounding and the mechanics have been polished even further than before. It is one of the greatest video games ever created. 10/10.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19, 2014
												Arkham Asylum was a great game, and this takes everything that was great about it and improves on it while still retaining the basic formula that made the first game great. It doesn't stray too far to confuse you if you played the first but it definitely takes the game in a different enough direction that you don't feel like you're playing a rehash called Arkham Asylum 1.5.A bigger, longer game from the first with a much improved story, some good plot twists, a more conventional 3 act story and still has the great moments and voice acting from the first.The Riddler challenges in the first game were fun to do, and they've been improved drastically here. They can be wildly different from the first game and quite hard to figure out, but well worth the time doing so.The Catwoman sections are a lot of fun too. She plays different enough from Batman but you don't feel like you're weaker than him. In fact, I liked playing as Catwoman more than I did Batman. Her takedowns are slower and she climbs up buildings differently and it can take a bit to get the hang of, but it added to the game a lot.The Harley Quinn DLC was very short, but most DLCs are. It was fun, it was different and geniunely added to the experience. You spend a lot of time playing as Robin and he plays a little more like Batman but with some different moves on him.The challenges include Batman, Catwoman, Robin & Nightwing (formerly the first Robin) and they all play different from one another but still have the same moves overall, just different actions, different power and different speed.This was an amazing game and easily recommended to anyone who likes action games.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												I have to say I'm not really fond of Batman, I could see the cartoon on TV but I wasn't interested by it.I started to play and the story gets you right into it like the first (Arkham Asylum), you just can't stop playing until you see the ending scene. This game is just a masterpiece, everything is made up for every batman fan and to make you become one.You can probably see all the characters in this, the story doesn't really follows the previous one in my opinion, maybe only with The Joker.When I was complaining of the lack of combat moves in Arkham Asylum, they added more here to create more techniques to make battles like so EPIC.However, they kept the challenges, they added even more with the Robin, Catwoman and Nightwing packs, the challenges are the same as Arkham Asylum, only the maps and the new moves change. For me, it's not really enjoyable, some challenges are too hard and require 1 hour of play doing nothing to get all the medals. Boring.The DLC Quinn's Revenge is quite good, a bit too short.If you're an achievement master, you will probably end the story campaign 99.50% with 3 Riddler's challenges that you can do only once in the middle of the story.To brief, this game has an awesome story that will get you curious of every single event in Arkham, The Joker is brilliant, I wonder what he's become in Arkham Origins. And if you didn't play Arkham Asylum, buy the triple pack.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												★★★★★ - "Do not miss this game" PROS:- Content, theres so much of it. A decent lengthen storyline with plenty of side missions and DLC story lines too.- Missions are varied, both within the storyline and side missions, including puzzles, stealth, gung-ho action and boss battles.- For the first time you can play as Catwoman and Robin, the former is awesome to play as and adds a fresh dimension to the game.- The storyline is great, thanks to incredible characters with superb voice acting and twists and turns to keep you guessing.- Roam the city, it feels great to glide around Arkham city with plenty to explore.- Combat is some of the best in the industry with some new moves and use of gadgets.- Batman, Robin, Catwoma, Joker, Harley Quinn, Bane, Mr.Freeze, Penguin..so many of the great comic book legends come to life in the game.- GOTY edition comes with all content including some rather cool skin packs for Batman and Robin.CONS:- On first play through on other platforms I found it easy to lose interest when wondering arkham city, often getting lost and mislead when navigating. I preferred Asylums more linear approach for a long time before I revisited arkham city.- Game mode plus, I hate this invention. Theres plenty of replay value anyway due to free roam after story completion, allowing you to revisit side missions but plus mode feels like a con. If there is an even more difficult mode have it available from the start as if your one to play for achievements you will need to play the game again.VERDICT? An incredible game which is high value for money.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Arkham City is the Second installment of Rocksteady's Arkham Franchise. Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill, Legendary Batman related Voice Actors return as their normal roles.Now, on to the story. After the events of Arkham Asylum, Arkham Asylum was shut down. And Mayor Sharp thought that maybe a bigger prison would be better. So, They built a Wall around Old Gotham. Where we start this story, Bruce Wayne is giving a speech infront of the Prison. He's part of the Anti-Arkham City thing that some poeple made. Hugo Strange, The Warden of Arkham City, Orders Bruce Wayne's arrest. Now we all know that Hugo Strange knows Bruce is Batman. Bruce then escapes Strange's custody and calls Alfred to send in the Batusit. Batman's long Night, has Just begun. That's all I'll say about the story. You'll just have to see what happens for yourself. (I know in my Arkham Origins review I talked about the end, But, I'm cheap. xD I enjoy the story in this more and it really sucks you in. So I choose not to spoil anything) There are many different Batman Characters in this game. Such as Barbara & Jim Gordon, Tim Drake Robin, Ra's Al Ghul, Hugo Strange, Catwoman, Two-Face, Penguin, Nightwing, (Sadly only a playable character in the challenge maps. No voice actor untill Arkham Knight either) Joker, Harley Quinn, Riddler, Deadshot, Mister Freeze, and much, much more. Now on to what I liked. I did like that Tim Was In here at least. I also, LOVED the Story. The Detective vision has improved since Arkham Asylum. The Combat system is also good. I Really like that this game has more than Batman Beating up people. It shows that he truely is The World's Greatest Detective. Batman and all the playable characters have a variety of Takedowns, and Gadgets. One of my favorite passtimes in Arkham Asylum & City is Thug Bowling on the Line Launcher. I also really like Playing as Nightwing in the challenge maps. Now, On to things I didn't like. I really liked everything in this game! But one of the VERY few Problems I had with this game was how they handled Tim Drake. With the Buzz Cut, Damian hood, & Brooding! He acted more Like Damian! Plus Tim Always had Anime style hair. Then again they hardly had any development in him. He acted more like Tim in the Story DLC. Anyway, Tim is basically the only problem I had with Arkham City. Well, Besides the Ra's Al Ghul part. When Batman Talks To Freeze he knows that Ra's has been using the Pit for centuries. Freeze asked "What will you do if he's dead?" Batman then responds with "Then I'll Wake Him Up". BUT, After the Ra's boss Battle, Batman talks to Barbara and is like "He's using some sort of Pit. He's been using it for centuries". Batman Already Knew that! Continuity error there! I also didn't really like how Penguin was. He was supposed to be gentleman like he looked in his poster in Arkham Asylum. He just sounds and looks like a British Thug! But the reason for this is because this is Arkham City, the criminals really are at there lowest points. I really had hardly any problems with Arkham City. I give this Game a 9.5 out of 10.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
 Batman Arkham City Review Much like Arkham Asylum, I fell in love with this game from the beginning. The story this time around certainly feels grander and the fantastic opener solidifies that, whilst capturing the tone of Batman and the atmosphere of the first game. We learn that Hugo Strange, who serves as warden of Arkham City, knows Bruce Wayne is Batman – oops, spoiler – and that he plans to execute some plan named Protocol 10 which Batman is out to stop. The Joker is also sick due to his obsession with Titan, resulting in an unlikely alliance between the two. This combination sends Batman on a myriad of tasks, which sees him meeting up with the likes of The Penguin, Mr Freeze and The League of Assassins. The narrative this time around, is surprisingly emotional but suffers from a few pacing issues, mostly due to the implementation of a Catwoman storyline. She serves as another playable character, and that’s not to say she isn’t interesting, because she is, Catwomen’s story just suffers from being placed between the most important moments in Batman’s quest.Aside from the main story, the open world this time features a few side quests involving Zsasz, Bane and even Deadshot. They vary in length, with some taking most of the game to finish and others taking less than ten minutes, but they’re a nice break from doing the main story missions and it’s fun to explore the rogues’ gallery of villains, Batman has to offer.The combat system has been slightly improved this time as well, offering a number of quick gadgets to use in combos and the ability to counter up to three enemies at once. The variety in enemy types is larger this time around, consisting of armoured and shield bearing thugs, that help to keep combat from getting repetitive. These combat overhauls are welcome and help to keep it varied and build upon the already great system. The same can be said for the predator sections – which like combat involve new enemy types, like the backpack wearing communication jammer and thugs with night vision goggles. As well as the new gadgets and environmental hazards which can be used to pick off said enemies. However like Arkham Asylum, the game suffers without varied and interesting boss battles with the exception of Mr Freeze, who forces the player to adapt throughout the fight. The other battles feel uninspired and lack the same creativity that Scarecrow had in the first game.Riddler is also back and has packed Arkham City tight with hundreds upon hundreds of collectibles, which to completionists might sound like heaven. The problem this time is that it becomes more of a chore than the previous game, in Asylum they weren’t absurd to collect and paired with the rewards, it just felt rewarding. Now it crosses into tedium, however the addition of Arkham City Stories, which are little lore pieces that you get from solving riddles are extremely interesting to read and add more character and depth to the world.The challenge mode with a mishmash of combat and predator levels also returns, amplified by four different characters, with over 200 medals to collect each. It’s much the same as the first, you pick a map and your character of choice – Batman, Catwoman, Nightwing or Robin – and fight for high scores on combat maps or complete tasks on the predator maps. The sheer amount of content around in challenge mode this time, will take hours upon hours to fully 100%, and with the gameplay being so damn enjoyable, it’s hard to become bored. A nice added feature for those who want to experience the main story a second time over, is New Game Plus. The mode carries over all your gadgets and progress from the main game and drops you into the story again, with amped up difficulty and all new enemy formations.Considering Batman Arkham City makes some welcome improvements to its predecessor, it’s a shame that its problems hold it back from being outright better that Arkham Asylum. Some finer tuning in the open world and Catwoman storyline would have made the difference it needed, but with that said – Arkham City is still a remarkable game and a worthy successor to Arkham Asylum. Batman Arkham City: Harley Quinn's Revenge Review Harley Quinn's Revenge is a small expansion for Batman Arkham City, that centers on Robin tracking down Batman in Harley Quinn's hideout.. The expansion is short, offering around 1-2 hours of content with all of that being the main story. No side missions or collectibles to speak of here.The expansion is also mostly linear, with the lion's share of it taking place inside a factory full of Harley Quinn's thugs, there is one free roaming part, but even that is limited to one area of Arkham City. It's the same type of Batman content you've come to to expect with - some combat, predator sections and puzzles.The standout of this entire expansion would be Kevin Conroy as Batman, due to the events that unfolded in Arkham City, Batman is broken. And it shows in Conroy's performance, it's fairly sublte, but his delivery is melancholic and damaged. You can hear the emotion in his voice, and it helps to remind us that Batman is human - he's not some superpowered god - but a man. I think it's an important study of Batman's character, one that makes the expansion worth any Batman fans time.It may be short, but Harley Quinn's Revenge is worth playing, it's more fantastic Batman gameplay with a performance from Conroy that shows us why he is the definitive Batman.

content:
Posted: February 27
Batman: Arkham City is a strategic brawler featuring polished mechanics and a brooding story that will entertain diehard fans and newcomers alike. Narrative:  Batman begins his journey with a violent ushering into the "no man's land" known as Arkham City, an Alcatraz-esque prison island where the world's most twisted criminals are now rampaging free. This is a decidedly bleak game, and absent are the saccharine clichés of other superhero plots. During his journey, Batman will encounter unlikely allies who have intriguing and oftentimes conflicting interests at play. But the core of the game's story revolves around the philosophical contrast drawn between the Batman and the Joker. Their constant struggle of opposing worldviews is executed to perfection and feels authentic and engaging. Minor quibbles aside concerning a character shift I felt was rushed, the general pacing of the game feels great. Batman: Arkham City has a compelling and concise script that will leave you wanting more. Gameplay: As the dark night spreads over the city of Arkham, the player must ultilize every tool at their disposal. The gameplay meat of Arkham City revolves around the "glass cannon" design of Batman and his arsenal of gadgets. When I executed my strategy with precision, I felt like the biggest, baddest superhero of all time. However, I quickly realized that even a few missteps would result in an untimely ending. The difficulty of the game is scalable (after initial completion) and lets the player dictate the depth of strategy they will need to employ to overcome obstacles. In addition to the main questline, there is a plethora of side content ranging from distress calls, augmented reality challenges and puzzles. Unfortunately for Batman, I did not encounter any bugs during my playthrough.I always felt disappointed when the game forced me to switch to Catwoman. Her character is fun to play, but I felt (in general) the swapping interrupted the natural flow of gameplay and I found myself thinking "I just want to be Batman."  Sensory: Batman rises above other similar games with an intricate soundstage, a powerful musical score and believable voice acting. The game designers have employed a stylized neo-gothic artistic aesthetic and incorporate interesting character design especially for bosses. Most of the time will be spent exploring the foreboding city, filled with depth of scenery and gritty recesses. During combat, punches and kicks sound delightfully crunch. The score is dark and undulating fitting the macabre mood of the game with razor-precision, accomplished with delicate plucking contrasted by stringed instruments and distortion. Mark Hamill reprises his role as the voice of the Joker and knocks it out of the park, bringing a video game character to life in a way I have never seen before. Conclusion: I came into this game with low expectations and left feeling a connection to the Batman franchise. If attempting to restore sanity and order in a dystopia filled to the brim with villains sounds like your piece of cake, then it's time to suit up.

												3 out of 5, fun at first, disjointed, repetitive and boring later.  I LOVED LOVED LOVED Asylum, but this game does not live up to the fun of the first.  This game takes place in a much larger world than the first game, however the world is boring and lifeless, and you will spend most of your time doing busywork to upgrade your character.  With all of the side missions this is a lengthy game, I wish they focused more on the core story.  The fun Riddler riddles from the first game have been replaced tons of boring easy puzzles.  It's not a bad game, but nowhere near as good as 1.  The boss battles are good.  In the first game you likely left detective mode turned on the whole game, in this game they made detective mode worse, encouraging you to turn it off.

												A slightly sequel to previous Batman's game "Batman: Arkham Asylum". Only in this game you get to play in a lot bigger area and with wider story, more to explore and more characters to discover. As previous game, it's done by Rocksteady, applying the same formula. Basically it's improved Batman: Arkham Asylum. Everything you got from Arkham Asylum is find here, only more. More villains, more missions, bigger story, more playable characters (as Catwoman, Robin) and more glitches (or bugs). But in this game those bugs will make you laugh more that be angry. I was able to see during a combat a henchman flying to the skys. Also challenges are more, but that is a minus. If you are aiming for 100% achievements, you have to do maps over and over and over and over again. And controls aren't places very well. I tried to play with a keyboard and with a controller, but I offen found Batman doing something I didn't told him to do ( like instead of running away, he took cover right next to enemy and got filled with bullets) And during a combat, Batman will attack to his desired enemy. But few bugs there and there doesn't make this game worse, it's forgivable since the story is very wide and there is a lot to discover.

content:
Posted: February 24
												Personal Rating: 7 of 10If you haven't played Arkham Asylum, I highly recommend you to tackle that first as this is a direct sequel to the game. Arkham City gameplay is very similar to Arkham Asylum. You get to access to a part Gotham City infested with bad guys but unfortunately no vehicle. There are several buildings that are interactable and missions mostly take part in them.The City is very well design and the dark gloomy environment really set the mood. Also, do expect top notch voice actors (do a little digging and you might be surprised) like Arkham Asylum but personally, I prefer the voice actor for Batman in Asylum. It just feels like the actor for City is much subtle.Story is linear with a little bit of plot but don't really raise my eyebrow. Again, I would prefer Asylum over this on the aspect. There are much more bosses in this game but they don't gel together for me. Its like too much cook spoils the broth. Some of the villians sits entirely out from the main story line and to get to them you need to perform the same mission over and over again. Boss fights are not as satisfying as Asylum. Most of them are timing and button mashing.Level design in my opinion are not as creative as Asylum. Most of the time is jump into fight, clear them and move on. Certain places allows you to take the sneaky way but approach method are not that many. I mean I am Batman, I don't want to hang around some ledge of scurry around some corners to catch someone unexpected. I want something like swoop down or left to take someone off.There are some new gadgets, puzzles, enemies and other combat features but after these has been introduced, you will be using it again and again and again.Maybe because of the quest, huge city and repetitiveness, it makes me feel like I am Gotham's slave rather den its knight. Game works really well without any problems for me. Clearly, the designer really stick to the idea of not fixing what is not broken but I really think this could have been better. Overall, this game had much more feature than its predecessor but can be a little frustrating and repetitive at times but being a Batman or even a third person action game person, this title can definitely provide good fun.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												Great game, well worth the price for the hours of entertainment you will get out of it. The crazy number of Riddler challenges seems daunting at first but it was actually quite fun colecting them all and the H2H combat is much improved over Batman:AA. When this game was announced I wondered how could they improve on such an epic game, I was not dissapointed. Pays good lip service to the comics and contains the best voice over cast ever to do the Batman franchise, Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamil in my mind are the best Batman and Joker combination ever concieved and they both delievered yet again. The gadgetry is well thought out and a nice improvement over Batman:AA The catwoman gameplay felt a little tacked on, especially the bonus missions, it just felt like they couldn't think of anything else to do with her. The revenge of Harley was actually a nice DLC add on that was a pretty good couple of hours, well worth the original price, and gives you a nice hands on with Robin. Robin definitely feels inferior to Batman in H2H which just adds to the greatness of Batman himself. Graphically the game is real nice running on the newet iteration of the unreal engine but nothing really ground breaking. Does the job and no real complaints, I just wish they would ditch Phys-X for something else. Sound wise the game is absolutely great, the atmosphere is fantastic and the sound track is fitting as always. Rocksteady has made a real masterpiece here and it is a great shame they have been denied the opportunity to do another sequel. I have played through both Batman AA and AC multiple times and enjoyed every moment of every play through.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												Rating: 9.5/10What is it?Third Person Action Adventure The Good:+The most important part of a Batman game is the 'feeling' of Batman. The way he moves, controls, gadgets and game play all facilitate towards that goal making you feel like you are in complete control of your surroundings. +The combat is fun and challenging requiring timing and precision to master. +Stealth is excellent, finding the right balance between fun and realism. The AI isn't so brain dead that you can kill them with ease nor are they super realistic that they will spot you a mile away.  +Solid sense of progression and upgrades. Gaining experience unlocks more powerful combat moves and gadgets. + Open World is detailed with lots of collectables and side quests.+ One of the few games that does collectables right. Some of the collectables are easy to get while other require a bit of thinking. The game also provides a way of unlocking collectables on the mini map so you don't need to use a guide to collect them all. Collecting riddler trophies unlocks new concept art, predator maps and helps you finish the riddler's side quest.  + Fantastic boss fights + Great cast of characters + Predator maps and combat maps further the replay value giving you extra challenges. You can play as Batman, Catwoman, Robin and Nightwing+ Great voice acting and sound + Game is gorgeous. + New Game Plus- Upgrades carry over. The Bad:- Some plot holes in the main story-Getting all the achievements will take a lot of work. Nitpicky issue, but going through all the maps with each of the four characters is exhausting. ConclusionThis is one of the best Batman games, this is one of the best action adventure games. You can tell Rocksteady put a lot of blood sweat and tears into this game to make it the best it can possibly be. The game is extremely polished and a joy to play with insane value. No matter what price you buy this game you will get your money's worth .

Posted: February 25
												Pros:    + Very large open world    + Great character dialogue    + Gadgets    + Decent enemies    + You're freaking BATMANCons:    - Fighting gets monotonous  Review     Batman: Arkham City - GOTY is a third-person superhero game with a large open world. Of course, you mainly play as Batman, although there are several scenes with Catwoman that were not included in the original console version.   Batman was placed in the city that is filled with tons of bad guys and he has to escape by defeating the bosses that include, of course The Joker. It is the second installment in the Batman Arkham series. I think that It's the best one in the series and strongly recommend it. Wait for a sale though because 20 bucks is a lot to pay for a six year old game.This game was curated and reviewed for PC Beta gaming, if you would like to follow, the link is here - http://steamcommunity.com/groups/PC-BetaG

content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												Overall: 9/10Concept: 10/10Play as Batman and occasionally as Catwoman. Robin and Nightwing are available in DLC challenge maps. Explore, fight, and solve crime in 3rd person throughout Gotham. Has a solid story and even more solid combat system, aside from the occasional glitch.Graphics: 10/10I would say that for its time, Batman: Arkham City has top of the line graphics. The Batman character model is well done, coupled with the environment, this leads to some impressive views when sitting atop a roof or overhang. The game is well optimized too. With graphics on highest settings I never dropped below 60fps. Sound: 9/10The voice acting is very well done, significantly enhancing the experience. Most sound effects and background noise are spot on as well. What really bothered me in this category however, was that the simple thugs you're fighting 80% time, had really redundant dialogue that grated on my nerves after 20+ hours of game play. Playability: 9/10Most of the time this game ran very smoothly. I commend how well combat flows, not to mention the fun variety of side missions and overall story. However I did often find myself "cheated" in combat, with enemies sliding ridiculous distances to score a punch outside of my peripheral vision. The combat system is easy to learn, hard to master, allowing you to jump right in, but still enjoy the combat hours later as you learn to incorporate new abilities into your fighting style.Entertainment: 10/10I really enjoyed this game. The story kept me involved, and the side missions were interesting enough to give a breath of fresh air. With the quality voice acting and graphics, it's almost like watching a movie. The combat is satisfying, and entertaining. The freedom of movement throughout the city is great too, grappling, gliding, sliding, sneaking, and running between and to your foes.Replay: 6/10Although new game plus is implemented, allowing you to go through the game again with your upgrades and skills unlocked, there's not much more to be gained entertainment-wise. The story-line and game play albeit being very fun, have no real deviation from the first time through. There are a plethora of DLC additions and challenge maps adding many hours of additional game play, but I've found these to be extremely tedious after the first few hours. (If you're looking to 100% this game expect to spend close to 60 hours repeating dozens of challenge maps over and over with every character,)

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2013
												Best. Game. Ever.I will go over 5 topics in this review.Story, Gameplay, Graphics, Sound and Replay ValueFirst off The Story.It is around 12-15 hours all-up storywise and it is truely gripping and a great premise. Without spoiling anything, The game is set a couple of years after Arkham Asylum, and the newly appointed mayor Quincy Sharp Ex Warden of old Arkham Asylum has created a super prison dubbed ARKHAM CITY, Sure just throw all the bad guys in one place and throw away the key, Like thats gonna work!It's up to Batman to sort all this out, by punching every Super-Villan in the face!The Character list in the main game, not to mention the side missions is huge, more than I can say but from the trailers of course you have Hugo Strange, The Joker, Two-Face, Catwoman, The Riddler, EVEN Solomon Grundy is here, if you like the comics you will love the detail the devs have put into this game.Next Gameplay, what good is an amazing story without gameplay?You for the most part of the game play as BATMAN, the worlds greatest Crimefighter and Detective, Both of which are put to work as you Grappel around the place, glide, Throw Batman's Signature Batarangs and fire his disarming Bat-Claw, and of course the magnificent FreeFlow combat from the previous game upscaled and infused with more awesome. Double Takedowns, Counters (Or more if those thugs dare hitting you at the same time!) The combat is improved dramatically and encouraging more use of using your gadgets more than ever during your combat and it really pays to do so!Graphics: I am not one to judge a game by its Graphics usually... But this game, is really pretty! So much detail in the enviroments you fly around in and well rendered character models all make this game truely immersive!Sound:The games sound is standout both in its strong epic soundtrack and the Excellent voice acting brought to us again in both Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamil repectively as Batman and The Joker, and the countless other characters from supporting characters like Alfred and Oracle to the complaining of the thugs you encounter on the street as Batman, this level of Voice Acting really makes the experience come alive.Replay Value:In addition to the main story you have a bunch of side quests, which are varied and interesting to play through and give Batman more time to show off his Detective Skills.The Riddler is the largest side mission, he has hidden large amounts of riddler trophies and created riddles all over Arkham City for Batman to collect and solve, and you won't turn a blind eye to this if you did in the previous game, the Riddler has hostages who he will kill if Batman doesn't solve enough of his riddles before the night is over. Also completing the Riddlers Challenges unlock Concept art and 3-D Character trophies for you to look at in the main menu which is sweet if you are into that!Aside from the many side quests there is a seperate gamemode called New Game Plus unlocked after you complete the game on Normal/Hard, which allows you to play the story again, With all of your upgrades! The Catch? No Counter icons in combat, and pretty much everything about the gameplay has gotten four times as hard. (Good Luck Beating Two-Face as Catwoman :P)Once you have done all of this to keep you entertained there is a mode called "Riddlers Revenge" a bunch of small levels usually of either Plain Combat or Predator rooms each of which you have to complete objectives for to get a High Score on that Leaderboard!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												Before I start this review, I would like to note that I REALLY reccomend this game. I got it last week and I have about 24 hours in it already. One of the best games I have played by far. Onto the review!  Batman: Arkham City is a 3rd Person Beat 'em Up game. Of course, there are more aspects to this game as well, such as the stealth, and the detective work. When you start out this game, you are shoved into Arkham City, a walled-off section of Gotham City that houses all of Gotham's dangerous criminals. The person behind this "Arkham City", Hugo Strange, has a plan labelled "Protocol 10", which Batman seems to be very suspicious of, and for good reason. Now, enough story, how does this game play? Well, first off, there is no jump button, something that I am used to, as I have played many tLoZ games, but that's not what we're talking about. Instead, there's a "run" button, which is space. You can run off of buildings and ledges and the game will make you jump then. That is the most obvious difference from other 3rd person games. Getting around Arkham City is quite easy, as you can grapple to far away buildings and ledges, and you can upgrade this ablility so that it allows you to get launched quite a ways from where you intended to grapple. The combat system is AMAZING, you could jump into a group of enemies, and take them all out because of how it works. It's really only a 2 button system, with the attack and counter button, but it works so well! I could keep going on and on about the positives of this game, but it'd be pointless. It took me about 10 hours to get through the main campaign on normal mode, and I'm replaying it on the hardest difficulty. There are sidequests and end-game DLC to keep you playing after the main campaign, and there are challenges you could do, such as taking out a group of enemies using stealth, or just jumping in and beating them up, there's so much to do. My only complaint is that there are waaaaay too many Riddler Trophies to get, and 100%-ing the game will take much more time. But that is just one complaint in a game full of positives, so I give this game a 9.5/10.

Posted: February 19, 2016
												Batman Arkham City- Game of the Year EditionNot as atmospheric as Arkham AsylumDon't be irritated by the 3 hours. I played it at least two times when it came out. In the following text, I'll be comparing it to Arkham Asylum a lot, so excuse me, if you haven't played it yet.First thing that got me when I started Arkham City were the graphics, definitely better than those in Arkham Asylum. And also the nice cutscene right at the beginning. Then I started playing it. It was and still is the exact same game, according to the gameplay. Only the story and setting are different, alas both above average. I enjoyed playing both, as I have loved Batman ever since I was a small kid. But I liked Arkham Asylum a lot more. It had this dark, gritty tone which Arkham City lacks most of the time. And it also had these crazy hallucinatory Scarecrow- missions. Ah, and also highly memorable, the moment when you thought the game had broken. To me, Arkham Asylum will always be the definitive Batman game. It may not have a world as open as in Arkham City, it may not be as long, but it is atmospheric as f**k.Still, I give Arkham City8/10enjoy it
