content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
												Yes, it is Arkham: Asylum perfected in an open world environment. I’d even argue that this might be the pinnacle of the series with their tweaks to combat and use of gadgets. They did a tremendous job of hearing out their core audience, and did their best to gather up a bigger cast of characters, made hand-to-hand combat more challenging not in terms of more button mashing but actual strategy, and created grandiose environments that made for both stellar level design and screen captures (seriously - it was a beautiful game for its time).  The story itself is much more dimensional than its predecessor. However, as expected with such a large supporting cast, your favourite villians might not get as much screen time as you’d like them to. Well, except for Joker and Harley - they’re in it almost all the way through. It was neat to see them there, but there were points in the narrative where they definitely felt shoe-horned. However, this was largely overshadowed by the Series’ best boss battles yet. I will write that while I’m sure you’re only going to be looking at this when the next sale for this rolls around, do not go for the DLC. It’s a 30 minute quest that just feels like total and absolute filler. It adds almost nothing to the story, and truly feels like cut content pre-packaged for release later on. You’ll be happy enough with the 10+ hour story you have ahead of you. It’s pretty coherent on the whole, but the act structure is a bit of a dragged out middle game only to have your eyes glued to the screen for the last 2-3 hours. After you beat it, you unlock a NG+ mode where you’re just collecting upgrades and you have all of your gadgets at the start so it’s easier to collect items you’d have trouble getting at the start of your first playthrough. It was a nice thought, but it’s one of those once-was-enough kind of games to me. And that really comes down to mediocre writing and the repetitive style of combat. Gameplay-wise, you’ll be happy to know that they gave you more buttons and combos to stress on your controller (the preferred method of playing the series). There are a lot of filler sidequests that you might end up doing just for the sake of upgrading Batman. I don’t blame you, but the kind of quests they ask you to do really take you away from the story and offer little in return. That’s great for fans of the world, but not entirely necessary for people that just want to play it for its best parts and move on. Aside from its unlocks, the rest of the stuff they offer in return is pretty minimal - unless you care about character bios and concept art that’s not flatout presented in the narrative. It just depends on how big of a fan you are. You’ll also notice some significant upgrades in the graphics. That I can’t stress enough - right down to the game’s core meme of cape physics. You’ll find yourself twirling around simply for the hell of it. The open world environment is also nice when you’re being pulled to certain locations in the main story, but it was just so bleak and I was given little reason to explore its entirety. I would have liked for the narrative to take me deeper into the lore of Arkham city or try to somehow make me care about why the world is the way it is.The music was your typical omniscient superhero themes - its mood borders on consistently dreary, but it won’t hurt your ears. It just felt very generic. Same for the sound effects - they didn’t add much to the mood that the visuals weren’t already giving off. TL;DR: This was a just sequel to an already-phenomenal game, and should easily satisfy addicts of the Batman universe and quality action games for at least ten hours.

												Loved playing this game. The combination of open ended content along with story line was great. If I had any gripe it's that some of the combo moves are more difficult on the PC with the use of keys but there are so many extremely good things about this game it pales. The game play is so intense I actually had minor vertigo when climbing up high in one of the scenes!The main story line is long enough to seem like an actual full story but short enough that I managed to complete it & I'm often lead off course by side missions & rarely complete the main story 1st so the fact I finished it should say something.Yet, I'm still playing the game regularly afterwards which should say more.  Between the combat & the predator modes there's literally 2 different play styles you can either "snipe" or 'button mash' and progress either way.Definitely an awesome game and I mean come on you can even dress as 70's Batman!

content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												This game... oh this game... This is the perfect mixture of old batman comics, the batman cartoon-series and the new Christopher Nolan-batman. You start of as mr Wayne, thrown into "Arkham City", a city at the edge of Gotham, a city with walls around it, a city just for criminals. Why did you get thrown in? Play and find out. I'm not gonna give too much of the story away.Anyway, all your favorite villains are here! Two-face, Mr Freeze, Poison Ivy and of course, the joker! These are just a few of the villains. Me, I'm a sucker for the "loonies" so I was so happy when I noticed that both "the Joker" and "The riddler" were in the same game! This is the ultimate batmangame!But frankly, not everything in this game is great. Some of the puzzles are easy, most of the battles are rather easy once you get the hang of it, and the ending is a disappointment. This are just a few flaws tho, the game in it's entirety is brilliant.I would go as far as to say, this is the best licencegame since... yeah, I'm gonna say it, "The return of the king" (Lord of the rings)Verdict+Amazing graphics+So many cool villains+Open world+Really nice voiceacting-Rather short-Really varied when it comes to difficulty -The ending8/10Get this game!

content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												Not much to say except for: Amazing story with a great twist. Level design and graphics with love to detail - even on such a large scale. Great gameplay with lots of freedom in an Open World environment. Played over 300h, didn't encounter a single bug! Only small downturn: Except for 2, most of the side quests weren't up to much. Extra content is great, though. Fair price for the quality of the game; worthy "AAA"-game. A real downer is changing the audio language settings: The reason might be due to some payment issues of foreign language voice actors, but you basically need to change 3 configuration files in order to set the spoken language.If you liked Assassin's Creed, you'll love it. Even though, I am not a fan of US-Superheroes, the game is captivating and is among my Top 5 games of all time.Edit: After playing all 4 Arkham games, this is still the best to me!My personal order 1, AC 2, AK 3, AA 4, AO.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												Batman Arkham City- Game of the Year EditionNot as atmospheric as Arkham AsylumDon't be irritated by the 3 hours. I played it at least two times when it came out. In the following text, I'll be comparing it to Arkham Asylum a lot, so excuse me, if you haven't played it yet.First thing that got me when I started Arkham City were the graphics, definitely better than those in Arkham Asylum. And also the nice cutscene right at the beginning. Then I started playing it. It was and still is the exact same game, according to the gameplay. Only the story and setting are different, alas both above average. I enjoyed playing both, as I have loved Batman ever since I was a small kid. But I liked Arkham Asylum a lot more. It had this dark, gritty tone which Arkham City lacks most of the time. And it also had these crazy hallucinatory Scarecrow- missions. Ah, and also highly memorable, the moment when you thought the game had broken. To me, Arkham Asylum will always be the definitive Batman game. It may not have a world as open as in Arkham City, it may not be as long, but it is atmospheric as f**k.Still, I give Arkham City8/10enjoy it

content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												Where do I start? This is probably one of the best games ever made. It's a true gem that has little to no flaws whatsoever. The graphics are superb, the story is great, the voice acting is amazing, the gameplay is a spot on. In short, it's a true joy to play.The game revolves around a small section of Gotham City, known now as "Arkham City", where gangs and thugs seem to have free-run of there own little slice of Gotham. It allows much greater freedom than Arkham Asylum did - and is all the better for it. You start with all the abilities and gadgets that you picked up in the previous game, and unlock a ton more too. As such, it may have a steep learning curve for people that did not play the previous game, but once you get into it, it's fluid, responsive and great fun.Upgrades to your Batsuit and character(s) abilities are bought with XP, that is earned fighting thugs - and you are rewarded for slick moves, long combos and variety. You can also quick-fire gadgets during combat, adding another really cool addition to the game.If you are still not sure about this one, ask yourself the following questions (2 points for yes, 1 for no - and add up your score to determine if you should buy the game).1. Do you like Batman?2. Do you like games?3. Do you like gadgets?4. Are you still reading this?5. Just go and buy it. You will not regret it, will you?Score <= 5 : Buy itScore >= 6 : Buy itScore >= 8 : Buy itScore >= 10 : Buy itJimbo Rating: 10/10

Posted: July 5, 2014
												I'll start of by saying this game had the best superhero campaign I have ever played. This is the only game in which I did not skip any cutscenes and enjoyed all of them; the script was written so excellent that you feel like they are truly talking to you. Like how Joker tries to talk to you and makes you oblivious to the tricks he has up his sleeves, or someone like Two-Face who just yells at his henchmen to blow you to bits! The gameplay is flawless and smooth without any hiccups, and it's also easy to learn for anyone new to the game. I would recommend this game to anyone and everyone who likes to play video games, because not only is this a game for comic book fans but it's an game for every gamer out there. 10/10.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												One of the best games I've ever played. The game has all you want: a good main story, interesting side-quests, many of the Batman important enemies from the comics are in this game, boss battles (especially Mr. Freeze and Ra's al Ghul battles) are very well done, voice actors fit the characters very good (especially Mark Hamill voice as Joker), an awesome soundtrack, good PC optimization (this game runs on a weak laptop with high settings), and also the fighting system is perfectly done, encouraging you to use gadgets or stealth. As cons, I would have liked the city to be bigger and the game to have some events like Crime alerts from Arkham Origins. In conclusion, this game is 9.5/10, and definitely one of the best games ever made. It doesn't matter if you aren't a Batman fan, this game would make you one. Also I recommend before playing this game to play Arkham Asylum.

Posted: September 1, 2014
												First of all I want to say that Batman Arkham City is the best open world game ever made(honestly it falls on top 3 as others may like different games)I have only 60+ hours on Steam version of this game, before I bought a gaming PC I used to play this game on a cloud gaming service called Onlive, and there I have 250+ hours on this game. Played this game so much because I really like this game. The Arkham City Story is very interesting, the characters was played by a great cast with very good voice acting. As you progress you unlock upgrades for Batman, The side missions are amazing. The Mystery Watcher, Character Hush....Riddler Trophies are an interesting part of this game. Some of them require some thinking, I collected all 440 trophies. The best part about this game I like is the combat and beating up thugs. The challenge maps are so fun. The most 2 fun challenge maps are Iceberg Lounge and Joker's Funhouse. Iceberg Lounge has unlimited wave of enemies that you could fight as long as you survive. I once got a 1157 combo in that map.And Joker's Funhouse is also another fun map that makes you keep on playing on you start learning not to get hit and how to keep on going.I totally recommend this game, it has great graphics, very well optimized. Totally worth every dollar and penny you spend on it.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												Batman Arkham City is a fun game. It has an excellent story, and at the time of the first games release, a revolutionary fighting style. While it may be played out and stolen by now, it is still great to see the game that first created it, and how well they were using it. The plot of the story, while I will not give more away than the beginning, leads off of the first game:  Batman is kidnapped as Bruce Wayne by Hugo Strange, and thrown into a maximum security prison/city called Arkham City. Soon after arriving, he finds out that the Joker is sick, and after some shenanigans by the clown, he is made sick as well, leading him to have to find Mr. Freeze and get a cure. The game is surprisingly difficult, and has a strong sense of stealth, especially in the Predator missions, where you have to take out a room full of armed gunmen, who are incredibly dangerous to you. You can use a large array of high tech tools; Smoke bombs, batarangs, and grappling hooks being some of the simplest, to defeat them without dying. My favourite part, however, is the Riddler. He sets up a whole bunch of puzzles for you to find and solve, giving you missions to play outside of the main game, as well as concept art and character trophies. It is a very fun game, and earns a excellent score of 8/10

content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
 Batman Arkham City GOTY review Batman Arkham City is another great game from Rocksteady studios. While they weren't able to recapture the atmosphere of loneliness, depression and madness of the asylum, it is still a very captivating experience. Combat The combat was improved, making the stun less useless and the special finish moves less useless. New enemy types are also a thing in this game, you have your standard henchmen, henchmen armed with guns, knives, stunsticks, henchmen carrying shields and MOTHERF*CKING NINJAS.The game now has an open world, it is now set in the northen part of Gotham that has been sealed off. Story The story is great but feels very short, and even though there are side mission you can do after finishing the main story, they just feel like the devs were lazy and just plopped these in to extend the playtime.The Harley Quinn's Revenge DLC is welcome addition to the story albeit a bit short. It nicely depicts the characters and the change they went through after Joker's death. DLC As stated before, Harley Quinn's Revenge is a great addition to the main storyline, however the rest of the extra content is forgettable at best. Same goes for the challenge maps (I didn't want to make another section for that :P), the over-abundance of them makes them feel very cheap and uninteresting (I personally haven't actually bothered to play most of the maps in City or even Origins).Overall, Arkham City is a great experience and a (weaker) followup to Arkham Asylum and I strongly recommend playing the games in chronological order as it helps to understand the story.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Awesome game. Truly one of the greatest.The controls are sharp even though you still cannot adjust the mouse sensitivity as I hoped but the camera speed is fast enough. There is still some sloppiness and slight delay when it comes to moving around. For instance just like in the first game, there are preset points where your grappling hook works - you can't pick your spots. Initially, there are too many HUD oriented hints, and even though you can turn off some, you cannot turn them all off. The game itself doesn't have that much hud especially in-doors which is a good thing in my opinion because it helps the immersion.The city map is small. REALLY small by today's standards at least. It's at best 30 square blocks. But the good thing is that eventually you get access to restricted areas such as houses, mansions, sewers, etc. So you will be doing a lot of backtracking just like in the first game, only this time, you have an open map and not a series of large closed off areas to navigate in. Plus there is always something happening in the city and you will see the city change as you play. Barely anything is static.The gameplay (battle-wise). I feel like it changed slightly for worst in some areas. The first game would literally force you to watch your enemies and anticipate their movies so you could counter-attack. This time it's different. This time you will see several lightening bolts flash above enemies that are about to attack you. This warning throws me off because it decreases the challenge and realism. However, if you want to play the second time on hardest mode then these warnings disappear which is neat. On the other hand, the fighting is at the same time easier than in the first game because you can actually counter-several enemies who are about to punch you at the same time - something you couldn't do in the first game.More so, what's tedious is that this time you will be battling sometimes about a dozen of enemies at a time. You will rarely be able to finish off your enemies while they are on the ground because you will be overwhelmed for the most part. While playing the PS3 version, my thumb frequently got tired at the time of battling. But that problem when away because of simply mouse clicks which do not require as much energy as tapping a button, evidently. So I actually did not die as many times as I did while playing the PS3 version.Also, this time if you want to counter-attack CONSTANTLY and never get hit (Except for when they try to throw a trash can at you) is to simply tap right the right mouse button (NO TIMING REQUIRED this time). In the first game if you pressed the counter-attack button a lot earlier before the preceding attack, then you would get hit, even IF you pressed the same button right after. The first game really forced you to monitor your enemies closely and work out the algorithm of the fight you were in. But at least now you can counter-attack two enemies attacking you at the same time.But eventually you get introduced to bigger and badder high-tech enemies that force you to employ different tactics (reminiscent of the last splinter cell game).Another minus is that there is no blood in the game, again. (but yes I know that this is Batman Universe, the villains never die, they simply escape over and over and over again....)Also, those annoying unrealistic bats that fly around you are still there. There's still no way to turn them off.Also, this time around, there are even more unlockables to unlock. There are still Joker teeth, but now there are Penguin's penguin dolls, air balloons and other miscellaneous interactive items that need to be destroyed upon sight.The story is engaging and ties itself well with the first game somewhat. Some villains as well as their demise gets mentioned so it's kind of cool to wonder what happened. The boss fights are okaish but the one that I didn't like was with that immortal dude. I mean the whole stage with him and the subsequent fight was just an excuse for Batman to fight some more (even though he was dreaming). Same applies tot he Mad Hatter stage of the game, it's just more fighting, albeit it is disturbing fighting. I think they could use more creativity with these stages. One of the best boss fights without a doubt is with Mr. Freeze, it can last for up to 20 minutes and you do have to use your brains. Sadly, that was the most developed boss battle in the entire game.Also, barely ANY dialogue gets repeated, ever, except for sometimes. I'm surprised how much effort went into dialogue here, it's like watching a movie, a good Batman movie that is, ahem ahem.The loading screen sometimes takes 11 seconds.I also appreciate the remix of the Hans Zimmer soundtracks from the last two Batman movies. Nice touch. There's some inception there too.The bosses and the characters are all so versatile and flamboyant. You get fully immersed in their personalities and you don't really want the villains dead you may want them hurt but you don't want them GONE because then you know that the fun is over. So the game makes you care even about the villains because aside from Batman that's what the Batman Universe if famous for. However, you do not really get to see too much of the villains. You only see the Two-Face a couple of times and you do not even see Killer Croc.The amount of the Riddler riddles and tricks is insane. I'm not sure if that many were needed. I mean, they are supposed to be concealed better; they are supposed to take time to find and unlock like in the first game. Here you get a large portion of them practically for free, but as you progress you realize that Batman has a whopping 400 riddler secrets to unlock and the cat woman has 100. A small portion of them (like 5-10%) is extremely hard to solve, some require blind luck which is annoying.The game is extremely well refined. Ever step and area is thought out, every engagement can still be approached differently so the gameplay will never get you bored. The artistic value of this game cannot be understated. The gangs and the bandits all have different allegiances to different villains, so it is a nice touch to see that not all villains team up with each other, they all have different missions and ideologies.The amount of upgrades here is about 3-4 times than the amount in the first game and you retain most if not all of your abilities from the first game.One of the downsides of this game being an open-worlded game is that quite often you will lose your sense of direction. You might weight out your priorities as to where it is you want to go. There's main mission and there are side missions and there are Riddler missions and there are miscellaneous missions. You might go into one direction only to realize that it's best if you went another direction. The first game didn't have that problem if you can call it that. Still, the world is not too big for you to get lost and it is not too small to be called a sand-box.One of the downsides of the PS3 version was slow texture loading. I haven't experienced anything like that on PC. AND, the loading time between deaths is about twice as short as on the PS3, go figure.Lastly, it's the same unreal engine from the last game; the water looks slightly better rendered on the PC, but it is not that great looking either.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												This game is beyond reproach. Everything from the opening minutes of the cutscenes to the final minutes of the soundtrack are perfectly polished. Every punch and kick thrown in combat is choreographed flawlessly and the sounds and sights of Arkham City create an impressive world for Batman to survey and protect from itself. The story takes so many twists and turns and even if you think you'll know who the next villain is going to be, you're going to have no idea what you're getting yourself into. Batman's got to use every tool at his disposal not just to survive, but to learn the secrets of Arkham City and stop the dangerous path that awaits Gotham's mega-prison on this fateful night.You can look at other reviews, they'll describe technically better what you can expect out of this game. But if you really think you're up for the challenge of being Batman during one of his darkest nights, fighting one of his most climactic fights, pick up this game now. It's time to don the cowl, for better or worse.

												Notice: over 12,000 positive reviews and 430 negative ones. The negative ones obviously are complaints that their PC can't handle the graphics.....or they're stuck in some part of the game and so it's the game's fault. I think this is the best of the Arkham games. I've played 3.There have been numerous times I thought I wouldn't figure out parts of this game, It's one challenge after another. That's why it's the best.I played a lot of the game on console back when it came out. I think I gave up somewhere in the riddler part. That, to me, is the most frustrating part.It isn't an easy game. But, there's so much to do, that it's worth every penny and all the frustration.I'm finisahing this game this time around. Also, I wannna meet the girl they used to model catwoman. Sheeesh. That's one hot looking character.Does anyone know why credits roll at 35%? Is it just that that part of the Joker story  as written and designed separately?Doesn't matter. Once you beat the Joker at 35%, you get the downloadable batsuits to play the rest.And there's A LOT more.All the best villians make an appearance. A few for just a few minutes.I haven't finished this game ever. So, I hear someone in game say "there's two Jokers? "Does that mean anything? I don't know yet. I'm busy trying to find Mr. Freeze's wife.....while trying to solve several murders and riddles galore.Totally addictive game......even the 2nd time around. I'm finding new stories and characters at every turn. Who is the mysterious figure watching Batman's every move?I saw Robin for a minute. Is he coming back? Is the mysterious figure Nightwing?Have fun with this one. Of the 4 Arkham games, this one is , by far, the best.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												While the first entry shows how a Batman video game should be made, the second one takes you to a new level. Well let me break down some details for you.a.StoryThe story of Batman has never been this frustrating. On the first series, Batman has been made confused by the infamous evil Joker's plan. Doctor Hugo Strange, Ra's al Ghul, and once again, Joker, put him on hard times even more than ever where he has to put down the chaos made in Arkham City in. Very interesting and engaging.b.GameplayWe know that Batman, among the Justice League, is the weakest. But, in the game he actually a badass. The free flow combat system makes him really strong and gives an awesome feeling when you hit the last enemy within a combo chain. You can also access many gadgets the dark knight can offer. Fantasy of being the bat came true.c.GraphicsI really like look of the game. The aura of Arkham City nightmare is felt really well. Atmosphere of injustice brings down upon the chaotic city of Arkham. What I like the most is that it can run on my computer very well with almost no performance issues.d.ReplayabilityIt is always good to back as "The Dark Knight". You can choose different customisation (character upgrade) from previous playthrough and try to play the hardest difficulty. Well, if you don't fancy yourself challenge modes, have yourself a new game plus.VerdictIt is the best Batman game, beating bad guys on the streets in the most dangerous area out there in the world to bring justice is very noble.Verdict9.0

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												(CONTAINS WHAT SOME MAY CONSIDER AS SPOILERS. HOWEVER NONE OF THESE "SPOILERS" ARE STORY-RELATED)Seeing as I just passed the 100 hour mark, I feel obligated to write a review. I always thought Batman was cool but I never really knew much about him. I never read the comics (it isn't such a big thing in my country, unlike in the US) and I haven't even watched all the movies about him. But these games...BUY THESE GAMES!!There isn't a single bad thing I can say about this game! I love every minute of it and I have played it a lot.It gives you a bigger playground than the last game and faster ways to make your way around it. Also there's a second playable character, a feline femme fatale who makes for a nice change every once in a while. With her unique skills, she can get to Riddler Trophies that Batman can't collect or can't reach.There are tons of Riddler Challenges to complete and find all over the world and I really love the fact that you can find them all without using a guide. These challenges unlock extras like character biographies, villain interview tapes, artwork and much more!! They really made me interested in everything about Batman. The stories or mysteries of how most villains came to be what they are, the reasons they have for hating Batman or Bruce Wayne, their twisted minds and extreme personalities, ... I LOVE IT!The combat in the Arkham games is what makes you feel so powerful! The satisfaction you get by taking out a whole group of thugs without getting hit, makes you feel like a complete BADASS! In this game the combat is even more fluent and seamless than the first. You can now use more different gadgets and use multi-counters (countering multiple enemies who attack at the same time) to dispatch of thugs. This gives you even more opportunities to make it through fights with dozens of thugs without getting hit.There's also the complete opposite of that when you're taking out a whole group of thugs one by one, using stealth and gadgets. The choice is yours, both give you satisfaction.And of course, by fighting and solving riddler challenges, you level up and can choose many upgrades. Almost all of them are necessary, especially when you're playing it on Hard or New Game+ difficulty. These difficulties also make you utilize the stealth-opportunities more, because a large group of thugs can be quite dangerous then.There are also many cool (and unexpected) boss fights and this game also has moments that take you to other "places" than Arkham City. The first time I played this game, it kept blowing me away. Now that I think about it, they've really done a fine job keeping the environment interesting. It can't have been easy if the main colors of your game are black and grey.The DLC costumes and Sidechapter also give you a refreshing experience after completing the game for the first time.Now I'm going to end this review, because I could keep yapping about this game. Instead I'm going to play it!tl;dr This game makes you become the bat. It's also one of the best games in the world and probably the universe.BUY ALL ARKHAM GAMES!!!P.S. - The story is GREAT!!!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Take Arkham Asylum, add more of everything, improve the combat system and you have Arkham City.The Combat - Compared to Arkham Asylum the combat has greatly improved as it's playing much more fluid now. The slow motion effect from the predecessor has been reduced, which makes it easier - at least for me - to time my hits and counters.The Story - I'm neither a comic book expert nor a Batman expert so I don't know how Arkham City's story compares to other Batman stories. Nevertheless the story seems fairly standard to me. Save the world - or in this case Arkham City - from destruction. There is a second story arc involving the Joker which is the more interesting one, in my opinion.The voice acting is superb. Especially Mark Hamill as the Joker is incredible.The Sidequests - Arkham Asylum had two side quests which only involved collecting stuff and solving riddles. Arkham City has about a dozen side quests and most of them feature other known characters from the Batman universe, the Mad Hatter, Zsasz etc. Although they bring a nice variety to the game, they don't always fit into the pace of the main story, e.g. the main story gives the impression that time is running out and Batman should move quickly to his next location, yet you're able to do the side quests. It's not like that you have some world-saving to do or anything... But this problem appears to happen in a lot of open world games and I might be the only one who is a bit annoyed by that. To sum ist up: the side quests are fun, but I would recommend doing most of them after you finished the story, so they fit into the canon.The Collectibles - While a chore in most games, Arkham City makes it actually fun to collect them. The high number of 440 collectibles/riddles might be a bit overwhelming in the beginning, but compared to other games (*cough* Assassin's Creed *cough*) they serve a purpose because they are necessary for finishing the Riddler side quest.Post-game - What to do after you finished the story? Hunting for achievements of course. The challenges from Arkham Asylum made it back into the game. You can either do combat challenges and fight in four rounds against a batch of enemies improving your highscores or you can do the predator challanges where you have to silently take out a group of enemies.New in this game are the campaigns which are pretty much the same as the challenge maps, except that one campaign consists of three challenge maps and a bunch of positive and negative modifiers which you have to apply to each map.If you're going for all 64 achievements you have to complete each of the twelve maps (which come in two different versions: normal and extreme) a whopping 16 times - 4 times with each of the four character, twice in the challenges (normal and extreme) and twice in the campaigns (normal, extreme).DLC - The story DLC 'Harley Quinn's Revenge' adds little to the story of the main game. It's nice to have but also not a must play. The character DLCs, with the exception of the Catwoman-DLC, are okay since they only affect the challenge mode. You basically have to play the same challenges again and again (see the passage above). The Catwoman DLC gives a different beginning of the game and you play her four times throughout the main story. In my opinion, she is also the most fun during combat, because she is even a more fluid fighter than batman.How long to beat - The game takes around 15 hours to finish, if you do the story and a couple of side quests and collectibles/riddles on the way. If you just play the main story, the credits would roll after approx. 7-8 hours.Getting all achievements took me 72 hours. You might be faster or slower depending on your skill.Rating - 4,5/5Buy it! It's fantastic!

content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												This is a ridiculously good game I found even if you're not really into Batman very much I still recomend it to you because I wasn't either but it was on sale and hell, now it's definitely awesome!I definitely prefer it on steam opposed to windows live because WINDOWS LIVE accounts are insanely hard to setup while I got my STEAM set up within an hour and without millions of google searches.Storyline:Without giving away any spoilers I will say that you will encounter plenty of the good old baddies such as the joker and harley etc. etc. The storyline is also amazing and will keep you captivated throughout the whole game.It took me a while to complete it but if you're unlike me and you prefer to play as long as you can on games than you are likely to complete the main story within a week.Characters:BATMAN:All in all Batman is just a complete bad♥♥♥♥♥in no matter what he's doing he will always find a way to pound a couple skulls together along the way.He also has the largest arsenary of gadgets of all the playable characters in the game.Take note that most gadgets have a quickfire control usable by simple double tapping the gadgets respective number on the numberpad.eg. by double tapping Batarang (1) it quickly releases Batarang(s) depending on how many times you double tap) out to stun and disorientate your foes.Batman also lets out the occasional one-liner and likes to discreetly do a bit of smack-talking before knocking some heads together.So definitely, Batman is a complete badass.CATWOMAN:Catwoman is just as much a badass as Batman because of her always finding a way to mimick a kiss before a knee to the gonads pounds a thug into incapacitation.Like all other characters bar Batman, she has a small arsenal of gadgets but each is effective in combat.Very good with the girly wisecracks, always willing to add something about chipping a nail or something like that.ROBIN:Very awesome character, seemingly more of a ninja because of his bo-staff and ninja themed gadgets.His bullet shield, I found, is extremly usefull in combat because of its ability to block bullets and power bash.For said reason, I reckon Batman should use this one.I won't include very much about NIGHTWING because I haven't used him very much so far.All I know is that he was the original Robin until he grew up and decided to fly it solo.only BATMAN and CATWOMAN are playable throughout the main storyline.That concludes my review of Batman: Arkham City - Game of the Year Edition.Hope You Enjoyed-Smiley_HD

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												For some reason, I never liked Batman. BUT That all changed when I played This Game:Batman:Arkham City.I decided to look at some gameplay before I bought it. It tick all the boxes for my favourite genresOpen World (go anywhere)(I’m)BatmanA lot of gadgetsKevin ConroyMark Hamill3rd PersonAnd I was allowed to play it becauseIt was within my classification range (M)I had enough MoneyI had the platform I was getting it for(PC)When I got Home I did what anyone would do…Put it in the Disc Drive of the laptop and Install it. After what seemed like 3 Hours (15 minutes) It had finished installing and, So I booted it up. It asked me to make an account for…The Dreaded…..GFWL(Games For Windows Live). I couldn’t make an account because of some stupid reason. so I panicked for 10 minutes THEN I had a brilliant idea to fix it...Look it up on youtube. I found that way to get around the no saving problem. I finally got to play and immediately I fell in love with the graphics and gameplay. The Gameplay:3rd personOpen WorldBatmanEPIC GADGETSStealthy or Fighting Detective Case filesKey Features:Made By a talented teamPerfect Voice ActingIn-Depth storyMany Easter Eggs (secrets)Engaging gameplayAfter I got up to a certain point in said game my disc stopped working and I was HALF WAY THROUGH. But by that time my game save had been deleted several times making me start again.½ a year later:I finally got another Copy of a really good site called {STEAM} and it was 75% off so i got the GOTY(Game Of The Year) Edition and I was happy again. BUT I had to start again. My playtime on steam is around 130 hours!! because of the open world there are many sidequests and thing to collect and secrets to find.The Review:Batman: Arkham City is a very engaging Batman styled “stealth-beat em up” with an amazing story. Although They tried to pack all the villains they could think of to add in to make it like the mad hatters tea party i still like it.It is not perfect but it is still pretty amazing.I really love how you get the feeling of actually being batman (without the raspy voice) Kevin(Batman) and Mark(The Joker) do an amazing job and so do all the other Voice actors.The thing I really took away from this is: You DON’T have to be Batman to be Batman. 9/10My favorite moments: The best boss fight in the game is Mr. Freeze which was very well thought out making you think and making you use all your skills.The Combat is what you’d expect very well flushed out mechanics and amazing Free Flow(jumping from thug to thug).Gadgets were well implemented too.Open world makes any game last longer to make you just want to fly around or grapple and punch randomly generated thugs.The Bugs and Glitches are just plain funny, once i saw a thug spinning rapidly and i walked right through him.The cutscenes are acted out using motion capture making them look extremely realistic.Animations of batman are always either crouching walking or leaping.There are amazing animations like when the thugs see you coming they might cower in a corner.The BAD: Not having a powerful computer affects cut scenes making the voices look desynced.Cramming in all the villains possible makes it look messy.Joker’s sadistic nature make it appropriate for people above the age of 11.After you complete EVERYTHING there is no reason to come back.Story is quite short: 9-10 hours for beginners.Can’t QuickFire Gadgets while flyingNo BatmobileWorld is quite smallBig Hard Drive Space (17 Gigabytes)Final thoughts:In conclusion you should play this game if you like batman or fun games in general.it only costs around $7.50 on sale and it will keep you coming back for ages.I am extremely excited about Batman: Arkham Knight coming out early next year (2015) because it has fixed most of the problems that I had with this near perfect game: Possibly a much longer story, you CAN QuickFire gadgets while flying , they added the batmobile and also the open world of Gotham is 5 times larger than this!Quiz: What was the first episode of the 1960s batman TV show called? ANSWER: Hi-Diddle Riddle. It featured Frank Gorshin as the Riddler and Adam West as Batman. It aired on the 12th of January 1966.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Take Arkham Asylum, add more of everything, improve the combat system and you have Arkham City.The Combat - Compared to Arkham Asylum the combat has greatly improved as it's playing much more fluid now. The slow motion effect from the predecessor has been reduced, which makes it easier - at least for me - to time my hits and counters.The Story - I'm neither a comic book expert nor a Batman expert so I don't know how Arkham City's story compares to other Batman stories. Nevertheless the story seems fairly standard to me. Save the world - or in this case Arkham City - from destruction. There is a second story arc involving the Joker which is the more interesting one, in my opinion.The voice acting is superb. Especially Mark Hamill as the Joker is incredible.The Sidequests - Arkham Asylum had two side quests which only involved collecting stuff and solving riddles. Arkham City has about a dozen side quests and most of them feature other known characters from the Batman universe, the Mad Hatter, Zsasz etc. Although they bring a nice variety to the game, they don't always fit into the pace of the main story, e.g. the main story gives the impression that time is running out and Batman should move quickly to his next location, yet you're able to do the side quests. It's not like that you have some world-saving to do or anything... But this problem appears to happen in a lot of open world games and I might be the only one who is a bit annoyed by that. To sum ist up: the side quests are fun, but I would recommend doing most of them after you finished the story, so they fit into the canon.The Collectibles - While a chore in most games, Arkham City makes it actually fun to collect them. The high number of 440 collectibles/riddles might be a bit overwhelming in the beginning, but compared to other games (*cough* Assassin's Creed *cough*) they serve a purpose because they are necessary for finishing the Riddler side quest.Post-game - What to do after you finished the story? Hunting for achievements of course. The challenges from Arkham Asylum made it back into the game. You can either do combat challenges and fight in four rounds against a batch of enemies improving your highscores or you can do the predator challanges where you have to silently take out a group of enemies.New in this game are the campaigns which are pretty much the same as the challenge maps, except that one campaign consists of three challenge maps and a bunch of positive and negative modifiers which you have to apply to each map.If you're going for all 64 achievements you have to complete each of the twelve maps (which come in two different versions: normal and extreme) a whopping 16 times - 4 times with each of the four character, twice in the challenges (normal and extreme) and twice in the campaigns (normal, extreme).DLC - The story DLC 'Harley Quinn's Revenge' adds little to the story of the main game. It's nice to have but also not a must play. The character DLCs, with the exception of the Catwoman-DLC, are okay since they only affect the challenge mode. You basically have to play the same challenges again and again (see the passage above). The Catwoman DLC gives a different beginning of the game and you play her four times throughout the main story. In my opinion, she is also the most fun during combat, because she is even a more fluid fighter than batman.How long to beat - The game takes around 15 hours to finish, if you do the story and a couple of side quests and collectibles/riddles on the way. If you just play the main story, the credits would roll after approx. 7-8 hours.Getting all achievements took me 72 hours. You might be faster or slower depending on your skill.Rating - 4,5/5Buy it! It's fantastic!

content:
Posted: November 1, 2013
												In the days of yore, the Comics Code prohibited comics to depict the negative sides of life. Based on Arkham City, removing the Code may have been a bad call for playing this resembled a superhero daydream on a sugar rush. Absolutely no real world logics or limitations apply here making this the finest escapist spectacle in recent memory.Batman finds himself in Arkham City, a large portion of Gotham isolated from outside world to house supercriminals and their organizations. Detailing the story and the absurdities within would require several pages (if not books). Suffice to say that this is one of those games powered by Why Not? logics. Why are everyone but Batman so helpless and why do all the women look and dress like Playboy Bunnies when it is winter and there are lonely inmates in every direction? Why does Batman cooperate with a supercriminal, then have a boss fight with him and then cooperate with him again? How can anyone do all this in one night and completely ignore gravity in his moves? The game answers all this and much more with a resounding Why Not? followed by a Wait, There's More!That is not to say that playing it was not entertaining, quite the opposite. Arkham is absolutely filled with fun superhero things to do. The game throws side quests, activities, challenges and rewards at the player so rapidly it all blurs on by. Completing everything is quite tempting for playing is so smooth and responsive as to approach perfection. The close combat system is still the best yet seen and requires far more than mere button mashing. The predator rooms, which task you with taking out gun-wielding thugs, give you a variety of possibilities and the freedom to test them as you see fit. The gadget arsenal features no duds and moving around Arkham is sheer pleasure as well. You also get some playtime as Catwoman and playing as her contains just the right amount of variety.Visuals and sounds are just as good as in Asylum, if not better, with the gorgeously melodramatic soundtrack giving an extra boost. I had some technical issues with certain pieces of music disappearing halfway through the game. Since AC uses the console system of autosaves only and in one slot, this was a pain. Games For Windows Live has finally been removed, however, and I had no other bugs.Comparing this with Arkham Asylum makes quite clear why Origins failed to recapture the magic or move the franchise forward. Arkham had nowhere to go from here. Asylum was clear, compact and suspenseful while City is completely blown out of proportions but instead of collapsing from absurdity, it is strengthened by embracing the superhero lifestyle. Arkham City is weightless, highly polished entertainment that is absolutely recommended for anyone looking to soar above everyday concerns as Batman.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												Batman: Arkham City is a highly recommended game if you’re into an open world action-adventure game. You get the chance to play Batman and Catwoman in Arkham City; a prison fortress controlled by Hugo Strange. Besides Hugo Strange, you’ll run into other Batman’s foes however I won’t give list the names since it will spoil the story.Playing Batman is fantastic. You got access to Batman’s gadgets that will help him in any errand he’s in and let’s not forget his cape. The game takes place in an abandoned city so you’ll get the chance to glide with minimum sound and attack the thugs by stealth. There are a lot of stealth methods to be applied so it’s about planning attacks. Sometimes I improvised to make it more authentic and that was such a cool experience! This game is the sequel to Batman - Arkham Asylum so I suggest trying that game as well.Peace.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Well I waited too long to play this one for sure! A great sequel to the fantastic first game, Arkham City presents a larger game world, more incredible characters from the Batman lore, a lot of new gadgets and combos/moves, nice graphics, top notch musical score, all this made precious by one of the best control interfaces and combat mechanics ever designed for a third person action game (please buy a gamepad if you don't have one!). The GOTY edition let's you play also as Catwoman, Robin and Nightwing, a nice short DLC campaign is included and there's also a big bunch of arenas where you can test your combat and stealth skills while trying to rank up more points as possible (and that is addictive I can assure you). Maybe the campaign story is a bit weaker than its prequel's and game fundamentals are basically the same all other from the previous title, but Rocksteady has expanded and optimized every positive aspect of the first game, so I think this is indeed the best super hero game on the market, and one of the best action games / beat 'em ups ever created.Let's see if they will be able to do better and maybe innovate their franchise with the third and final game of this planned trilogy, Arkham Knight is coming in 2015!

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												For some reason, I never liked Batman. BUT That all changed when I played This Game:Batman:Arkham City.I decided to look at some gameplay before I bought it. It tick all the boxes for my favourite genresOpen World (go anywhere)(I’m)BatmanA lot of gadgetsKevin ConroyMark Hamill3rd PersonAnd I was allowed to play it becauseIt was within my classification range (M)I had enough MoneyI had the platform I was getting it for(PC)When I got Home I did what anyone would do…Put it in the Disc Drive of the laptop and Install it. After what seemed like 3 Hours (15 minutes) It had finished installing and, So I booted it up. It asked me to make an account for…The Dreaded…..GFWL(Games For Windows Live). I couldn’t make an account because of some stupid reason. so I panicked for 10 minutes THEN I had a brilliant idea to fix it...Look it up on youtube. I found that way to get around the no saving problem. I finally got to play and immediately I fell in love with the graphics and gameplay. The Gameplay:3rd personOpen WorldBatmanEPIC GADGETSStealthy or Fighting Detective Case filesKey Features:Made By a talented teamPerfect Voice ActingIn-Depth storyMany Easter Eggs (secrets)Engaging gameplayAfter I got up to a certain point in said game my disc stopped working and I was HALF WAY THROUGH. But by that time my game save had been deleted several times making me start again.½ a year later:I finally got another Copy of a really good site called {STEAM} and it was 75% off so i got the GOTY(Game Of The Year) Edition and I was happy again. BUT I had to start again. My playtime on steam is around 130 hours!! because of the open world there are many sidequests and thing to collect and secrets to find.The Review:Batman: Arkham City is a very engaging Batman styled “stealth-beat em up” with an amazing story. Although They tried to pack all the villains they could think of to add in to make it like the mad hatters tea party i still like it.It is not perfect but it is still pretty amazing.I really love how you get the feeling of actually being batman (without the raspy voice) Kevin(Batman) and Mark(The Joker) do an amazing job and so do all the other Voice actors.The thing I really took away from this is: You DON’T have to be Batman to be Batman. 9/10My favorite moments: The best boss fight in the game is Mr. Freeze which was very well thought out making you think and making you use all your skills.The Combat is what you’d expect very well flushed out mechanics and amazing Free Flow(jumping from thug to thug).Gadgets were well implemented too.Open world makes any game last longer to make you just want to fly around or grapple and punch randomly generated thugs.The Bugs and Glitches are just plain funny, once i saw a thug spinning rapidly and i walked right through him.The cutscenes are acted out using motion capture making them look extremely realistic.Animations of batman are always either crouching walking or leaping.There are amazing animations like when the thugs see you coming they might cower in a corner.The BAD: Not having a powerful computer affects cut scenes making the voices look desynced.Cramming in all the villains possible makes it look messy.Joker’s sadistic nature make it appropriate for people above the age of 11.After you complete EVERYTHING there is no reason to come back.Story is quite short: 9-10 hours for beginners.Can’t QuickFire Gadgets while flyingNo BatmobileWorld is quite smallBig Hard Drive Space (17 Gigabytes)Final thoughts:In conclusion you should play this game if you like batman or fun games in general.it only costs around $7.50 on sale and it will keep you coming back for ages.I am extremely excited about Batman: Arkham Knight coming out early next year (2015) because it has fixed most of the problems that I had with this near perfect game: Possibly a much longer story, you CAN QuickFire gadgets while flying , they added the batmobile and also the open world of Gotham is 5 times larger than this!Quiz: What was the first episode of the 1960s batman TV show called? ANSWER: Hi-Diddle Riddle. It featured Frank Gorshin as the Riddler and Adam West as Batman. It aired on the 12th of January 1966.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												This is a ridiculously good game I found even if you're not really into Batman very much I still recomend it to you because I wasn't either but it was on sale and hell, now it's definitely awesome!I definitely prefer it on steam opposed to windows live because WINDOWS LIVE accounts are insanely hard to setup while I got my STEAM set up within an hour and without millions of google searches.Storyline:Without giving away any spoilers I will say that you will encounter plenty of the good old baddies such as the joker and harley etc. etc. The storyline is also amazing and will keep you captivated throughout the whole game.It took me a while to complete it but if you're unlike me and you prefer to play as long as you can on games than you are likely to complete the main story within a week.Characters:BATMAN:All in all Batman is just a complete bad♥♥♥♥♥in no matter what he's doing he will always find a way to pound a couple skulls together along the way.He also has the largest arsenary of gadgets of all the playable characters in the game.Take note that most gadgets have a quickfire control usable by simple double tapping the gadgets respective number on the numberpad.eg. by double tapping Batarang (1) it quickly releases Batarang(s) depending on how many times you double tap) out to stun and disorientate your foes.Batman also lets out the occasional one-liner and likes to discreetly do a bit of smack-talking before knocking some heads together.So definitely, Batman is a complete badass.CATWOMAN:Catwoman is just as much a badass as Batman because of her always finding a way to mimick a kiss before a knee to the gonads pounds a thug into incapacitation.Like all other characters bar Batman, she has a small arsenal of gadgets but each is effective in combat.Very good with the girly wisecracks, always willing to add something about chipping a nail or something like that.ROBIN:Very awesome character, seemingly more of a ninja because of his bo-staff and ninja themed gadgets.His bullet shield, I found, is extremly usefull in combat because of its ability to block bullets and power bash.For said reason, I reckon Batman should use this one.I won't include very much about NIGHTWING because I haven't used him very much so far.All I know is that he was the original Robin until he grew up and decided to fly it solo.only BATMAN and CATWOMAN are playable throughout the main storyline.That concludes my review of Batman: Arkham City - Game of the Year Edition.Hope You Enjoyed-Smiley_HD

content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
												Arkham city is one of the best game in the Batman Arkham series, packing action and a great storyline with a satisfying length and good replayability.The game re-uses the good old Arkham Asylum mechanics (which is the same across all the Arkham games) and expands the explorable area to the whole of Arkham city, a prison city that Bruce Wayne is trying to shut down through the political game. But Dr. Hugo Strange has other plans for Mr. Wayne, namely throwing him into Arkham City with shackles to tie loose ends. Once inside Arkham, Bruce Wayne finds his way to an airdrop with a batsuit sent by Alfred, his butler. He then takes matters into his own hands and clears the city himself.The gameplay is honestly flawless, as per usual in this game series. Couple that with a nice lengthy storyline (14-16h) that builds upon the Batman universe and characters, such as Catwoman, Mr. Freeze, Bane, The Joker, and many more classic vilains. I would highly recommend any Batman: Arkham X games, even if you're not a fan of Batman at all. The story is good and easy to get into, the gameplay is noob friendly on low difficulties, and it's overall a very enjoyable experience.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2016
												22-Nov-2016 : Finished main story + extrasSetup : Windows 10 64-Bit, MSI GT80-2QE Notebook, Logitech F710 GamepadREVIEW :Great voice acting, great graphics (4-year old technology still holding up), great soundtrack, mediocre story and characters, and mediocre gameplay. Too many collectibles to be found and unfortunately you can't just leave them because some of the side-quest are related to them. The control design also not so fluid as I expected to be. Several times I missed a jump or a counter-attack because of this. I love the detective side-quests and the riddles. And to get the collectibles, you also need to solve a kind of mini-puzzle. But again, the collectibles are just too much and tedious. Overall, it still a great game, especially compared to other comic-based superhero games which normally have bad quality, but it's not as memorable as Arkham Asylum. CONCLUSION :Recommended on full price, a must-have on sale price.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												Batman : Arkham City is a very good open-world action title with a heavy emphasis on exploration. With interesting boss fights (a nice upgrade from the first game), a very slick and balanced gameplay that manages to balance stealthy segments with more action-packed ones, and great visual identity, Arkham City establishes itself as a solid AAA title that follows in the footsteps of its predecessor for great results.  The game is filled to the brim with content ; while the main story can be beaten in about 15 hours, the many sidequests and collectibles will grab dedicated players' attention. Also worth noting are the numerous iconic characters from the Batman lore that make an appearance, whether during the main storyline or during sidequests. This will most certainly satisfy hardcore fans of the franchise, while being a great way to introduce newcomers, as each appearing character is given a biography that the player can read at any time.The elements that disappointed me were the simplistic combat system (not really improved since the previous title), the upgrades that sometimes felt like they were only useful for one specific situation ; and the story, while more developed than in the previous title, did not quite make up for the slightly underwhelming and subdued overall atmosphere that clashed with the oppressive, almost intoxicating setting of Arkham Asylum. All in all, Batman Arkham City is really enjoyable, and although it is not revolutionary by any means, I recommend it wholeheartedly to anyone with as much as a passing interest in the Batman universe.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												Batman: Arkham City is a spectacle fighting/partial stealth game featuring (you guessed it) the Batman. Plot:Batman is captured by Hugo Strange and sent into Arkham City, the super prison built in part of Gotham. Batman soon learns of "Protocol 10", which Strange says will make him famous. Batman begins his quest to stop Hugo Strange and his Protocol 10 to save Gotham city. Notable villains include:-Hugo Strange-Two-Face-Penguin-Mr. Freeze-Ra's al-Ghul-Joker All of the characters are very well done with phenomenal voice acting. Most notably are Batman voiced by Kevin Conroy and Joker voiced by Mark Hamill (HEEEEEEHEHEEhehehee AHAAAAAAAAAHHHHAAAAhooo HA HEHEEE heee heee)Gameplay:You will spend the majority of the game as the Dark Knight himself, and there's a reason he is "The most dangerous man in the world", as Superman once said. The gameplay can be split into four basic categories:Batman is a master of all forms of martial arts, and it shows. The combat is focused on a free-flow brawl which utilizes combos after 8 uninterrupted moves and is very responsive and satisfying. The right click to counter system works very well and is very enjoyable to play.He is the Dark Knight for a reason after all. Not all thugs are simply using their fists to try and beat you to death, some have found that bullets are far more effective. Now begins the stealth portions of the game, which are just as fun as the brawling. Stealth focuses around Takedowns. Takedowns can be silent, loud, terrifying, and much more. The thugs in the room have a very realistic reaction to things. I love (perhaps a bit too much) terrorizing thugs as I zip around, breaking more than a few of their bones.Arkham City is a big place, and the sidewalk just ain't gonna cut it. Batman uses the Batclaw (his grapple gun) to zip around Arkham City in a very enjoyable manner. He can also use his cape to glide around like the bat he is. Parkour in the game is also very well done: not very complicated, but very effective.And of course, what would Batman be without his toolbelt? At your disposal are all sorts of gadgets available to the Bat at any time. These gadgets range from the Batclaw, smoke pellets, explosive gel, and the classic Batarang. His gadgets are all unique in their own way, each with their own puprose and all very useful.Graphics: The game has great graphics and the in game cutscenes transition very well to actual gameplay. I don't have much else to say, I'm not a graphics guy.Overall, I highly recommend this game. When I got it I didn't expect to play it that much. I don't like fighting games all too much. After 5 hours (straight) of "I'M BATMAN" I changed my mind. Also:I'M BATMAN

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												This game is truly something special.  Though I was a comic book fan in younger days, I always favored Marvel over DC, and I was a particular fan of Spider-Man.  Also, when it comes to video games, my preference skews toward complexity.  Selling me on a basic beat 'em up starring Batman would not be easy.  However, I was intrigued by a proliferation of glowing reviews, so I took the plunge when it became available at a heavily discounted price.Sometimes Steam feels like gambling -- you put your money on the table, and either you get loads of smiles or you walk away feeling cheated.  Almost anyone who thinks they might enjoy this game will get loads of smiles from it.  Combat resembles a simple rhythm game, but it becomes much more complex for players who care to learn and exploit some of the many special maneuvers available through the progression system.  Also, the gritty dark tone is probably my favorite variety of Batman -- heavy on the Dark Knight vibe with pitch perfect comic relief sparingly applied.Though it feels like a console game, and I imagine it could be a little awkward without a gamepad or Xbox controller, it delivered the best of both worlds for me.  Beautiful graphics were silky smooth for me at 1920x1080, and I did not experience troublesome technical hiccups that could really mess with the fun of combat so sensitive to timing.  It is also, just a little bit, a genuine open world game in the tradition of GTA or Skyrim.  The "world" is confined to a few neighborhoods in a walled off section of a big city, but the various villains and their henchmen make some territories much different from others.  Perhaps the best way to convey the scope is by pointing out that vehicles are not missed.  Skillful use of grapnel and cape make it possible to swing and glide quickly across large areas.The game abounds with side quests and collectibles -- these things aren't essential, but they can provide supplemental XP, and some players will really appreciate that sort of feature along with achievements and cosmetic unlocks involved.  Also, some of the side quests are well thought out stories unto themselves.  The excellent main storyline is not confined to Batman alone.  The narratives of other characters must be advanced by completing missions with those characters during substantial breaks in Batman's adventures.  However, when the story does put Batman toe to toe against a major villain, you can expect a properly elaborate boss fight.By now there are a couple of newer choices in this product line, but I get the vibe that Arkham City remains a sentimental favorite among critics.  I've acquired a few AAA comic book action hero games over the past year, and none of them can hold a candle to this purchase.  I join the consensus holding that it was a masterpiece at the time it was released, and I believe it is an excellent bargain at the prices we're now seeing 2-3 years after that release.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												How have I not reviewed this yet?  Arkham City is the sequel to Arkham Asylum, which was an excellent game itself.  I said a lot of great things about that game, and Arkham City improves on pretty much everything.First, the combat.  The combat in Arkham Asylum was okay, but had some awkwardness.  This game is a little more forgiving and far more fluid when fighting, you'll notice the difference immediately if you've played the original game.  This along with a whole lot of new moves and better combos means fighting is more fun and interesting, and feels less stiff.  While Arkham Asylum took place on an island divided into three areas that loaded separately and were connected by passages, Arkham City takes a different approach to make it feel more like an open world.  The entire exterior map acts as one large area, and you can move freely across it, even though overall it is larger than the entire map of Arkham Asylum.  Interior areas still load separately, but the outside has eliminated loading screens and connector areas entirely.  It makes moving through Arkham City seamless.  Even better, with the improved controls, it is now possible to travel through the entire game world using glide without ever touching the ground.  It's amazing thing to see.  The glide system was overhauled, allowing new actions during gliding, such as diving, giving Batman near-flight powers.  The grapnel gun was also upgraded, with a boost mechanism that instead of pulling you to a location allows you to gain momentum and shoot out into the sky.  The grapnel gun can easily be used in mid-glide, now.  This makes travelling around the city both exciting and easy, instead of tedious.  Another nice touch is the addition of another character.  In the storyline (Game of the Year Edition), the plot alternates between Batman and Catwoman, both are playable.  Catwoman's moves are completely different from Batman's, which makes a nice change.  Unfortunately, for most of the game the switching is mandatory, meaning you have to finish a Catwoman segment to continue as Batman, and the transitions between the characters are cliffhangers.  Eventually, you will get the option to switch back and forth between them.  The story is excellent, and plays into the foreshadowing in Arkham Asylum.  The Warden, Quincy Sharpe, is now the mayor of Gotham, and following Joker's takeover of Arkham, ordered both the Asylum and Blackgate shut down, and a rundown section of Gotham was designated a maximum security prison, the new Arkham City.  This setting means most of Batman's regular foes can all be running loose in one crime-infested area, with no one to stop them, which gives villains like Penguin and Two-Face a lot of time to shine after being left out of the previous game.  Joker and Harley Quinn remain the biggest threat to Batman, but something strange is going on with Joker.  Few people have actually seen him, and rumor is that he is very ill after the Arkham Asylum incident.  But Joker is not the only mastermind in Arkham City, not in the least.The ending is stunning.  I was shocked.  I won't spoil it.  All I will say is I won't hear the song "Only You" the same ever again.I know I used a lot of words, but I didn't come close to talking about everything good about this game.  It really is great.  Definitely recommended.

Posted: October 18, 2014
												Batman: Arkham City is overwhelmingly great and atmospheric, everything in this game is great, more than great. The graphics, the sound effects and especially the music, the gameplay, and the storyline. Arkham City is one of the best games ever.  For me the thing that made Arkham City beautiful the most is its storyline and combat system.  The story has dozens of surprises, easter eggs for example, dozens of them that has connections with the main story, the sidequests and collectibles (riddler trophies unlockables like interview tapes) supports the main story giving the player background and an idea about key characters in the game. The game has a complete feeling when you finish it, the story isn't vague, not confusing, has few flaws, the storyline is nearly perfect. Plus the history of Arkham Asylum gives the game more background.BTW, I played the game for more than 80 hours, Steam didn't record my playtime when I'm offline.Still, Poison Ivy and Catwoman are so hot.9.8 + .2 for Catwoman's sexy a$$.10/10 would like to see Poison Ivy's vines all around Catwoman again

Almost anyone who thinks they might enjoy this game will get loads of smiles from it.  Combat resembles a simple rhythm game, but it becomes much more complex for players who care to learn and exploit some of the many special maneuvers available through the progression system.  Also, the gritty dark tone is probably my favorite variety of Batman -- heavy on the Dark Knight vibe with pitch perfect comic relief sparingly applied.Though it feels like a console game, and I imagine it could be a little awkward without a gamepad or Xbox controller, it delivered the best of both worlds for me.  Beautiful graphics were silky smooth for me at 1920x1080, and I did not experience troublesome technical hiccups that could really mess with the fun of combat so sensitive to timing.  It is also, just a little bit, a genuine open world game in the tradition of GTA or Skyrim.  The "world" is confined to a few neighborhoods in a walled off section of a big city, but the various villains and their henchmen make some territories much different from others.  Perhaps the best way to convey the scope is by pointing out that vehicles are not missed.  Skillful use of grapnel and cape make it possible to swing and glide quickly across large areas.The game abounds with side quests and collectibles -- these things aren't essential, but they can provide supplemental XP, and some players will really appreciate that sort of feature along with achievements and cosmetic unlocks involved.  Also, some of the side quests are well thought out stories unto themselves.  The excellent main storyline is not confined to Batman alone.  The narratives of other characters must be advanced by completing missions with those characters during substantial breaks in Batman's adventures.  However, when the story does put Batman toe to toe against a major villain, you can expect a properly elaborate boss fight.By now there are a couple of newer choices in this product line, but I get the vibe that Arkham City remains a sentimental favorite among critics.  I've acquired a few AAA comic book action hero games over the past year, and none of them can hold a candle to this purchase.  I join the consensus holding that it was a masterpiece at the time it was released, and I believe it is an excellent bargain at the prices we're now seeing 2-3 years after that release.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												Batman: Arkham City is a spectacle fighting/partial stealth game featuring (you guessed it) the Batman. Plot:Batman is captured by Hugo Strange and sent into Arkham City, the super prison built in part of Gotham. Batman soon learns of "Protocol 10", which Strange says will make him famous. Batman begins his quest to stop Hugo Strange and his Protocol 10 to save Gotham city. Notable villains include:-Hugo Strange-Two-Face-Penguin-Mr. Freeze-Ra's al-Ghul-Joker All of the characters are very well done with phenomenal voice acting. Most notably are Batman voiced by Kevin Conroy and Joker voiced by Mark Hamill (HEEEEEEHEHEEhehehee AHAAAAAAAAAHHHHAAAAhooo HA HEHEEE heee heee)Gameplay:You will spend the majority of the game as the Dark Knight himself, and there's a reason he is "The most dangerous man in the world", as Superman once said. The gameplay can be split into four basic categories:Batman is a master of all forms of martial arts, and it shows. The combat is focused on a free-flow brawl which utilizes combos after 8 uninterrupted moves and is very responsive and satisfying. The right click to counter system works very well and is very enjoyable to play.He is the Dark Knight for a reason after all. Not all thugs are simply using their fists to try and beat you to death, some have found that bullets are far more effective. Now begins the stealth portions of the game, which are just as fun as the brawling. Stealth focuses around Takedowns. Takedowns can be silent, loud, terrifying, and much more. The thugs in the room have a very realistic reaction to things. I love (perhaps a bit too much) terrorizing thugs as I zip around, breaking more than a few of their bones.Arkham City is a big place, and the sidewalk just ain't gonna cut it. Batman uses the Batclaw (his grapple gun) to zip around Arkham City in a very enjoyable manner. He can also use his cape to glide around like the bat he is. Parkour in the game is also very well done: not very complicated, but very effective.And of course, what would Batman be without his toolbelt? At your disposal are all sorts of gadgets available to the Bat at any time. These gadgets range from the Batclaw, smoke pellets, explosive gel, and the classic Batarang. His gadgets are all unique in their own way, each with their own puprose and all very useful.Graphics: The game has great graphics and the in game cutscenes transition very well to actual gameplay. I don't have much else to say, I'm not a graphics guy.Overall, I highly recommend this game. When I got it I didn't expect to play it that much. I don't like fighting games all too much. After 5 hours (straight) of "I'M BATMAN" I changed my mind. Also:I'M BATMAN

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												How have I not reviewed this yet?  Arkham City is the sequel to Arkham Asylum, which was an excellent game itself.  I said a lot of great things about that game, and Arkham City improves on pretty much everything.First, the combat.  The combat in Arkham Asylum was okay, but had some awkwardness.  This game is a little more forgiving and far more fluid when fighting, you'll notice the difference immediately if you've played the original game.  This along with a whole lot of new moves and better combos means fighting is more fun and interesting, and feels less stiff.  While Arkham Asylum took place on an island divided into three areas that loaded separately and were connected by passages, Arkham City takes a different approach to make it feel more like an open world.  The entire exterior map acts as one large area, and you can move freely across it, even though overall it is larger than the entire map of Arkham Asylum.  Interior areas still load separately, but the outside has eliminated loading screens and connector areas entirely.  It makes moving through Arkham City seamless.  Even better, with the improved controls, it is now possible to travel through the entire game world using glide without ever touching the ground.  It's amazing thing to see.  The glide system was overhauled, allowing new actions during gliding, such as diving, giving Batman near-flight powers.  The grapnel gun was also upgraded, with a boost mechanism that instead of pulling you to a location allows you to gain momentum and shoot out into the sky.  The grapnel gun can easily be used in mid-glide, now.  This makes travelling around the city both exciting and easy, instead of tedious.  Another nice touch is the addition of another character.  In the storyline (Game of the Year Edition), the plot alternates between Batman and Catwoman, both are playable.  Catwoman's moves are completely different from Batman's, which makes a nice change.  Unfortunately, for most of the game the switching is mandatory, meaning you have to finish a Catwoman segment to continue as Batman, and the transitions between the characters are cliffhangers.  Eventually, you will get the option to switch back and forth between them.  The story is excellent, and plays into the foreshadowing in Arkham Asylum.  The Warden, Quincy Sharpe, is now the mayor of Gotham, and following Joker's takeover of Arkham, ordered both the Asylum and Blackgate shut down, and a rundown section of Gotham was designated a maximum security prison, the new Arkham City.  This setting means most of Batman's regular foes can all be running loose in one crime-infested area, with no one to stop them, which gives villains like Penguin and Two-Face a lot of time to shine after being left out of the previous game.  Joker and Harley Quinn remain the biggest threat to Batman, but something strange is going on with Joker.  Few people have actually seen him, and rumor is that he is very ill after the Arkham Asylum incident.  But Joker is not the only mastermind in Arkham City, not in the least.The ending is stunning.  I was shocked.  I won't spoil it.  All I will say is I won't hear the song "Only You" the same ever again.I know I used a lot of words, but I didn't come close to talking about everything good about this game.  It really is great.  Definitely recommended.
