After a quick introduction to being mentally ill, dying your hair in a way that makes you look like a surprised carrot, and finally getting your AR15, which as well all have been taught is essential to daily survival next to shelter, clothing, and food, you will encounter the enemies of the first level. Do not be fooled! These stone cold monsters are portrayed as harmless cinema enthusiasts. Beware ... pure evil sleeps within their deceptive popcorn buckets and soft drink bottles. The hope for salvation of the whole world lies in your hands, and your hands only. Your finger, the trigger, the blood rage - the essential holy trinity of this mission.Young hero, be prepared to show no mercy to these traitors. You must succeed.Oh, wait ..

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2013
												I absolutely loved Batman: Arkham Asylum. It was a spectacular look into the asylum itself, a location that stole the show, transformed and twisted by the inmates over the course of the game and providing ample room to explore. The plot wasn't groundbreaking, but it was great, and the spectacular returns of Animated Series cast members were accompanied by other great performances across the board. Most importantly, it gave the player an experience no other game could attest to: The feeling of becoming The Bat, learning his methods and feeling the tension he never expresses. When I heard about Arkham City, I doubted that a sequel could do it justice.Those doubts have been blasted out of the frikkin' water.The mere concept of Arkham City as a location cleverly serves several purposes: The reasons you'll uncover over the course of the game, a chance to explore much of Gotham City while staying in criminal territory, a way to bring together enemies both criminally insane and just downright criminal, and a warning that this is all-new, untrodden territory. Sure, there are a ton of thematic illusions to classic Batman works, as in Asylum, but while Asylum stuck to a composite of other works, City creates a new blend of characters all its own, and does quite well in doing so. A lot of characters we write off nowadays as pathetic jokes are brought back up to the terrifying, vicious foes they're meant to be.The vocal talents on display here are fantastic once again, although I personally got a little annoyed at Nolan North voicing every other goon. (To be fair, he does an excellent job as Penguin. I just feel the lack of vocal variety for enemies stands out.) I was disappointed to hear that Arleen wasn't voicing Harley this time around, but Tara Strong takes the role and runs with it like it was hers from the start. Everyone on the cast slips into these roles quite naturally.Anyways! Combat is quite well evolved from Arkham Asylum, and just as thrilling as before. The "quickfire" options took me quite a while to actually figure out, though, and I only understood how to do the knife counters until after completing the story (and all side missions (besides the AR stuff but we'll get to that later)). Stealth segments didn't feel quite as interesting to me as before, but that might just be nostalgia goggles and a bit of repetitive choices on my part.The side missions are quite engaging and presented in a reasonably organic manner. I would go as far as to say that the only missions that legitimately suck and are never fun are the AR Training challenges. Finish the first four early on, get your Grapnel Boost upgrade, and don't even bother with the other ones. They are not worth the frustration.Boss battles were one thing that Arkham Asylum sucked at. They are noticably better here, with the exception of one that reminded me of a certain infuriating duo in the first game. Here, it's frustrating due to a particular environmental hazard that you WILL hit. Upgrade your health early.As far as the Game of the Year content goes, there's some new challenge maps, some costumes, and most importantly, extra characters. Unlike what you might expect, they all play very distinctly from one another, and Catwoman takes center stage a few times in the main plot in this version. Her role provides a refreshing change of pace every now and then.They heavily advertise the addition of a new story mode called "Harley Quinn's Revenge". That is not really the strong point of this version. It's more of a neat little extra for when you've finished pretty much everything else and would like to see a little more story. It's like an OVA: It's a nice extra to have if you really, really want more, but it doesn't fundamentally change much. I would've at least hoped for more focus on Robin in it, but nope. Back to The Bat in short order.In short, excellent detail, intriguing plot, fantastic gameplay, and a spectacular Batman experience all-round, with most issues arising in tacked-on extras that shouldn't hamper the core experience much for you.

												This is an insta classic game. 10/10!Arkham City is on of the best game's i played last 5 years.I could tell you millions of reasons why to own this game but i will for fast forward...a) The visuals are Freaking amazing, and the game is AMAZINGLY renderd without the need of a super computer to play it on max settings.b)Music and game sounds are so intence you will catch yourself squeezing your mouse in fights or chaces with a stupid smile in your face.c)Gameplay is perfect. You can roam around city gliding like a bat or you can kick 20 peaple's♥♥♥♥♥on the ground with 40x combos screaming out of pleasure. Everything works like a charm.d)Storyline is great without needing a previus game explanation for what is going on. Most of gamers knows the enemys anyway from comics, cartoons or movies.e)Replayability? Well, i finished the main storyline in about 9 hours. After that i did some missions which they where totally AWESOME feeling like i was still playing the main story. I 'll say 3-5 more hours there. Riddles could take you days to solve, adding more time. You can restart the game with all your upgrades in a harder mode and dont forget the GOTY edition with huge amount of extras and an extra story line with the amazing Harley Queen! :p I'd say 25-35 hours of pure gameplay and more of 50hours for the 100% achiv.The best game i played this year so far! BUY IT ALREADY!

Posted: August 6, 2016
												I have finished the main story and the dlc story of this game and enyoyed every part of it. The game has a really good fighting system and gives a challange to the player when there are a lot of enemys.The Story is ok and simple to understand.U have a open world with a few side-quests that put batman against some of his less known villians.Being batman does not feel like u are imortal yet u dont feel like u can die in 1 hit.The thing that makes this game really awsome for me atleast is that u can stealth a lot of missions and by doing them stealthy u get rewarded more.There is a progression system in the game which allows u to unlock a lot of gadets to help u on your journey.Now lets get to the bad stuff...The game is a bad console port, playing the game on low and the fps is still going down to ~20 while i can run lets say Battlefield 3 on high with 60fps. This game has also a lot of problems with crashing randomly when loading areas.So in short....+ good story+ good fighting system+ open world+ become Batman- FPS problems- Random crashing- GlitchesIf u do not mind googling some fixes this game is a must buy :)

Posted: November 12, 2013
												Batman: Arkham City (B:AC) is a sequel to Rocksteady Studios' original Batman: Arkham Asylum. Featuring many of the same components that made the first game a success, B:AC improves upon the open-world design which gives you free reign on initiating additional side-quests. Yet again, B:AC does not cease to satisfy fans of the Dark Knight given their clever use of the cast of villains and tying them to the grand plot. B:AC is an absolute must for fans and should not be passed up by any gamer.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												                                                          *****WALL OF TEXT WARNING*****The legendary Batman Arkham series continues with Batman: Arkham City.  I haven't played Arkham Asylum, so I can't make a comparison between two.  It wouldn't make sense to compare it to the other Batman game I played, Batman NES by Sunsoft.  The game takes place in Arkham City, a new super prison set up in walled off section of Gotham containing the area where Bruce Wayne's parents were gunned down by Joe Chill.  As Batman you fight to uncover the truth behind the walls of this new super prison.  You can also play at Catwoman during the campaign.  The game features challenge maps where you play as Batman in different skins, such as the Animated Series Batman and Batman Beyond.  You can also play a few different characters.  There is an add-on campaign called Harley Quinn's revenge where you reprise your role as Batman not that long after the events of the main campaign.  The "Free Flow" combat system carries on from the previous installment, which allows for more dynamic hand to hand combat or Bat vs Gun combat.  As you land consecutive hits the combo meter increases and the more hits you can land without getting hurt or taking too long to get another hit, the more experience points you get.  You use the experience points to level up your armor for both Batman and Catwoman.  You can also unlock extra gadgets, improve your gadgets, and you can improve your combat skills with special takedowns or moves.  There are other factors that goes into your XP gains.  There are bonuses for using different gadgets during combat, such as the Bat-a-rang, the Batclaw, etc.  There is also an "intimidation bonus" where taking out thugs through stealth and concealment.  Once you get down to the last thug standing or if you are only fighting one thug you are granted a slow-mo take down where you can look at the painful last hit thrown by Batman or Catwoman(the nutshots are painful to watch).  Honestly, the combat can get a little boring but the takedowns are satisfying.  You can counter enemy attacks with default RMB, if you see little blue lines above an enemies head they are about to try to hit you.  You block multiple enemy attacks by pressing the RMB the number of times there are people about to try to hit you.    The graphics are fantastic, but there are some glitches, but overall it is pretty well put together.  There are times where you can tell that it was ported, but don't let that fool you, it is still a great game.  The voice acting is superb, the Joker is voiced by Mark Hamill aka Luke Skywalker.  Batman is voiced by Kevin Conroy, the same man behind the Animated Series's Batman.  I never found any dull voice acting, even the minor characters were well done.  The game can last pretty long if you go for the side-quests, especially getting all the Riddler trophies without looking up hints.  Overall, I give it a 9/10, it is a great game once you get past some of the glitches, but for me I never had any problems with it except for some long load times at some points.  This is one of my favorite games of all time.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												A sequel to Batman Arkham Asylum and the second entry to the trilogy, it brought back everything that was succesful in Arkham Asylum, but gives you more with more interesting gadgets, and a big city sandbox to play with it in.PROS- The previous combat system is improved, but nothing changed too much, since it was already pretty good as it was before. - Big variety of enemies on how they will try to take you down, of course, that means you have more tools to take them down. Because you know, you're the Batman. Rich snob.- A large map is yours to glide around, not much to do, but still a big relief compared to the cramped space that was the Asylum.- Expanded the detective part of Batman a lot more with a variety of cases that range from homicide to search and rescue. - Two (or three, depending how you look at it) playable characters! Though its still more heavily focused on Batman, you'll get to play as Catwoman here and there. She's a little forgetable though. My only regret is that they didn't expand the use of Robin a little more than they should have.- Plot twists! Plenty of plot twists! It solved the previous game's problem of being a little predictable by having multiple side missions with their own little story focusing on some of the villains of the past. CONS- Goddammit, Riddler, you still prove to be annoying with your trophy collectibles, but now you come back with some really easy puzzles to solve for his side case. - A little short for the main story, but this is the type of game that you don't just focus on the main story. Its not really a complaint against it, you should focus on getting the most out of this game, not just the main campaign.- Post-game story uses a better way to fight bosses that aren't used for the main game. A little unforunate, since it was definitely more interesting to try and stealth takedown a boss than rushing at them announced.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Don't let the hours fool you. I have a lot of hours on the PS3 version i just recently decided to get the PC version. I have to honestly say this is one of the best games I have played in a while. Everything about this game i just love about it. The combat feels great. And I love the story of the Arkham games and this one to me doesnt dissappoint me at all. The pc port of this game feels like a really good port despite the specs i have i still can run this game rather well and still have a wonderful time with it. And like with the other Arkham games the riddler is here and boy are there a lot of stuff to do with especially since this is the Game Of The Year edition. Now I'm gonna talk about the combat. If you have played either Arkham Asylum or Orgins then the combat will feel the same. Arkham city's combat really feels perfect i can't really find a fault with it. If you have ever played sleeping dogs then this combat will feel the same. Now about the riddler there are a lot of riddles and riddler trophies to collect since this is the GOTY edition. If you enjoyed getting all of them in Asylum/Origins then you will enjoy getting them here. Now i haven't gotten all of them yet on the PS3 version but i do plan on getting all of them on here. Ill try to get talk about some of the story. The story begins with Catwomen trying to steal from Two-Face but then gets caught then the game cuts to bruce wayne getting shocked by Hugo Strange then a flashback happens and shows Bruce at the gates of Arkham City's gate saying how Arkham city is destorying the fine city of Gotham and he wants it shut down then he gets captured. Fast forward to bruce getting shocked and hugo strange saying how by the end of the night he will be a hero thanks to protocol 10. Its up to you Batman to figure out what protocol 10 is and shut it down before its too late. And one last thing the music Oh my god is it amazing. Every track fits what is going on. Buy the soundtrack if you love it. The soundtrack can be found on itunes. Overall I would give this game a 9/10. It is an amazing game and I feel like everyone should play it if you have the specs for it. And as of this theres a sale for it where its only 5 bucks. Get it while its on sale you will not be disappointed.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												Nagyon jó játék volt. A sztori érdekes volt, végig fenntartotta a figyelmet, voltak benne különösen jó pillanatok. A szereplők is nagyon jók voltak, a szinkronhangok is tetszettek. El lettek találva a játékbeli elemek. Jó ötletem tartom, hogy nem csak Batman-nel kellett játszani a játék során. A harcrendszer, a különféle újabb, és újabb ellenféltípusok is nagyon tetszettek. Egy-egy harcban eléggé meg lehetett izzadni, főleg, hogy egyszerre 3-4-5 fajta ellenséggel is kellett harcolni, és mind ellen más-más technikát kellett alkalmazni. A skillrendszer is tetszett, jó volt fejlesztgetni Batman képességeit, a kütyüim képességét, vagy akár Macskanőt. A Rébuszokkal is elvoltam, bár volt, amit nem tudtam megcsinálni, nem is kevés. A bossfight-ok különösképp jók voltak, bár azok nem voltak annyira nehezek, viszont annál inkább lehetett izgulni, hogy le tudjuk győzni az adott ellenfelet. Többször előfordult, hogy elakadtam, és hosszú ideig nem jöttem rá, hogy most mi a fenét is kellene csinálnom, de ez csak a játék mellett áll, ettől lesz egy Batman játék igazi Batman játék. Hisz mint tudjuk, ő a világ legnagyobb nyomozója, és nem csak egy agyatlan darálógép, így az Asylum-ból már megszokott környezeti puzzle-kből sem volt hiány -- már önmagában az a 400 Rébusz kihívás is nagyon sok agyalást, és gondolkodást követel, és ezt nagyon pozitív értelemben mondom. Tehát az egész játék a tetejétől a talpáig teljesen kiváló volt. Mindenkinek ajánlom a játékot, aki szereti Batman-t, esetleg csak szeretne egy jó sztorival rendelkező, játszásra érdemes játékkal foglalkozni. Azok is nyugodtan játszhatnak vele, akik az előző részt kihagyták. A játék nem túl hosszú, de rengeteg tartalom van benne, ha akarunk eltölthetünk 30-40 órát is, mire mindent megcsinálunk benne. Megérte végigjátszani! Kíváncsian várom az Origins-t, valószínűleg azt is elkezdem a közeljövőben.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
												A great sequel to a masterpiece of a game. Batman Arkham City took all the great points from Batman Arkham Asylum and combined them with the concept of an open world game - beautifully. I recommend you to play Batman AA before playing Batman AC to fully enjoy yourself.Pros:+ GREAT story, many new and interesting characters are added to this sequel. + GREAT gameplay. + GREAT fighting system. Free Flow Combat is still implemented beautifully. + GREAT array of classic and new gadgets, allowing you to takedown enemies with your own style. + GREAT sound. + GREAT atmosphere. + GREAT graphics. + GREAT characters and voice acting, the characters really felt like they are coming right out of the comics. + GREAT and beautiful open world. Arkham City is a big world with so many things to do beside the main story, such as side missions, collectibles, challenges, and more villains to kick.Cons:- Catwoman's "Thief Vision" is blurry and kinda hurt my eyes, but still acceptable.  Overall: 99/100BE THE BATMAN

COMPLETED 100%Decent game with the same excellent gameplay mechanics. Story however is pretty inconsistent; like how the heck did Batman keep up with his same performance despite being infected ill for 90% of the game? The whole main story isn't that long, in fact, it's pretty darn short if you just ignored all the riddler trophies and side missions.  Combat system is quite improved from Asylum but it becomes easy as pie once you master it.Arkham City is mostly cramped and tiny in size but does offer many incentives to explore (mostly riddler stuff). What's amazing is how the game is completely flawless from glitches/bugs throughout my entire playthrough. Real neat work.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
												I didn't enjoy Arkham City as much as Arkham Asylum, but it's still a great game and good continuation of the story. Everything else feels pretty much the same, which is a good thing... plus some new gadgets.What Arkham Asylum did better: the whole reality breaking psychological tricks were much better in Arkham AsylumWhat Arkham City did better: gave the opportunity to perch high and look down on the city, also gave additional playable characters that fit into the story with different gameplay stylesScarecrow (who didn't make a return in Arkham City) is one of my favourite villains, and I love the reality breaking stuff so it stands to reason that I'd like the first game better, however both games absolutely deliver on what their titles promise: Batman in an asylum and Batman in a city.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2016
												If you haven't played this game yet then I can assure you that you've missed out big time, buddy.Batman: Arkham City is without a doubt one of the most fun I've ever had playing a single-player game. And I'm not just saying that because I am a huge Batman fan: No, the gameplay and story itself are impeccably executed by Rocksteady Studios. As you progress through the main (and side) missions you'll have the opporunity to fight through a vast majority of the caped crusader's rogue gallery, each of whom present a great challenge and intriguing conflict to the player. You'll find yourself wanting to know what comes next and who is really behind the launch of Arkham City. The most important aspect of any game, however, is arguably the gameplay. To date I have seen very, very few games that offer such a fun and smooth combat system as presented by the Arkham games. Obviously many games have tried to emulate this flawless and freeflowing fighting system that Arkham City brings to the table, but none have even come close in my opinion.Especially considering how cheap this game has become I must insist that Batman: Arkham City is an absolute must-have for every gamer out there.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												Welcome to Arkham City the massive hub of riddler trophies and secrets... If you thought that the riddler collectables had a too big presence in the Asylum, you are out of luck. They are everywhere here. And they aren't exactly hidden, oh no, the green question marks are everywhere and they will spam you in the face even after you are done with him... four hundred riddler challenges/secrets for batman and forty for catwoman. This time riddler isn't alone, no he wants to force you to play with him, so if you are immersed in the role of crime fighter you have to find four hundred secrets in order to free the hostages!!! Frustrating and annoying affair. Making what should be an optional side objective at best feel like it is taking over the game... It really is the biggest down of this game.The bosses were all interesting encounters this time around, with different methods of taking them down. But the thugs... Damn there are a lot in an open city where they respawn. And they get way too repetitive.I preferred the atmosphere in Asylum, but this game is still dripping with that whole batman vibe, and you get to see a lot of the batman cast in your adventure in Arkham city. If your favorite is a more unknown character, there is still a chance that she/he won't be mentioned or appear.In the main campaign you get to play as batman and for some portions as Catwoman, who for some reason doesn't close her costume all the way... I mean it clearly looks like it can be zipped up all the way like normal, but for some reason she lets it be unzipped enough to reveal her cleavege. Maybe she thinks she will be a better thief if she distracts twoface and batman with breasts? But honestly I enjoyed playing as catwoman. I love the way she moves and her fight animation. All the voice acting is great as well as the character designs really fitting with the different personalities. Except for cat-cleavage... I'm sorry, but it really annoy me. Every time her front was on the screen I wanted to go over there and zip it up.The main story was interesting and had a shocking finish. Well shocking for those who hadn't seen spoilers. And even then you might not have seen all the spoilers related to the finish. I had heard the main one, but was still surprised at the end.I will recommend it to any fan of batman and action games, as long as you can stomach a grind for riddler secrets...

content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												Batman: Arkham City is what you get when a studio isn't trying and is content to rest on its laurels. Other than the half-hearted attempt at an open world setting, nothing stands out as being an improvement on the previous game and many things that Arkham Asylum did well were completely fumbled here.A brave game, trying new ideas while trying to stay fundamentally similar. Naturaly there are weaknesses in the recipe that Rocksteady has created - I can't say that the open world approach won me over.But despite that Arkham City is still a very strong game.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												A fantastic sequel to a fantastic game! I would recommend this to anyone who likes stealth-games and beat-'em-ups. It definitely improves on a lot of things from the first game, such as more upgrades and more fun way to take down enemies. I can't decide whether I like the changes made to the detective mode. I feel it is mostly a change made to make things harder, so you're not constantly in detective mode, scanning for enemies. It is now easier for enemies to destroy gargoyles, which means stealth becomes harder. Another improvement is that you get the batclaw, the explosive gel and the cry-something-hacker-device.With the GOTY-edition you get all the DLC, which there is a lot of, for example the Catwoman-pach which lets you play as catwoman from time to time, which makes combat completely different as Catwoman has different combat tools. If this doesn't convince you, just watch the trailer, which is fantastic.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												This game is awesome. The storyline is engaging (albeit short), the gameplay is smooth and easy to learn, the graphics are pretty good, and the staggering amount of side missions and game modes ensures that you won't run out of things to do for a very long time. The game is set in a detailed open-world mini city, with little side missions everywhere. There is also a bonus level, an alternate version of the storyline, and challenge maps that require you to beat up thugs by the truckful, along with the delightful predator mode gameplay, which is basically hiding in a high place and swooping in to take out your enemies before they know what hit them. If that wasn't enough, Catwoman, Robin, and Nightwing are playable characters in various game modes. This is a great game. Get it and you won't regret it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												Follow up to Arkham Asylum, the game that brought Batman to the realm of kickass gaming. In the same vein as its predecessor, Arkham City stylishly blends visual and conceptual elements from the Nolanverse, the Burtonverse, and most of all (and most importantly IMO), the Timmverse.Pros: Interesting story, but don't think that just because many of The Animated Series voice actors are involved that this is part of the TAS continuity. Many liberties were taken, but it all plays out pretty well, and pays enough homage to the DCAU to keep us 1990s Saturday Morning Cartoon kids pleased. An excellent arsenal of familiar and loveable characters. Amazing voice acting (of course). This is sadly, Mark Hamill's final outing as The Joker, ending his reign as one of the greatest and most iconic Joker portrayals in history, in my opinion only slightly behind Heath Ledger in the Number One spot.Combat that is fluid, easy enough for just about anyone to get used to, and fun enough to keep you wanting more.Cons: Really terrible third-person navigation. This doesn't affect the main story campaign so much, you can make it work well enough, but for a lot of the quick, tricky maneuvers required for the Extreme Challenge missions it becomes a real Bane. Want to grapple to that vantage point in a hurry? Too bad, you're going to grapple to this ledge with people on it instead. Need to dive over this railing to escape gunfire? Too bad, because Batman can't navigate around this short banister. Environmental circumstances must be JUST RIGHT to perform certain maneuvers, and that is really uncool. Don't expect this Batman to navigate obstacles like a ninja when the action gets intense. He's more like Russell Casse from Independence Day ("I'm fly... I'm pilot"). On Extreme Challenge Campaigns, this causes controller-chucking rage episodes. /rantMaybe it's just me, but the story mode campaign seemed a bit on the short side. I have not yet begun New Game Plus, but I definitely finished my first playthrough wishing there was more to it. I think that one contribution to this feeling is the fact that they crammed so many big-name foes that none of them really get enough screentime and a lot of them seem to come and go way too quickly. Take your time, explore everything, do all the things. All in all:I definitely recommend the game, especially if it's on sale. It's worth it for the main game. Add in the buttloads of concept art, character dossiers, and REALLY cool alternative character skins for the playable characters (yes, including really funny 3D adaptations of their TAS counterparts). I'm raging my way through the bonus missions, and I do plan on playing through the game again, gunning for full completion.

												The world is not over-large but big enough that it doesn't feel cramped and detailed enough to convince but not so detailed as to distract. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												Possibly the greatest action adventure game of this (past) generation. That generic genre descriptor really does apply for all the Arkham games though: there’s a lot of action, and you constantly feel like you’re on an adventure. Rocksteady capitalizes on the foundations of Asylum and takes the series along for a ride on the open-world bandwagon; however, they do so in a way that makes their AAA competitors simply look dull and slow. There’s a great feeling of speed and environmental mastery as you use your grapple and cape, upgraded here as a slingshot mechanism that hurls you into the air before bobbing down to maintain lift. Gadgets are now incorporated into your combat repetoire; A-list villains are actually given their due with some impressive boss encounters; the Catwoman chapter is short but immensely fun; environmental puzzles are more complex while the Riddler challenges are compulsively fun to track down and complete. You want to know how to make your collectathon mini games fun? Make them inherently fun, not because they reward a shiny or an achievement or feed your OCD (although all those are legit reasons). 'City' is packed with fun stuff to do.There’s just more of Arkham here: more characters, an expanded moveset, bigger and more diverse environments, more DC universe shoutouts and fanbait (the terrible Harley Quinn DLC is one such tease). It’s the ‘Batman Returns’ of the franchise: a louder and campier sequel that raises the fun quotient significantly, even if it comes at the cost of some narrative and design tightness.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												The Dark Knight/ Violent Saint returns in Arkham CityStoryThe story is written by Batman TAS veteran Paul Dini. Billionaire Bruce Wayne attends a press conference speaking against Gotham's latest project Arkham City. Arkham City is a walled off part of Gotham that houses all of the criminals from Arkham Asylum and Blackgate. There are no guards other than the Tyger mercenaries who rarely intervene, no cells and food drop-offs are not overseen by Tyger. Worse off gang wars occur in Arkham City with the powerful super criminals obtaining military grade weapons somehow. At the conference Bruce Wayne is taken by Tyger and the founder of Arkham City, Dr. Hugo Strange, reveals to Wayne that he knows he is Batman. He also tells him of Protocol 10 and how it will make him famous. With Hugo Strange obviously being a conniving piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ Wayne dons the mask of Batman and sets off to find out more about Protocol 10. But he later on faces more obstacles that all connect in one big story.GameplayThe freeflow combat is back and better than ever. You can counter multiple people and you have more quickfire combat weapons like the explosive gel and the freeze bombs. You also have more combo takedowns like a barrage of bats that disorient enemies, a barrage of batarangs that instantly incapacitate anyone laying on their backs, and more. The best thing about Arkham City is the open world. You have an entire city to explore along with the buildings that house the super criminals like the Penguin, Joker, and more. There are also side objectives you can do like break Tyger cameras just to make them mad, stop Zsasz from killing innocent people by making it from one payphone to another, finding a contract killer, and more. The missions in Arkham City are actually interesting to me. Most open world games I play have boring missions in my opinion and I really don't care about killing innocent civilians in GTA even if they are annoying. You can beat up random people and that is more satisfactory in my opinion. Arkham City has the full package.Catwoman seems like someone they added at the last minute though. She has her own upgrades so you think she will play a big role but she doesn't really. I will spoil what she does. She tries to steal something from Strange so she needs Poison Ivy to help. She fights Poison Ivy's plant slaves and then is captured by Ivy and is hung upside down. This happens early in the game. Later on Ivy lets her go if she promises to rescue her plant from Strange. The funny thing about this is that between her being captured and Ivy letting her go 10 HOURS HAVE PASSED and the game is near the end. So what you are saying is that Ivy hung Catwoman upside down for 10 hours in front of her face and did nothing for 10 hours? That is why I feel she was added at the last minute. After you beat the game you can play as her with her own sidequest (I am still on that) and so far it's pretty decent but in the main story her involvement is virtually nonexistent in the scope of the whole story (she did save Batman but big deal he could've flexed those rocks off of himself.)Wonderful game all around and I haven't even touched the Riddler's Revenge challenge maps or Harley Quinn's Revenge.EDIT: There is a mistake I would like to correct. I thought that Catwoman was held up by Ivy for 10 hours but when Catwoman says "It looks like he will be in there a while.." she is looking at the enterance to Wonder Tower not the Steel Mill. Despite this I still think she doesn't add much to the story.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
												This is the best game I have played on PC but that isn't saying much condidering I have a horrible computer and a low budget. But that brings up a point. My computer is horrid and can still run this game almost completely without lag which means it could probably run well on other dispicable computers. It also has a great story that is quite long but sadly you can't replay a specific mission so if you want to replay a section of the story you're gonna have to start from scratch. It has great graphics, nice voice acting, and amazing gameplay. Speaking of gameplay, it is quite unique. It has pretty great replayability, a variety of stealth takedowns, great combat, and of course, free roaming. There are two differnt types of maps, predator and combat. Combat is prett straight forward but predator is all based around stealth. You could go in guns a blazing but that will most likely get you killed. So you go in with a smile on your face and do some hardcore planning to takedown  4 guys at a time,or maybe that's just me. The combat is great too though. You have many different moves and combos that allow complete maneuverability in combat and you can leave almost any fight without a scratch if you are skilled enough (Like me). The DLC makes it even better. It allows you to be other characters with a wide variety of abilities and gadgets. Oh, I almost forgot to tell about the gadgets. There are a lot and every single one is extremely helpful. You can use many gadgets in combat and of course all of them in predator that are all nothing like the next. There are so many other things that I could tell you about but I would have to think about and I am too lazy so you're just gonna have to go on youtube or something and look it up or maybe buy this amazing game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												As I rewrite this, the meta rating is 96% positive. What should that say to you?I love this game. Open world but not oversized. Freeflow combat but not insanely overwhelming. Gadgets but not so many you feel overloaded. Story galore. Each street has its own tale. All the major baddies. Most of the secondaries. Catwoman pulls the camera back just enough to show another valid POV. The Story has the entierty of the dark knight saga behind it but never trily shys away from the fact that it's Batman versus himself and his own demons given form in the Joker. It continues stories from the first game, adds a little more in but never once does it ever dissappoint me in my eyes.It's a game that I play on the TV and my kids play it with me or treat it as a movie. They love flying all around the city. Even my wife played it one time through and never complained about it being that hard or difficult. I only paid $5 for the game on the Steam Summer Sale. Knowing what I know now about this game, it is the second best value of a game I have ever had second only to Minecraft. It is perfection at any price but when it is on sale, make it your first purchase.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												After playing Arkham Asylum, I was thirsty for more. This sequel proved what a sequel should do. Batman Arkham City expanded and improved upon what was already great for a Batman game. A smoother combat and stealth system and additonal tactics for taking out bad guys made this game incredibly replayable. I first bought this game on the Xbox 360, and I just had to to get it again for my PC. This game creates great sub-plots and introduces popular villains that were previously just referenced in Arkham Asylum. The first of the series felt repetitive with a simple combat system of "punch and counter" and fixes it with new enemies and moves that challenge you to utilize new combat moves. The only downsides to this game are the ridiculous amounts of Riddler trophies to collect, and the downplay of certain big-name villains such as Bane. Overall, this is a must-buy.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
												What can I say about this one? In a nutshell, it's fantastic. If your rig can handle the higher settings, this is still a STUNNING looking game. Combat is fantastic, intuitive, and just plain fun. The story was well worth it to me. You can either blow through the main story in a dozen or less hours, but if you invest in the side missions, riddler challenges, expect to spend a considerable amount of time in Arkham City.Bigger is not always better. Arkham City is larger in scope than its predecessor, Arkham Asylum, but is modest in size compared to other open world games today. What we do have here is an amazing attention to detail that left me simply staring at the scenery.The Riddler challenges require some patience. For some, they will seem overwhelming - just keep in mind that like the prior game, not all challenges can be done immediately. Certain upgrades will be required. Once those are, most challenges make sense and are surprisingly addictive to find!The Ending? FantasticThe voice acting? Fantastic?I played this on consoles when it first came out, but in some ways I felt like I was playing for the first time, thanks to the PC setting option - no comparisons. Never played it on PC, then you need to check out the game again!!!M

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												Gonna start off by being honest and saying I am 100% a Marvel fanboy. I absolutely love Marvel's movies and comics more than DC. However, I find Batman to be one of the coolest superheroes ever created.But with my Marvel fanboyness in mind... This is one of the best superhero games of all time, far surpassing almost any other that comes to mind. The sheer fluidity of the game, the takedowns, the well crafted story everything just comes together to make one of the best games of all time. Heck, this is one of the few games that actually let's you play your way, for the most part, with stealth or loud as an option. And enemies react based on what you're doing. If you take down all of their friends, they become scared. If they have all of their friends up and standing, they become more confident and taunting. There are so few games that make use of fear as something enemies exeperience, and it works so well for a Batman game.Rocksteady knows how to use Batman's story in the best way possible, and it makes me sad to know there's only one more game after this one. Buy this game at full price, it's worth it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												This game is an incredible improvement on the gameplay front compared to Asylum. The freeflow combat system is incredibly fun, and even better than before thanks to new enemy types, new gadgets, and, most importantly, significantly tightened up controls. People who played the previous game will know all those annoying situations when your punch happens to be just a bit too slow to stop an attack, or a counter not working. That happens extremely rarely now - whenever you break your combo, it is your fault. The predator sections are also more fun now, as the enemy henchmen now use their own gadgets to mess up your strategies, like the detective mode-disrupting jammers and mines, which you can also use against them.If you haven't played Asylum, well, prepare for one of the best combat systems in a game, ever. I am not overexaggerating. The freeflow combat system is incredibly simple to leare, but fun and has a lot of depth. It is used in fights with up to 40 unarmed or melee-armed henchmen. It's basics are simple: punch, dodge and counter, but add in the whole different layer of gadgets and special combos, and you really feel like the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed Batman. The predator sections are a whole different beast: up to 10 armed henchment in open rooms force you to play stealthily, swinging from vantage point to vantage point to take them out one by one. There are a lot of different ways to do this, from a simple takedown from the back to dragging your enemies over railings, blowing up walls and knocking them out with debris, and my personal favourite, disabling their guns, then dropping right in front of them and watching them struggle helplessly as you pummel them into sleep. There are just so many ways to approach an objective, that I can't help but adore these sections.This game adds a free roaming element to the series, and while it is by no means as developed in full-blown sandboxes, it really ties the game together quite nicely. There are a few sidequests which revolve around you catching various (super)criminals in the titular Arkham City, and they do not feel shoehorned in, although there could certainly be more of them. Simply put, don't buy this game just for the open world, as you will regret it if you do. The riddler trophies and riddles return, and they feel far better thanks to the open world. There is more of them, they give better rewards, and it is easier to find them thanks to the new informant system.As for the story, well, it is really the only weaker side of this game, at least when compared to Asylum. The linear structure of the last game lent itself far better to the type of story Rocksteady was trying to tell, but it is still by no means bad. Still, the big plot twist at the end is far too easy to spot, and the characters feel weaker than they did in the last game.The length of the game is around 8 hours, should you just want to complete the main story. However, 100%ing the game will take far more, which should prove really nice for a completionist like me: Besides the aforementioned riddler trophies and sidequests, there is a new game+ with tougher enemies and combat, but you start with all your gadgets, rather than aquiring them over the course of the plot, a 2-3 hour story DLC, and an incredibly large challenge mode.This challenge mode is a bit hit and miss: some people will find it very repetitive. What you need to know is that it can add around 10-20 hours of entertainment, should you choose to complete it.TL:DR;Chances are, you will really like this game if you liked Arkham Asylum.  If you haven't played it or didn't like Asylum, well, you will probably still like it. All in all, this a really good game and one of my favourite games ever, and I would recommend anyone to try it.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2013
												At first I thought they couldn't make anything better than Arkham Asylum, but I was proven wrong. This game is incredibly improved, much better controls, packed with extra content, new gadgets, new side-missions, new characters and enemies... They really went hardcore with this game. The single-player campaign is good and entertaining, but rather short and bosses are too easy, but they realized that and added an "extreme" mode, which is too difficult XDThe GOTY edition has all the DLCs and many different modes for you to play so you'll never get bored.The graphics are outstanding, but leave PhysX disabled if you don't have 2 or more GPUs in SLI. The game still uses UE3 but has bigger environments so you might experience some stutterings and slowdowns depending on your hardware. Loading times have decreased, though.You don't need to play the first one before this one, since it's a completely different story, but you'll get familiar with the controls more quickly if you played Arkham Asylum.Soundtrack is as epic as the first game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2013
												The gameplay is top notch. The stealth, but especially the combat, are much improved since the first game. The fluidity of its "easy to learn, hard to master" combat mechanics puts stuff like "Assassin's Creed" (with its silly hold block until you can counter kill simplicity) to shame. In fact, I'm hard pressed to think of another third person game which has better hand to hand combat than "Batman: AC."The open world is a nice touch too, even though alot of the side quests are kind of a pain and best left alone given that they tend to be of the "find x number of hidden objects on a map, then fight a boss" variety. The main plot is better, but never really matches the highs of "Arkham Asylum." It tries to cram every single Batman villain ever into one overarching storyline, and not only does this stretch credulity even in comic book terms, but individual segments feel rushed and lack the depth of "Arkham Asylum" (which focused on relatively fewer villains). Still, if you approach it more as a series of slightly interrelated episodes rather than one grand story the game works much better. Despite its flaws it surpasses the original in most respects and in terms of pure gameplay might be the best third person action game on the market; definitely more polished, better made, and way more fun than any given Assassin's Creed game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												Batman: Arkham City is just as good as (maybe even better than) the previous title in the Batman: Arkham series! I thoroughly enjoyed every aspect of it. From the gameplay that makes you feel like the Batman himself, to the joy of flying around Arkham City, helping political prisoners from getting beaten up by thugs and finding the Riddler's trophies. If you're a major fan of Batman or just superheroes in general, this is a MUST-BUY for you! It really is just that simple!!Without delving into the game's story and giving away key details, I will just say that the story is nothing short of movie-quality action. Batman is my favourite superhero of them all, and so I couldn't help from getting excited everytime a cutscene would come on, because the voice-acting and character animations are just superb! The music is true to the franchise too and, if you're familiar with the dark world that the latest movies are set in, you will find that this game perfectly represents the world that Batman is set in.One of the best parts of the game is the gameplay itself. Aside from the ability to glide around the city, grappling to gargoyles and rooftops in order to get to places, the combat is what you will be most interested in. Some would argue that it's a simple system of having to attack, counter, attack, counter, and so on. But in the later stages of the game, you will have to learn the movesets of certain enemies that are of a greater risk to you. Facing off multiple enemies with guns, though, will require you to take them out in a stealthy manner. This is where your gear and gadgets come into full play. From the classy batarang to the grenade-like freeze blast, there are plenty of weapons at your disposal to use.So with the game staying true to the Batman franchise, and the gameplay being spot on, the only thing left to discuss are the visuals. Simply put, they are great, and so I have nothing to complain about with them. Even on my 7 year old system (which was close to mid-range at the time) can run this game. And on top of all of this great news, this is the GOTY edition, so you will be able to enjoy things such as Catwoman's storyline, intertwined with Batman's! Definitely get this game, you won't regret it!Enjoy! :D

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												-Prologue-I'm going to try and do this review without going into too much detail and without any spoilers from Batman: Arkham Asylum and Arkham City, so if there are parts that are lacking from my review, it's because they are tied into the story.Batman: Arkham City is the second in the Arkham series, and I'd be lying if I said that I didn't enjoy it thoroughly. I bought it in the recent Summer Sale for $5, which is a real steal. After the 17 Gb download, I was ready to plunge into this brilliant game, after being impressed by Arkham Asylum. It's beautiful scenery down to it's simplistic but engaging combat and it's amazing character potrayals. With that said, Arkham City does the exact same thing, except we're taken to the whole of Arkham Island. The city has been made to an excellent quality, and I couldn't help but get lost in it's picturesque beauty, despite being in a ghetto-like area.The storyline was enjoyable with enough action and adventure to keep you occupied. In regards to length, I got through the main missions and objectives in about 7 hours with the odd sidequest here and there. The main missions (or quest, if you will) were interesting, but some objectives were only put in to either extend gameplay time or frustrate the player. This bothered me at points, but I kept going for the delectable reward which would be a boss fight or a cutscene, which is all acted and set excellently, as you would expect. Villains felt amazingly recreated, and I loved every single one. Not to mention the Joker, who by far was the most interesting one of them all, which once again would be expected. Now, coming out of Arkham Asylum, I was quite disappointed about his potrayal at the end, as it was the polar opposite of what the Joker stood for, but without getting into too much detail about that, I'll move on. In Arkham City, you see less of the Joker than compared to Arkham Asylum, but that's to make way for the other villains such as Two Face, The Penguin, Catwoman (in a sense), Mr Freeze, etc. This wasn't a bad choice, but I really did the interactions with the Joker, but every conversation or cutscene with him was savoured and was enjoyable to witness.To sum up the storyline, we move on about 6 months from the events of Arkham Asylum and the Joker has fallen ill from a disease (which it's origins are explained in AA) and so, with his final hours on the horizon, he is in need of a cure. While in the mean time, another villain comes into the picture by the name of Hugo Strange, who is hell bent on executing 'Protocol 10' and it's up to the Dark Knight to stop it, at all costs. The idea was good, and I liked how they went about it, but I feel it could've felt a lot more alive and engaging if they were to incorporate more villains into the story. Of course, that's not to say that I didn't enjoy the villains that they did include into the main story; I thought they were brilliantly played and potrayed, but more of that was needed. I found myself questioning the result of what I was doing because I found the objectives dull and grindish in a way, but the outcome was interesting interations with them, and that's what kept me going throughout the whole game.The basis of the game, the combat system, is simplistic as mentioned before, with Left Click your primary attack and Right Click being your counter attack, alongside your gadgets which are all able of use in combat situations. This made for interesting firefights and it always remained fresh, if using the gadgets, which I did infrequently as I saw no point if my basic attacks would get me through the game. If you choose to take combat like me and just click the hell out of your mouse, then you're in for an interesting time. It's effective, but it does get dull quickly, which is where this game falls short of a prolonged enjoyment in combat. Initially, you go around looking for fights and you get excited for your next fight. Then as time passes, you try to find ways around fights and you're flying pass every opportunity to engage the enemy and they just become an annoyance more than anything. The developers tried their best to keep it interesting with the addition of extra enemy types and different move types, but these were short lived revivals, and they soon became part of the common fodder of boring combat.Stealth was one of the many strong points of Batman: Arkham City, which was interesting throughout the whole game in my opinion. I had a lot of fun in every situation that involved stealth, and it got me using tactics and patience. This was another part of the game that was done to a superb degree, and I'm sure most players would agree.The boss fights were interesting and quite enjoyable. They were designed really nicely, and they weren't too unbalanced/frustrating, nor were they too easy. You'll definitely have your favourites when playing through the game, and some you wish would just end with the next blow, but I never felt that urge to give up due to difficulty or the fact I disliked it. It's expected that the boss fights be amazing, but this is definitely not a note to glance over.If you purchased the Game of the Year Edition, depending on how much of a Batman fan you are, you'll enjoy it on different levels. If you're a die-hard fan like me, then you'll love the additional (and playable) character models from some of the comic books and the TV series for Batman and Catwoman. There are additional challenges available, but no one buys this game for the challenges, let's be honest here. Along with that, you'll get the Catwoman campaign which comes with 4 missions with Catwoman and more collectables which are just for her, you cannot collect them if you're playing as Batman which I thought was quite smart. You'll also get 'Harley Quinn's Revenge', which is the final chapter to the story of Arkham City, as by the end of the game, you'll definitely want more. I can assure you that you will want more, and the developers responded with this little DLC.To sum up, the performance was smooth on max settings without the DX11 additions enabled, and that's with my GTX 650, which I thought was quite impressive. The challenges you will glance over because you'll play them when you have nothing better to do. The information that the game provides about the characters of the Batman universe is brilliant for people who want to know a little more about their favourite characters. The 3D 'trophies' that you unlock over time look fantastic and are nice to look at every once and a while. Although Arkham Island can be a little dull to explore, and some objectives are grueling, you'll definitely enjoy the results that come. With interesting characters executed in a brilliant way and an atmospheric world, you'll love the eerie nature that is Batman: Arkham Asylum. Although your playtime for main missions is at 7~ hours, you'll still have plenty more hours to put into side missions and for completionists, you have plenty to keep you occupied for quite a while.I'll give this an 8.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												THIS REVIEW MAY CONTAIN GAMEPLAY SPOILERS!!!I really enjoyed playing Batman:Arkham city, it was one of the best games i've ever played. The fist-fighting is amazing, like when-at various points- you take on about twenty people in one fight. The stealth sequences are also tens, and exciting, after flying across Arkham city beating the small groups of people up, I always liked a good stealth section. The combat consists mainly of spamming x, square, or left-mouse button, and occasionally y, triangle or right-mouse button to counter the thugs' attacks. That sounds incredibly boring, but once you have a high enough free-flow combo(Something that lets you do speacial takedowns and other moves when you have enough punches) you can hurl yourself around the battlefields, not letting anybody attack you because by the time they try you are mangling somebody else, it is very fun. Once you get enough free-flow combo, instead of hurling yourself around like a lunatic, you can also do speacial moves, like one that lets you take out one person automatically. You have to purchase the others when you level up, which takes me to the skill tree. There is multiple things you can invest your skill points on, like the speacial moves in fist fighting, or the different gadgets to use in fist fighting or stealth. The stealth is basically crouch-walking around, not getting detected and stealthily taking people out. Again, this sounds boring, but it is tense, terrifying(especially on one of the stealth boss-battles) and overall, fun. A good thing about it is that if you get detected, for whatever reason, you still have a chance to get away, like there are gargoyles that you can swing around on, and multiple vents and floor grates to hide in, but if the thugs find an unconcious body by one, they will check it, and if you are in it they will start shooting you. The game starts with you as Bruce Wayne, being sent into Arkham city, which is just a walled off section of Gotham city to keep the bad-guys in. You get taken through a section where you are introduced to the combat, and Tyger guards, a group of guards led by Hugo Strange, the mega-bad-guy who knows Bruce Wayne's secrets. You then have to scale a building called Ace chemicals, where you get the batsuit and have to save Catwoman from Two-face. SKIPPING. After a while, you go to Joker's place in a steel mill, where you break into his office, and he poisons you! He knocks you out and-he is poisoned too- He puts his blood in you. You then do a section about Ra's Al Ghul, somebody who controls a Lazarus pit, which is a pit full of danger! You then do a boss-fight against him, which I would say is certainly the best boss-fight in the game. You then get cured and go to wonder tower, which is a big tower in the middle of Arkham city. You do a very difficult stealth bit at the top, where the gargoyles are actually on the outside of the tower so you cannot do inverted takedowns(reaching down off a gargoyle and lifting someone up, strangling them until unconcious, and dropping them with rope attached) You then go into Hugo Strange's office, there is a cutscene, he says "Activate protocol 11" and you run out and the tower blows up and there is a sequence where Ra's Al Ghul kills himself because he will live forever and he doesn't want to.I would definetly give this amazing game 10/10, for its excellence, and I would very highly reccomend it. BUY THIS GAME!!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2013
												The gameplay is top notch. The stealth, but especially the combat, are much improved since the first game. The fluidity of its "easy to learn, hard to master" combat mechanics puts stuff like "Assassin's Creed" (with its silly hold block until you can counter kill simplicity) to shame. In fact, I'm hard pressed to think of another third person game which has better hand to hand combat than "Batman: AC."The open world is a nice touch too, even though alot of the side quests are kind of a pain and best left alone given that they tend to be of the "find x number of hidden objects on a map, then fight a boss" variety. The main plot is better, but never really matches the highs of "Arkham Asylum." It tries to cram every single Batman villain ever into one overarching storyline, and not only does this stretch credulity even in comic book terms, but individual segments feel rushed and lack the depth of "Arkham Asylum" (which focused on relatively fewer villains). Still, if you approach it more as a series of slightly interrelated episodes rather than one grand story the game works much better. Despite its flaws it surpasses the original in most respects and in terms of pure gameplay might be the best third person action game on the market; definitely more polished, better made, and way more fun than any given Assassin's Creed game.

Posted: April 17, 2014
												What can I say about this one? In a nutshell, it's fantastic. If your rig can handle the higher settings, this is still a STUNNING looking game. Combat is fantastic, intuitive, and just plain fun. The story was well worth it to me. You can either blow through the main story in a dozen or less hours, but if you invest in the side missions, riddler challenges, expect to spend a considerable amount of time in Arkham City.Bigger is not always better. Arkham City is larger in scope than its predecessor, Arkham Asylum, but is modest in size compared to other open world games today. What we do have here is an amazing attention to detail that left me simply staring at the scenery.The Riddler challenges require some patience. For some, they will seem overwhelming - just keep in mind that like the prior game, not all challenges can be done immediately. Certain upgrades will be required. Once those are, most challenges make sense and are surprisingly addictive to find!The Ending? FantasticThe voice acting? Fantastic?I played this on consoles when it first came out, but in some ways I felt like I was playing for the first time, thanks to the PC setting option - no comparisons. Never played it on PC, then you need to check out the game again!!!M

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												Batman Arkham City to me was the best video game released during the 7th console generation (2005-2014). Where ever you go trying to do the main story, Arkham City leads you off the trail to do side missions, investigate puzzles and beat the tar out of thugs. You can do various objectives in different order, it's non-linear. Unfortunately you can't solve every Riddler puzzle until you get the last equipment including the line launcher and freeze blast, but don't get hung up on that. I love being able to fly around Gotham with the grapnel boost, following custom way points or deviating from them to spontaneously do something else without getting lost. Top notch voice acting for Batman, Joker and Harley. The Batman villain roster is impressive. I didn't think much of Batman Arkham Asylum, the claustrophobic setting was limited, but was consistent to the story at least.  It's the perfect sequel. Newgame+ and the hard difficulty proves replay ability. The point in the story where Batman is forced to complete the demon trials was where I became the most engaged.If you grew up watching the Tim Burtom Batman movies, including Forever and the Warner Brother animated series, you gotta play this. It's the best representation of Batman in a video game.5/5Here is a list of my favorite games released during the 7th generation of consoles. Honorable mentions to Dead Rising 2 Off The Record, Skyrim, Portal 2 , Call Of Duty Black Ops and Super Mario Galaxy. 1. Batman Arkham City (Best flow of navigation and mission activity)2. Fallout New Vegas (Balances FO3 for more challenge and variety) 3. Bioshock 1 (Defines FPS 1P)4. Call Of Duty 4 (Defines FPS Multiplayer)5. Super Smash Brothers Brawl (Reason to get a Wii)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												Possibly the greatest action adventure game of this (past) generation. That generic genre descriptor really does apply for all the Arkham games though: there’s a lot of action, and you constantly feel like you’re on an adventure. Rocksteady capitalizes on the foundations of Asylum and takes the series along for a ride on the open-world bandwagon; however, they do so in a way that makes their AAA competitors simply look dull and slow. There’s a great feeling of speed and environmental mastery as you use your grapple and cape, upgraded here as a slingshot mechanism that hurls you into the air before bobbing down to maintain lift. Gadgets are now incorporated into your combat repetoire; A-list villains are actually given their due with some impressive boss encounters; the Catwoman chapter is short but immensely fun; environmental puzzles are more complex while the Riddler challenges are compulsively fun to track down and complete. You want to know how to make your collectathon mini games fun? Make them inherently fun, not because they reward a shiny or an achievement or feed your OCD (although all those are legit reasons). 'City' is packed with fun stuff to do.There’s just more of Arkham here: more characters, an expanded moveset, bigger and more diverse environments, more DC universe shoutouts and fanbait (the terrible Harley Quinn DLC is one such tease). It’s the ‘Batman Returns’ of the franchise: a louder and campier sequel that raises the fun quotient significantly, even if it comes at the cost of some narrative and design tightness.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												The world is not over-large but big enough that it doesn't feel cramped and detailed enough to convince but not so detailed as to distract. The combat system is precise, full of useful options and endlessly entertaining. The voice acting is positively top-notch. The music is excellent. The story veers madly from the ridiculous to the sublime but never fails to engage meaningful gameplay. Without DLC there is a massive amount of stuff to do and with it things get almost silly.Yeah, I think this game is pretty much okay.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												If you told me 5+ years ago that a lesser-known studio under a massive publisher is making a triple-A comicbook hero game adaptation, I'd be a cynic.2011, Batman:Arkham City was released, the sequel to the acclaimed Batman:Arkham Asylum developed by Rocksteady studios. While AA managed to exceed the expectations of cynics like me, being a really polished and solid game in itself, AC rose way up higher, being one of the most amazing games in recent memory. Or at least for me personally.Arkham City, in essence, is Arkham Asylum with a massive open world, slightly better animations (e.g. no more cretins holding their heads when they're defeated, regardless of where you actually hurt them) and more polishes around its edges, It manages to keep the fantastic, fluid combat, excellent level design, atmospheric setting, incredible narrative and oh-so perfect voice acting. So much of this review has been said in my previous review of AA.Combat in AC is satisfying as ever, but now with more awesome animations and more importantly, more gadgets and the introduction of freeflow gadgets. Freeflow gadgets basically allows you to incorporate your gadgets mid-combat more seamlessly which makes the variety of combos way more exciting. With the introduction of more gadgets comes more approaches in combat which plays a huge part in AC and is without a doubt, extremely fun to experiment with different gadgets in different combat situations.Boss fights in AC are a major improvement from its predecessor. Each boss is almost perfectly depicted as their comicbook counterpart not only in terms of presentation, but also their method of combat. Bottom line, boss encounters are extremely fun and at times challenging, although some bosses rely alot on button mashing.Stealth in AA relied a lot on the game's excellent level design and combat/gadgetry to a certain extent (ignoring the clumsy AI). AC manages to yet again, excel in the series' stealth aspect with even more incredible level designs and as said earlier, more gadgets which also are incorporable for stealthy approaches. If you are a fan of stealth games, I recommend playing the game on hard because more often than not when you have a multiple gun-armed men encounter, you are forced to approach them extremely stealthily as guns kill you fairly quick. IMO, stealth on hard in Arkham City is feels just as or even more rewarding than combat.Talking about stealth, it is almost unignorable to talk about the clumsy AI. Whilst enemies patroling/covering area are sometimes very tight and challenging, it sometimes fails to notice you in obvious positions of their line of sight and I am also convinced they never look behind or above them (unless theyre using thermo). This most definitely needs work.Presentation of the game is without a doubt a massive eye (and ear) candy. The world is grim, dark and quite large, managing to retain the gothic atmosphere of AA once again. AC manages to have an ungeneric world due to being able to not to use generic buildings or placing alike buildings very close to each other. Rocksteady manages to put a lot of easter eggs in the world pretty well with references to the comic book stories in the form of riddler challenges and sidemissions. There's one easter egg where if you go to crime alley within the game which really generates a ton of feels (personally), if you are getting this game, do not forget to check it out, this shows the amount of effort the devs put into the game.The music is not only extremely good as well, but its placement within each scene is perfection, definitely worth checking out the soundtrack itself. Voice acting, oh my god, Mark Hamill nails it down the ground yet again with his portrayal of Joker, alongside Kevin Conroy, Tara Strong and every other villain as well being quite possibly one of the best voice-acting crew in the history of gaming. This helps build a spot-on portrayal of each character which is already presented extremely well with each of their character models and great costume design.Story-wise, a lot of reviews I've read mentions that AC isn's as strong as AA but I say otherwise. While I do agree some villains felt rather shoehorned into the story after much thought, my initial playthrough almost ignores this fact due to the game's undeniably spectacular narrative. AC's narrative played out extremely well and felt very much alike a blockbuster movie (perhaps maybe even comparable to Nolan's trilogy) as the scale felt grand as compared to AA. Overall, I felt that the story was pretty much one of the key selling points of the game (again, personally).Well that pretty much covers all my opinions of the game. I admit I do have abit of a Batboner (ok not that small after all..) but whether or not you are a huge fan of Batman should not be taken to consideration if you are deciding whether or not to buy this game because personally, Batman:Arkham City is one of the best games in recent memory. Treat yourselves well by buying yourselves this incredible piece of entertainment.Conclusion; a fantastic game with incredibly satisfying combat, rewardingly challenging stealth, a relatively large world with excellent world and level design, great atmosphere of grim ( and yet, epicness of being the caped crusader), perfect sound direction and composition, unforgettable characters with their spot-on impressions/models/costume and triple-A voice acting, great story and a wonderful narrative. Yes, this game is so good i ran out of unique positive reinforcement adjectives to use. 9.5/10 - Brings me wonders how TESV got goty instead of this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Taking to the roof-tops as The Dark Knight in this game is a surprising delight. Gliding through the skies to swoop down on gangs of thugs, solving some of the many side missions, or just playing the actual story campaign - whatever your preference this game will most likely satisfy it (unless you want to be tooling around in a Batmobile, but I'll get to that in a sec)The combat is well executed and in the style we have come to expect as a result of the Chris Nolan movies and, whilst some may find it repetitive, it has the option of being a straight-up slug fest or a combination of well timed moves. The general opponents range from unarmed thugs to snipers, shield carriers and some in body armour - each of which requires a slightly different approach.The open-world format gives you the freedom to do things in your own time, breaking up the story with numerous side missions and a staggering number of "collectibles" so even when the story is finished there is still plenty to do in Arkham City.About the aforementioned Batmobile : The close confines and ruined conditions in Arkham City really don't lend themselves to using a vehicle so to be honest it's really not a piece of Lore that I missed. The combination of Gliding and grapple assisted parkour are more than capable of getting you anywhere in the map in pretty good time.The characterisations are perfect (although this is sadly the last time Mark Hamill will be voicing the Joker) and the scripting is well enough written to let the voice talent really shine. The animations are smooth and fluid, even in the midst of combat with multiple opponents.As a player, the only thing I'd suggest is that you get a controller for this game, much as I prefer Keyboard and Mouse it is better suited to a handset.Overall, I'd say that this was definitely one of my better purchases - but don't take my word for it, get your hands on a copy and see for yourself.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												You enter a room full of henchmen guarding a certain supervillain's gear from Batman's rogue gallery. By activating detective mode you see that there are 8 in total, with 2 armed and a hostage. One of them also has a thermal scanner attached. You slowly creep from a vantage point and begin a silent takedown. Once he is unconcious a beeping sound occurs. Suddenly everyone in the room is alerted to your presence and you grapple to a vantage point to re-assess the situation. You drop down and hide under a grate before perfoming a takedown that finishes with a loud thud. The remaning six run down the stairs and approach you. You hide behind a weak wooden wall that you have sprayed explosive gel on before imploding it onto the first man that approaches. They start shooting at you and you throw batarangs at three of them before dropping a smoke pellet. Activating detective mode you calmly batclaw one of the henchmen outside the smoke towards you, knocking him unconcious. You take down one more before grappling up to another vantage point.Panicking and with his heart rate rising one guy takes the hostage and threatens to kill him. Another runs up and starts shooting down one vantage point, shouting and saying you won't be able to use it. The third man runs under your vantage point and uses his thermal scanner. However because of your anti-heat detection upgrade he doesn't detect you as you stand perfectly still. You then drop down and leave him hanging from the gargoyle you were perched on as he screams. The others rush over and you use you disrupter to jam the armed guy's weapon. You then throw a freeze grenade at the first guy rooting him in place before flying up to a vantage point. The guy with a gun becomes shaky as his weapon is no longer working and he has lost sight of you as you have quickly moved from vantage point to vantage point. As he moves under you you drop down on him and knock him out before running to the frozen guy and finishing him with an ice takedown. Batman then proceeds to clean and brush his wristguards very casually.This is just one tiny morsel of an amazing open-world game. Buy it and play through the rest.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
												This is the best game I have played on PC but that isn't saying much condidering I have a horrible computer and a low budget. But that brings up a point. My computer is horrid and can still run this game almost completely without lag which means it could probably run well on other dispicable computers. It also has a great story that is quite long but sadly you can't replay a specific mission so if you want to replay a section of the story you're gonna have to start from scratch. It has great graphics, nice voice acting, and amazing gameplay. Speaking of gameplay, it is quite unique. It has pretty great replayability, a variety of stealth takedowns, great combat, and of course, free roaming. There are two differnt types of maps, predator and combat. Combat is prett straight forward but predator is all based around stealth. You could go in guns a blazing but that will most likely get you killed. So you go in with a smile on your face and do some hardcore planning to takedown  4 guys at a time,or maybe that's just me. The combat is great too though. You have many different moves and combos that allow complete maneuverability in combat and you can leave almost any fight without a scratch if you are skilled enough (Like me). The DLC makes it even better. It allows you to be other characters with a wide variety of abilities and gadgets. Oh, I almost forgot to tell about the gadgets. There are a lot and every single one is extremely helpful. You can use many gadgets in combat and of course all of them in predator that are all nothing like the next. There are so many other things that I could tell you about but I would have to think about and I am too lazy so you're just gonna have to go on youtube or something and look it up or maybe buy this amazing game.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												First game was my absolute favorite game to come out in years when it arrived, until I purchased Arkham City. Bigger, Prettier, and still retains that feeling of being a love letter to fans of The Dark Knight (hallowed be his name). If there's any series out there that pays more respect and courtesy to it's source materials and said source's fans it's probably The Witcher series, but this is a wickedly close second. If you love open-world brawlers, platformers, modern 3ps metroidvanias, and The Bat, you owe it to yourself to play this game, and play it till there ain't nothin left.NOTE: I know I only have 10ish hours of playtime recorded as of posting this, but I logged many many more hours on my faithful Xbox 360, which I dumped for a PC.
