As he moves under you you drop down on him and knock him out before running to the frozen guy and finishing him with an ice takedown. Batman then proceeds to clean and brush his wristguards very casually.This is just one tiny morsel of an amazing open-world game. Buy it and play through the rest.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												You enter a room full of henchmen guarding a certain supervillain's gear from Batman's rogue gallery. By activating detective mode you see that there are 8 in total, with 2 armed and a hostage. One of them also has a thermal scanner attached. You slowly creep from a vantage point and begin a silent takedown. Once he is unconcious a beeping sound occurs. Suddenly everyone in the room is alerted to your presence and you grapple to a vantage point to re-assess the situation. You drop down and hide under a grate before perfoming a takedown that finishes with a loud thud. The remaning six run down the stairs and approach you. You hide behind a weak wooden wall that you have sprayed explosive gel on before imploding it onto the first man that approaches. They start shooting at you and you throw batarangs at three of them before dropping a smoke pellet. Activating detective mode you calmly batclaw one of the henchmen outside the smoke towards you, knocking him unconcious. You take down one more before grappling up to another vantage point.Panicking and with his heart rate rising one guy takes the hostage and threatens to kill him. Another runs up and starts shooting down one vantage point, shouting and saying you won't be able to use it. The third man runs under your vantage point and uses his thermal scanner. However because of your anti-heat detection upgrade he doesn't detect you as you stand perfectly still. You then drop down and leave him hanging from the gargoyle you were perched on as he screams. The others rush over and you use you disrupter to jam the armed guy's weapon. You then throw a freeze grenade at the first guy rooting him in place before flying up to a vantage point. The guy with a gun becomes shaky as his weapon is no longer working and he has lost sight of you as you have quickly moved from vantage point to vantage point. As he moves under you you drop down on him and knock him out before running to the frozen guy and finishing him with an ice takedown. Batman then proceeds to clean and brush his wristguards very casually.This is just one tiny morsel of an amazing open-world game. Buy it and play through the rest.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												The best in the sereis This is the secound instalment in the Arkham sereies, and this is truely the most eventfull of the games I have palyed. The overall gameplay is like the first game in the sereis, but it have been inproved, and perfected. The fighting part of the game, is made by using the mouse to navigate whitch charecter you want to attack, you use the left mouse button to attack and the right to counter, you can also use the middle to confuse. Along the way the enemeys get harder, and get new equpment, and new tacktics must be used to deafeat them. There is also the stealth element, where Batman must take down a room with armed thugs in order to continue or save someone. Here you must plan your attacks and be paistent in order to succed. There are so many small details in this game, and I really love how many mini games and challenges, there are. You can take challenges in fighting and stealth, and use diffrent charecters such as catwomen, there is also a playable charecter in the story mode, nightwing and robin. Furthermore, in the main game Zaez is on the run, the Riddler is kisnapping people and putting up his throphies and riddles to find again. The Mad Hatter is runnig amok, and so much more. The story is the best Batman story in a long time. The story takes palce after the events of Arkham Asylum, where the Joker have become sick becouse of the titan serum he took, meanwhile Bruce Wayne is sent to the new jail city Arham City, and here we find out that Hugo Strange now knows, who Batman really is. This makes the plot more interesting, and it only get`s more tence after the Joker infects Batman with he`s blood. So now Batman needs to find a cure and defeat Hugo Strange, in order to keep he`s identety hidden. Since this is a prison city, we meet many other charecters, such as the Penguine, Mister Frezze, Solomon Grundy, Clayface and even Ras al` Ghoul. Every single charecter is well made, and really memerable. Along the way, you can also find informatiomn about the charecters, inside Arkham city, this only adds more depth to the charecters and I love it. The ending is worth talking about, and this is also the part where I talk about the DLC mission from the game, if you don`t want the ending spolied, don`t read untill you see the spoiler over part.-----------spoilers------------In this game, the Joker dies, this is a shock to anyone who played this game, and it is truely a fantastic ending. It is clear that Batman will be scared by this event, since the Joker and Batman, have a conection deep down, every fan of the seires knows about. The Joker needs Batman and the other way around, but this put the nail in the coffin and made a climactic ending, that will be remembered by me.This leads to the events after the attack on Arkham, and guees who`s gone mad? Well of couse it`s Harly Quen. Since the Joker died, she have kidnapped police officers, and turned prttey goth. We also find out that Batman have been kidnapped, and that Harly Quen thought she was pragnent with Jokers child, whitch only made her even more mad. It is up to Robin to save the day in this DLC, and it is a nice change since you have played as Batman all day in the main game. ------------spoilers over----------Overall this game is really well designed and it is a fantastic story, that have twist and turns along the way, plus fantasitc sceneory, that only will make you love the game even more, thumps up. 8 out of 10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2014
												I'm ashamed to admit that this game was my first Batman experience. I'd never been interested enough to watch any of the movies or read the comic books, so I had no prior knowledge beyond Batman being a guy in a batsuit. Even so, I really enjoyed this game.Gotham City is absolutely beautiful, and jumping/gliding from building to building never gets old. The game is also filled with interesting characters – allies and villains alike. There are plenty of familiar faces for people who know the franchise, but they were convincing enough for me to like them based on the game alone.Add to that some interesting game mechanics and boss fights (a direct approach will not always work) and an engaging storyline, and I see no reason for people not to play this game. Even if like me, you have no prior interest in the franchise – Arkham City just might surprise you.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												The Game of the Year Edition of Batman: Arkham City packages new gameplay content, seven maps, three playable characters, and 12 skins beyond the original retail release. Also included is the exciting epilogue, Harley Quinn's Revenge -- in this mission, players are sent back into Arkham City to face their final challenge as they interchange between playing as both Batman and Robin. Utilize each of the characters' unique combat and investigative skills to uncover Harley's vengeful plan and shut the gates on the urban mega-prison forever. In addition to experiencing a new storyline, fans can explore new environments and face-off against Harley's all new gang of thugs.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												An ambitious folllowup to Arkham Asylum.  Arkham City paints with a much broader brush, but doesn't quite paint a complete picture.  If one were to simply play the main storyline and disregard any sidequests in this game, Arkham City would easily be on par with Arkham Asylum.  However, when the side quests are taken into account, the overall package falls short.  The sidequests feel like constant buildups towards payoffs that don't happen.  Half of the side missions result in nothing more than a nod to past comic book storylines, while the other half culminate in an unsatisfying stealth takedown of the villain who put you through so much frustration to get to him.  When the game asks you to find and collect several hundred collectables only to "reward" you with a stealth gauntlet and a stealth takedown on the perpetrator, it just doesn't feel like you have been rewarded at all.If you were to play this game for fun, I would reccommend ignoring everything but the main storyline.  There's a solid game there, but it is buried in an unfocused and unrewarding open world environment.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												Overall Score: 10/10       ---------------------------------------Concept: 10Great story, Batman fans will love it. Took Arkham Asylum, made it more open world, and fixed all the flaws with the game, while at the same time making it alot more interesting. ---------------------------------------Graphics: 10Game looks really nice, textures are great, nice shaders, good character models, and still runs great on lower end machines. Can't go wrong there!----------------------------------------Sound: 10Good music, good voice acting, good sound effects, not much more to say about that.----------------------------------------Playability: 10Pretty nicely optimized for PC, no complaints about that. Supports keyboard and controller. Somple combat, yet can be alot more complex. You won't encounter many glitches, if any. ----------------------------------------Entertainment: 10SO much to do in this game, a decent sized open world packed full of secrets and missions to do. hardly is there ever a dull moment. lots of gameplay hours are needed to 100%.

												This is my 5th favorite game of all time (my other 4 being Sly's 1 and 2, jak and daxter, and jak II). I love this game so much. Protical 10 made the game for me. the only problem I had with it was that after I beat it, my save file went wacky and set me back to the fight with Joker in the steel mill, but whatever, I wanted to explore more of Arkham City anyway. And speaking of Arkham, it is a well built, creatively textured gothic masterpiece. It's riddled (no pun intended) with secrets, awsome locations,  Azrial (that armored, hooded guy,[I recognized him from the outfit. I'm not spoiling anything.]), side quests, and so much more. It feels veeeery atmospherical, and while it may be better to refer to it as "Arkham Town" it is still very large. Oh yeah, and it's main character is Batman.... enough said.All of what other people say aside, wether good or bad, this is a good game.10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Batman: Arkham City is the follow up to the mega-success Batman: Arkham Asylum. It features the same free-flow combat, with even more bat-gadgets for your goon-beating pleasure and a sprawling open city scape for you to grapple and glide your way across. This is also Mark Hamill's final performance as the Joker, Mark having stated the only way he will ever come back to voice Joker is if someone makes an animated version of The Killing Joke comic book arc. In addition to having even more options while playing as Batman, the game also lets you play as other Gotham city heroes Catwoman, Robin, and Nightwing, with their own distinct animations and move sets.I need to mention though, that while Batman: Arkham Asylum had typical comic book problems with portrayal of Harle Quinn and Poison Ivy as sex objects, Arkham City offended my wife and I a lot more with the opening sequence. You begin as Catwoman and have to fight a group of thugs while trying to steal something, but unlike the random threats to simply beat and kill the player that Batman receives, Catwoman is treated to her own taunts that include ra pe threats. There is no ra pe in the game as far as I'm aware, but just the suggestion of it really broke my immersion in the game world and made my wife refuse to play it. Batman exists as a very unique property in that he has been portrayed in very dark and gritty ways (Frank Miller's The Dark Knight), but also as extreme camp with jovial and silly aspects (Adam West live TV show). Even if you pretend the live action show never existed, the animated series (which shared voice actors with this game) was still targetted at children and is in the mind of many the iconic and definitive Batman. It just wasn't necessary to include ra pe threats, we already knew these were bad men we were beating up, and dark for the sake of dark is not a good thing. Frank Miller's exploration of the darker side of Batman was also about dealing with getting old, too old to be fighting punks in the street and super-criminals, too old to continue to let Joker get away with with murder sprees. The Dark Knight comics had more to say than just "this is what Batman with even more violence is like".Aside from this (not minor, you play as her more than once) issue with the game, though, the rest is competently executed. The combat is smooth and satisfying, and the difficulty was cranked up a bit since Asylum, especially on the harder settings. There is a LOT of game here for you to discover, with side-objectives such as tracking Zaz by listening to him talk about his origin, and an actual fight with The Riddler if you find all his trophies this time around. I dare say if not for the ra pe threats I would easily recommend this game to anyone, but honestly Batman: Arkham Asylum is all you really need. This game does not offer enough improvement over Asylum to be the definitive game in the series, but if you loved Asylum and want more Batman, Arkham City is mechanically a great game. I do recommend it, because to not do so would be a case of throwing the baby away with the bath water.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
												As the follow up to Arkham Asylum there was a lot of expectations for Arkham City, and thankfully the game lives up to just about everything one could expect from a sequel, adding in new features while keeping the same basic design unchanged.In Arkham City you play as The Batman who as Bruce Wayne is captured and thrown into Arkham City, a city that has been turned into a prison to house all the supervillains and thugs of Gotham, by Hugo Strange who knows Bruce is Batman and wishes to rid the world of him once and for all. It is not long however before he breaks free and gathers his costume, becoming Batman and ready to get to the bottom of what is going on.Along the way Batman meets a bevy of supervillains, from Two-Face to Penguin to Joker and more, all seemingly at a war with each other within the city and like always it is up to Batman to stop them all, this gives reason for Batman to at times work with some villains for the greater good, least till someones back is turned.Arkham City plays, for the most part, just like Arkham Asylum but with more gadgets, moves, and now a big open city to run around in, making it much larger in pretty much every way it could be as well as letting you play as Catwoman in the open city, and Robin as well as Nightwing in the Riddler challenge rooms, each with their own medals and achievements to earn.Combine that with all the downloadable content such as the mini campaign, bonus maps, and all the skins and you got yourself an amazing package with hours on hours of great gameplay that builds on everything Asylum started. I have very few complaints against this game, noticeable ones being that even though there are more Riddler objects to collect, over four hundred in fact, it is one aspect where more content does not always mean better content, but it is a very small complaint to an otherwise fantastic game, if you loved Arkham Asylum there is a very good chance you will adore this game as well.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												Batman Arkham City to me was the best video game released during the 7th console generation (2005-2014). Where ever you go trying to do the main story, Arkham City leads you off the trail to do side missions, investigate puzzles and beat the tar out of thugs. You can do various objectives in different order, it's non-linear. Unfortunately you can't solve every Riddler puzzle until you get the last equipment including the line launcher and freeze blast, but don't get hung up on that. I love being able to fly around Gotham with the grapnel boost, following custom way points or deviating from them to spontaneously do something else without getting lost. Top notch voice acting for Batman, Joker and Harley. The Batman villain roster is impressive. I didn't think much of Batman Arkham Asylum, the claustrophobic setting was limited, but was consistent to the story at least.  It's the perfect sequel. Newgame+ and the hard difficulty proves replay ability. The point in the story where Batman is forced to complete the demon trials was where I became the most engaged.If you grew up watching the Tim Burtom Batman movies, including Forever and the Warner Brother animated series, you gotta play this. It's the best representation of Batman in a video game.5/5Here is a list of my favorite games released during the 7th generation of consoles. Honorable mentions to Dead Rising 2 Off The Record, Skyrim, Portal 2 , Call Of Duty Black Ops and Super Mario Galaxy. 1. Batman Arkham City (Best flow of navigation and mission activity)2. Fallout New Vegas (Balances FO3 for more challenge and variety) 3. Bioshock 1 (Defines FPS 1P)4. Call Of Duty 4 (Defines FPS Multiplayer)5. Super Smash Brothers Brawl (Reason to get a Wii)

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												What can I say that hasn't already been said about this awesome game? You're Batman, Batman! And not only do you play as Batman, but you feel like Batman. Whether leaping from the shadows to takedown your enemies or gliding over the rooftops no other game (besides Arkham Asylum) makes you feel quite like the Caped Crusader.If you liked Arkham Asylum, you're in for a treat. Everything is bigger, and badder. Combat is more intense, and it's a blast to glide through the enormous Arkham City. While Arkham City is a monumental achievement for games of this nature, there are a few caveats. As an open world game, players are given the option to explore and complete side missions at their leisure. While this can be fun, the side missions are repetitive, and largely irrelevant to overall plot. To a completionist, this can grind the story to a halt. I would advise going straight for each main story objective before attempting any secondary missions, as the story is fast-paced and worth experiencing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												Going into this game after playing Asylum, I honestly didn't really know how Arkham City could be better (except the boss fights). But it certainly showed me how- it expands massively on Asylum, building on everything done right in it like a good sequel should. The gameplay is even better, with more gadgets and special moves (even the boss fights were improved, although still not perfect (except the Mr Freeze one; that was just plain awesome!)). I also loved playing as Catwoman. There's also way more content in this, with over 10 side missions, over 400 Riddler trophies to collect, New Game +, Harley Quinn's revenge and all the Challenge maps. With it comes the kinda small, but amazingly detailed open world of Arkham City with tonnes of Easter Eggs to explore. The voice acting is still of film quality and the graphics are awesome. The story may feel a bit jumpy and messy at times, and I didn't think Hugo Strange was that good of a villain (mainly because he has soooooo many opportunities to kill Batman practically gift-wrapped for him and he doesn't take advantage of a single one), but the story was still very enjoyable, particularly the beginning and the ending. Overall, Arkham City is one of the best games I've ever played and is by far the best superhero game ever. 10/10

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												Possibly the greatest action adventure game of this (past) generation. That generic genre descriptor really does apply for all the Arkham games though: there’s a lot of action, and you constantly feel like you’re on an adventure. Rocksteady capitalizes on the foundations of Asylum and takes the series along for a ride on the open-world bandwagon; however, they do so in a way that makes their AAA competitors simply look dull and slow. There’s a great feeling of speed and environmental mastery as you use your grapple and cape, upgraded here as a slingshot mechanism that hurls you into the air before bobbing down to maintain lift. Gadgets are now incorporated into your combat repetoire; A-list villains are actually given their due with some impressive boss encounters; the Catwoman chapter is short but immensely fun; environmental puzzles are more complex while the Riddler challenges are compulsively fun to track down and complete. You want to know how to make your collectathon mini games fun? Make them inherently fun, not because they reward a shiny or an achievement or feed your OCD (although all those are legit reasons). 'City' is packed with fun stuff to do.There’s just more of Arkham here: more characters, an expanded moveset, bigger and more diverse environments, more DC universe shoutouts and fanbait (the terrible Harley Quinn DLC is one such tease). It’s the ‘Batman Returns’ of the franchise: a louder and campier sequel that raises the fun quotient significantly, even if it comes at the cost of some narrative and design tightness.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2014
												Overall Rating: 10.0RPG/Action: AAAIf you have played other Batman games and followed the comics you will agree that Batman returns garbed in a modern, truly intimidating black and grey combat suit. Arkham city provides the ultimate playground to test Wayne Industries latest gadgets with it's distinctive towers, buildings and ruins.You are quickly thrown into the storyline as you first play Catwoman and learn the basics to fighting. You are given freedom to choose when to fight, what side-quests to take up or you could just complete the main storyline while still being able to go back at any time to complete the other stories. Batman AC is a power trip unlocking one gadget which you use both in and out of combat. The controls are very fluid and easy to use. The gadgets you use are very realistic and convincing.If you enjoy a challenge you will not be disappointed. Riddler has left plenty of trophies in difficult locations to get to. If that's not enough you will always find a challenge in New Game+ mode where you rely on your own intuition in combat to counter-attack.I found no bugs when playing this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Taking to the roof-tops as The Dark Knight in this game is a surprising delight. Gliding through the skies to swoop down on gangs of thugs, solving some of the many side missions, or just playing the actual story campaign - whatever your preference this game will most likely satisfy it (unless you want to be tooling around in a Batmobile, but I'll get to that in a sec)The combat is well executed and in the style we have come to expect as a result of the Chris Nolan movies and, whilst some may find it repetitive, it has the option of being a straight-up slug fest or a combination of well timed moves. The general opponents range from unarmed thugs to snipers, shield carriers and some in body armour - each of which requires a slightly different approach.The open-world format gives you the freedom to do things in your own time, breaking up the story with numerous side missions and a staggering number of "collectibles" so even when the story is finished there is still plenty to do in Arkham City.About the aforementioned Batmobile : The close confines and ruined conditions in Arkham City really don't lend themselves to using a vehicle so to be honest it's really not a piece of Lore that I missed. The combination of Gliding and grapple assisted parkour are more than capable of getting you anywhere in the map in pretty good time.The characterisations are perfect (although this is sadly the last time Mark Hamill will be voicing the Joker) and the scripting is well enough written to let the voice talent really shine. The animations are smooth and fluid, even in the midst of combat with multiple opponents.As a player, the only thing I'd suggest is that you get a controller for this game, much as I prefer Keyboard and Mouse it is better suited to a handset.Overall, I'd say that this was definitely one of my better purchases - but don't take my word for it, get your hands on a copy and see for yourself.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												If you told me 5+ years ago that a lesser-known studio under a massive publisher is making a triple-A comicbook hero game adaptation, I'd be a cynic.2011, Batman:Arkham City was released, the sequel to the acclaimed Batman:Arkham Asylum developed by Rocksteady studios. While AA managed to exceed the expectations of cynics like me, being a really polished and solid game in itself, AC rose way up higher, being one of the most amazing games in recent memory. Or at least for me personally.Arkham City, in essence, is Arkham Asylum with a massive open world, slightly better animations (e.g. no more cretins holding their heads when they're defeated, regardless of where you actually hurt them) and more polishes around its edges, It manages to keep the fantastic, fluid combat, excellent level design, atmospheric setting, incredible narrative and oh-so perfect voice acting. So much of this review has been said in my previous review of AA.Combat in AC is satisfying as ever, but now with more awesome animations and more importantly, more gadgets and the introduction of freeflow gadgets. Freeflow gadgets basically allows you to incorporate your gadgets mid-combat more seamlessly which makes the variety of combos way more exciting. With the introduction of more gadgets comes more approaches in combat which plays a huge part in AC and is without a doubt, extremely fun to experiment with different gadgets in different combat situations.Boss fights in AC are a major improvement from its predecessor. Each boss is almost perfectly depicted as their comicbook counterpart not only in terms of presentation, but also their method of combat. Bottom line, boss encounters are extremely fun and at times challenging, although some bosses rely alot on button mashing.Stealth in AA relied a lot on the game's excellent level design and combat/gadgetry to a certain extent (ignoring the clumsy AI). AC manages to yet again, excel in the series' stealth aspect with even more incredible level designs and as said earlier, more gadgets which also are incorporable for stealthy approaches. If you are a fan of stealth games, I recommend playing the game on hard because more often than not when you have a multiple gun-armed men encounter, you are forced to approach them extremely stealthily as guns kill you fairly quick. IMO, stealth on hard in Arkham City is feels just as or even more rewarding than combat.Talking about stealth, it is almost unignorable to talk about the clumsy AI. Whilst enemies patroling/covering area are sometimes very tight and challenging, it sometimes fails to notice you in obvious positions of their line of sight and I am also convinced they never look behind or above them (unless theyre using thermo). This most definitely needs work.Presentation of the game is without a doubt a massive eye (and ear) candy. The world is grim, dark and quite large, managing to retain the gothic atmosphere of AA once again. AC manages to have an ungeneric world due to being able to not to use generic buildings or placing alike buildings very close to each other. Rocksteady manages to put a lot of easter eggs in the world pretty well with references to the comic book stories in the form of riddler challenges and sidemissions. There's one easter egg where if you go to crime alley within the game which really generates a ton of feels (personally), if you are getting this game, do not forget to check it out, this shows the amount of effort the devs put into the game.The music is not only extremely good as well, but its placement within each scene is perfection, definitely worth checking out the soundtrack itself. Voice acting, oh my god, Mark Hamill nails it down the ground yet again with his portrayal of Joker, alongside Kevin Conroy, Tara Strong and every other villain as well being quite possibly one of the best voice-acting crew in the history of gaming. This helps build a spot-on portrayal of each character which is already presented extremely well with each of their character models and great costume design.Story-wise, a lot of reviews I've read mentions that AC isn's as strong as AA but I say otherwise. While I do agree some villains felt rather shoehorned into the story after much thought, my initial playthrough almost ignores this fact due to the game's undeniably spectacular narrative. AC's narrative played out extremely well and felt very much alike a blockbuster movie (perhaps maybe even comparable to Nolan's trilogy) as the scale felt grand as compared to AA. Overall, I felt that the story was pretty much one of the key selling points of the game (again, personally).Well that pretty much covers all my opinions of the game. I admit I do have abit of a Batboner (ok not that small after all..) but whether or not you are a huge fan of Batman should not be taken to consideration if you are deciding whether or not to buy this game because personally, Batman:Arkham City is one of the best games in recent memory. Treat yourselves well by buying yourselves this incredible piece of entertainment.Conclusion; a fantastic game with incredibly satisfying combat, rewardingly challenging stealth, a relatively large world with excellent world and level design, great atmosphere of grim ( and yet, epicness of being the caped crusader), perfect sound direction and composition, unforgettable characters with their spot-on impressions/models/costume and triple-A voice acting, great story and a wonderful narrative. Yes, this game is so good i ran out of unique positive reinforcement adjectives to use. 9.5/10 - Brings me wonders how TESV got goty instead of this.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												If you played Arkham Asylum before this you will probably be a little disappointed.Arkham City's devs chose the safe route and basically recycled everything from Arkham Asylum and put it in this one.They polished the combat/graphics a little but there's not a huge difference.The game is based in a pretty big city where they tried to implement the ''open world'' feel but I think they didn't really succed.The optional quests are not that interesting and most likely you will ignore them.The city has a lot of secrets and it is fun to explore it,the only problem is the lack of optional quests.With a city like this they could add so many interesting quests but they focused more on the main campaign while still building this amazing city. The plot in this game is a bit weaker than in the previous game in my opinion but it is still worth following.I feel like the atmosphere of the game is a bit off,while in the first it is top notch.As I said before,the combat is almost the same with little improvement.Arkham City is definitely a great game but it is sad that they didn't take any risks and basically took Asylum,polished it a little and added another plot to it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 22, 2013
												*SPOILERS!*In many ways not as good as Arkham Asylum. The More open world can become confusing but also seem a little empty as Batman spends most of his time jumpting from rooftop to rooftop or gliding about the city. On the other hand the additional characters gadgets and abilities give this game an edge in that department.The plot is well done, though within the actual fram of the game missies out the history of Arkham City in any detail (though some can be found secondarily throughout the game) and it leaves it feeling a little detatched from the first.Catwoman is an interesting addition and incredibly well done, though my own feeling the switch between characters ended up feeling a little jarring and that Catwoman would have been better left as a complete expanson, as her story is minimal.*SPOILERS END!*On the whole, if you want a good Batman game, get the first one. if you've played that, get this, but be prepared to dedicate some time to it and not expect the same feeling the first gave so many.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												Arkham City is a hard game to recommend or pan. There is nothing glaringly wrong with it but it feels like a step down from Asylum. City lacks any truly memorable sequences, like the original’s Killer Croc battle or the Scarecrow bits. Asylum also had a more cohesive plot. Plus, while I like playing with Catwoman, I don’t like being forced to switch between her and Batman during the campaign. It just makes things feel disjointed.That being said it looks good, runs great, and there are a ton of gadgets to play with. If you liked Asylum then this offers some more of that gameplay. If you pick it up for $5 or so you’ll probably be satisfied with it, but you won’t love it.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												The Bat!  What can I say?  If you've played Arkham Asylum, this is a no-brainer and a natural progression of the same story.  The game is large, graphically pleasing, the combat is exquisite.  There is no unpolished aspect to this game, as far as I am aware.  It was made solid.  If you want to be a vigilante dressed like a bat...this is where it's at.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												Batman: Arkham City is the sequel of Batman: Arkham Asylum and retains the latter's action and stealth game nature. The main story takes place after the events of the first game, with Quincy Sharp (now mayor of Gotham City) building a special facility to contain criminals and super villains upon a derelict part of Gotham (the titular Arkham City) and letting professor Hugo Strange manage the inmates and the facility's security. Batman decides to enter the area to better investigate Strange's true goals and face the many elements of his rogue gallery inside (with the Joker being the primary threat).Gameplay-wise, Arkham City improves the main formula of Arkham Asylum in basically everything. First of all, the game is now an open world experience, with Batman being able to roam freely through a section of Gotham City, with few indoor areas, which serve as "dungeons" of some sort. The huge map is inhabitated by respawning enemies and pletora of collectables and other assignments you can complete (but see below). On top of the gadgets Batman could use in the first game, Arkham City features a new set of gimmicks, which, as always, can be used both for exploration or in combat (for instance, you'll be given an electrical charges generator and freezing granades). There are also new combat moves available for Batman. While the main core of the hand-to-hand combat remains basically the same, now your enemies can use several picked up objects to make your life harder (thugs will deploy shields that require a special move to overcome and reinforced armors that'll make them immune to everything except to beatdowns). The same can be said for the stealth sequences: now the enemies'll be able to flush you out with granades and destroy your vintage points and spot some new nasty equipment (some thugs'll carry portable scramblers which'll disrupt your detective vision or special googles to spot you on vintage points). Althought Arkham City doesn't offer different levels of difficulty, upon beating the main story you'll be able to select a new Game Plus mode: it'll allow you to keep your current unlocks against advanced enemies (and reinforced bosses) up from the very beginning.Aside from the main story missions, you can also go after several side quests. The Riddler's challenges return, and so do his trophies and riddles, with now the additional task to save hostages from deadly trap rooms once you completed enough tasks. The other side missions revolve around other important characters and Batman trying to find them to stop their agenda or to ally with them (for example a series of quests revolves around Batman trying to stop Deadshot from killing various political prisoners). It's worth mentioning however that the side missions design could had used a bit more work and trying to follow each from one step to another (especially while dealing with the main story too) is often far too confusing or frustrating (namely, several Riddler's trophies require absolute controls precision to be achieved, and triggering the next step of nearly all the side stories require scouting the huge game's map for hard to find bodies and such).Other side activities include the combat and predator challenges (which require you to achieve the highest score possibly in selected maps by realizing the best flawless combos or offing the enemies in specific ways, respectively), which can be also cleared with different characters, and concept arts and character trophies to unlock.I'd also like to notice how, as some kind of big Batman fan, Arkham City really blowed up my expectation. Not only the main story of the game manages to put together several important Batman antagonists (Penguin, Two-Face, Joker, Mr. Freeze, ...) in the same place, but it also manages to sound incredibly convicing: it's one of my favorite tale from the Batman universe ever. Add to that the general great focus the developers put into the characters' and levels' design and the clever easter eggs.The Catwoman DLC is included in every new copy of Arkham City and allows you to play as Catwoman in few mission which are fullu integrated into Batman's own story (as well as being able to go on free roam with her after the end of it). Catwoman spots different gadgets than Batman and is generally a more fragile character, but she makes up for it with a more agile style of fighting (she can walk on ceilings during predator sequences and pick up unexpected enemies from there, for instance). She can also be used as a character in challenge mode.The Harley Quinn's Revenge DLC is the first and only story-driven DLC for Arkham City. It takes place after the main campaign and inside the Steel Mill level, albeit with several new decorations. You play the first part of the DLC as Robin, while the second one sees you taking control of Batman once again. Despite this, the whole package can be seen as extremely disappointing (the whole main story of it takes place in a reskin of an area you already visited and pits you against reskinned enemies, while there aren't really much elements to advance the general plot of the Arkham universe).All the other DLCs for Arkham City are dedicated to the challenge mode, either introducing new characters for both combat and predator challenges (like Robin and Nightwing) or new maps. They also include several skins for the various characters.To this day I consider Batman: Arkham City one of the greatest jump in quality for a videogame sequel I've ever played, one of the best pieces of Batman media I've ever experienced and one of the finest action game I've ever enjoyed.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
Batman: Arkham City features perfect balance between open-world game and more focused Metrovania-style structure; the combat is refined even further while stealth sections are still challenging and engaging as its predecessor. Moreover, while some may miss the more Metroid-style approach of the last game, Arkham City at least makes sure that its open world is not a gimmick: traversing the map is a breeze (both literally and figuratively), while the side missions and amount of things to do are great both in quantity and quality. Last but not least, Arkham City shows how to do a strikingly impressive storytelling in a game form, another quality which it thankfully inherits from its esteemed predecessor.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												Hey guys it has been a while now since Origins came out and I thought as BIIIG Fan I need to speak a few words. This game is worth buying but not at top mark value. The amount of bugs I encountered and continue to encounter while playing origins holds me back from really enjoying the game and getting into being the bat. If I hadnt been so hungry for the collectors edition and statue on console I would've waited for a sale. That aside, it is a great game with some pretty great moments. When compared to the other two batman games I will say this, it does fall short in some areas, but also makes changes in others.  The combat is MUCH more challenging in this one . However, the combat falls prey to the ever so counter intuitive design pitfalls and glitches . Many times I find myself frustrated with larger groups of enemies instead of excited as I was in the previous batman games. In the first two games when you see a large group of enemies you get a sense of challenge and a thrill to get that highscore. In this it becomes more of a pain in the butt 9 times out of 10. It does challenge you but when you fail it doesnt feel like it was your mistake it feels like somehting happened that shouldnt have. Not saying thats the case 100% of the time but none the less my point still stands.All in all a great game but, it makes appreciate the first two and Rock Steady all the more. I see DLC coming out as well and I am very concerned and warn all of you about the fact they have not polished up all glitches in the current main game they have sold us. They ARE in deed working on it and ever 2-4 weeks ive seen a significant patch solving many issues and improving the experience. Well besides the obvious pros and cons that was my feelings, review and experience with Batman Arkham Origins. Hope you have fun with it ! I know I did ;)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												Pros:- An open world that's not too big, but not too small- Large cast of characters and villains- Improved, tighter combat controls- Well crafted story from Batman veteran Paul Dini- Varied enemy types keep you on your toes in both open combat and stealth/predator sections- Good amount of gadgets and upgrades- Many challenge maps with four playable characters (Batman, Robin, Catwoman, and Nightwing)Cons:- Riddler overkill- All but two or three side missions are underwhelming/boring- Traversing the map can be tedious- Technical issues- Horrible looking cutscenes- Catwoman sub-plot is there for gimmickThe Bottom Line:Anyone progressing from Arkham Asylum to Arkham City will notice a significant improvement over the previous title. Better combat, an open world with interior and exterior locations, and a large cast of characters will all be welcome additions and make the game feel superior to the franchise debut.However, Arkham City isn't without flaws. The biggest in my book is the absolute over-saturation/overkill of Riddler junk. There are over 400 trophies, riddles, and destructible objects all over the place and with their integration into a side-mission you almost feel obligated to track them all down - something that becomes even MORE of a pain when you come across numerous ones you can't access yet due to your progress in the main story (needing certain gadgets). This annoyance is multiplied then when you have to come back to it later but to do so requires a lengthy journey to their location hampered by areas that were accessible but no longer (forcing you to find a different path) and/or the simple time it takes to get to them.Arkham City is also still hindered by bugs/glitches and crashes even four years after its intial release, and cutscenes are absolutely terrible looking as they're done at a resolution and detail level that shouldn't even have been the "norm" for 2011 consoles. Beyond these things there are plenty of other smaller annoyances that, while not severly diminishing the overall experience, certainly hold the game back from being almost perfect.In the end, Arkham City is a fantastic game that every Batman fan has to play. Easily the second best game in the entire franchise it's not one to glance over because of its age.8 Joker Balloons out of 10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												***SPOILER FREE REVIEW OF BATMAN ARKHAM CITY***	1/05/15So after spending 17-18 hours with Batman Arkham City and completing the main story, I must say that I am blown away. This game is absolutely unbelievable! The story is so rich and motivates you to keep pushing in the story, the gameplay really makes you feel like Batman, and the amount of things to do in the game is staggering. I still have not completed the Catwomen storyline or any other of the DLC included in the GOTY edition of the game (however, I plan on continuing to play Batman Arkham City so be on the lookout for updated reviews regarding the DLC component of this game). This is strictly a review of the base game of Batman Arkham.Story: 9.5 out of 10	After completing the main story of the game, my jaw dropped. Everything that led up to the end, the struggle, all concluded in an epic finale that I will not forget for a long time. I am not going to discuss the story for fear of spoiling something, but I must say that the story alone is worth the price of admission. The written script is excellent, and Batman is confronted by a numerous amount of famous rivals. Overall, I enjoyed every minute of the story; sequences with the Joker (just like Arkham Asylum) were definitely a highlight in my book.Graphics: 9.5 out of 10The graphics in Batman Arkham City are excellent. The atmosphere is dark, tense, rich with detail, and a feeling of dread overcomes me everytime I play the game (in a good way). However, this does not last long due to the fact that you are Batman! The environments vary greatly in Arkham City. There is a steel mill taken over by the Joker and turned into something resembling a circus act, a police department taken over by Mr. Freeze, a museum occupied by the Penguin, etc. The character models and environment are polished, filled with detail, and provide for a rich Batman experience.- The only thing I disliked about Batman Arkham City is that the game sometimes stutters when gliding over Arkham City which I imagine has to be streaming issue (this is a well known issue among many PC gamers). However, other than this issue, the game runs great on my R9 290. Maxed out, I average about 160+ fps indoors and 90-120 fps outdoors. Do not let the stuttering issue prevent you from playing this masterpiece - you honestly get use to it. A work-around that I use to fix some stuttering issues is to pan the camera 360 degrees around Batman a few times - this really helps!Gameplay: 9.8 out of 10Just like Batman Arkham Asylum, Batman Arkham City is broken into a few gameplay scenarios: stealth, combat, and exploration - Riddler trophies/challenges. Just like the previous game, stealth is one of my favorite parts of this game. As the predator, you hunt down one thug at a time using different tactics such as hanging from gargoyles and performing inverted takedowns, and using a range of different gadgets at your disposal. Overall, the amount of options you have when approaching these scenarios is amazing, and I can totally see myself going back and perfecting my skills in the challenge mode.Combat is much more dynamic and free-flowing than in Arkham Asylum. You can now counter multiple enemies at one time, there are many more enemy types, and there are now more gadgets that are hotkeyed to use to string together combos. The combat in Batman Arkham City can be as in-depth as you want it to be. Overall, the stealth and combat is turned up to eleven as compared to Arkham Asylum, and the game really makes you feel like Batman!The game also comes with 12 side missions (I believe that is right?) that has Batman fighting, tracking down, and helping some classic rivals. Challenge rooms return letting you refine your skills in stealth and combat. Also, with the GOTY edition of the game, Catwomen becomes a playable character whose story becomes intertwined with Batman's. Catwomen controls greatly, her fighting style differs greatly from Batman's, and it is a joy playing as her (I personally prefer playing as Batman, but playing as Catwoman is a nice change of pace.)Lastly, just like Arkham Asylum, Riddler trophies/challenges return in abundance (however this is not a bad thing). Spread out among Arkham City are 440 Riddler trophies/challenges (I have only collected 170). These trophies/challenges really make you scavenge the environment, and provide many more hours of enjoyment to an already fantastic game.Audio: 10 out of 10	It should come as no surprise that the audio in this game is stellar. The voice acting is the best that I have ever heard in a game; the musical score bring out the perfect emotions at the perfect times. Gadgets sound just as they should, and gliding around Arkham City with wind flowing underneath Batman's wingsuit is excellent. I could not wish for anything better in the audio department of this game!Conclusion:	I LOVED BATMAN ARKHAM CITY! It is the reason I love playing video games, and why I continue to do so. This game provides a medium to play as Batman, and should not be passed up on. This game does everything right, and is one of the best games that I have played in the past five years (I do not say that lightly). It improves so much upon the great core provided by Batman Arkham Asylum, yet provides so much innovation to keep the game fresh and rewarding. Do yourself a favor, you owe it to yourself to play Batman Arkham City.Batman Arkham  City		9.7 out of 10BUY THIS GAME!!!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												Batman: Arkham Asylum was a surprise hit in 2009, blowing away all expectations and grabbing several Game of the Year awards, against heavy hitters like Uncharted 2. It was an excellent game, however it had a few issues, such as glitchy character models and repeated boss fights. Two years later, Arkham City came out. Oh boy. Batman; Arkham City is an improvement in every single way and form, and is a testament to the saying that "Bigger is better." As expected, the voice acting is top notch, with Mark Hamill and Kevin Conroy delivering excellent performances as Joker and Batman, respectively. The story is leagues better than the original, with an ending so emotionally fulfilling that it left me stunned when I first beat this game. The graphics have aged, yet still help maintain the dark, damp style of Arkham City. The gameplay is the simple "tap x to punch, y to counter". Overall, there is so much bang for your buck here. From the side quests featuring a wide range of villains, to the story line that can be truly considered a comic book worthy story, you're getting you're money's worth. Graphics: 7/10Gameplay: 8/10Story:9/10Overall:9/10 - Must buy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												Going into this game after playing Asylum, I honestly didn't really know how Arkham City could be better (except the boss fights). But it certainly showed me how- it expands massively on Asylum, building on everything done right in it like a good sequel should. The gameplay is even better, with more gadgets and special moves (even the boss fights were improved, although still not perfect (except the Mr Freeze one; that was just plain awesome!)). I also loved playing as Catwoman. There's also way more content in this, with over 10 side missions, over 400 Riddler trophies to collect, New Game +, Harley Quinn's revenge and all the Challenge maps. With it comes the kinda small, but amazingly detailed open world of Arkham City with tonnes of Easter Eggs to explore. The voice acting is still of film quality and the graphics are awesome. The story may feel a bit jumpy and messy at times, and I didn't think Hugo Strange was that good of a villain (mainly because he has soooooo many opportunities to kill Batman practically gift-wrapped for him and he doesn't take advantage of a single one), but the story was still very enjoyable, particularly the beginning and the ending. Overall, Arkham City is one of the best games I've ever played and is by far the best superhero game ever. 10/10

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												The best in the sereis This is the secound instalment in the Arkham sereies, and this is truely the most eventfull of the games I have palyed. The overall gameplay is like the first game in the sereis, but it have been inproved, and perfected. The fighting part of the game, is made by using the mouse to navigate whitch charecter you want to attack, you use the left mouse button to attack and the right to counter, you can also use the middle to confuse. Along the way the enemeys get harder, and get new equpment, and new tacktics must be used to deafeat them. There is also the stealth element, where Batman must take down a room with armed thugs in order to continue or save someone. Here you must plan your attacks and be paistent in order to succed. There are so many small details in this game, and I really love how many mini games and challenges, there are. You can take challenges in fighting and stealth, and use diffrent charecters such as catwomen, there is also a playable charecter in the story mode, nightwing and robin. Furthermore, in the main game Zaez is on the run, the Riddler is kisnapping people and putting up his throphies and riddles to find again. The Mad Hatter is runnig amok, and so much more. The story is the best Batman story in a long time. The story takes palce after the events of Arkham Asylum, where the Joker have become sick becouse of the titan serum he took, meanwhile Bruce Wayne is sent to the new jail city Arham City, and here we find out that Hugo Strange now knows, who Batman really is. This makes the plot more interesting, and it only get`s more tence after the Joker infects Batman with he`s blood. So now Batman needs to find a cure and defeat Hugo Strange, in order to keep he`s identety hidden. Since this is a prison city, we meet many other charecters, such as the Penguine, Mister Frezze, Solomon Grundy, Clayface and even Ras al` Ghoul. Every single charecter is well made, and really memerable. Along the way, you can also find informatiomn about the charecters, inside Arkham city, this only adds more depth to the charecters and I love it. The ending is worth talking about, and this is also the part where I talk about the DLC mission from the game, if you don`t want the ending spolied, don`t read untill you see the spoiler over part.-----------spoilers------------In this game, the Joker dies, this is a shock to anyone who played this game, and it is truely a fantastic ending. It is clear that Batman will be scared by this event, since the Joker and Batman, have a conection deep down, every fan of the seires knows about. The Joker needs Batman and the other way around, but this put the nail in the coffin and made a climactic ending, that will be remembered by me.This leads to the events after the attack on Arkham, and guees who`s gone mad? Well of couse it`s Harly Quen. Since the Joker died, she have kidnapped police officers, and turned prttey goth. We also find out that Batman have been kidnapped, and that Harly Quen thought she was pragnent with Jokers child, whitch only made her even more mad. It is up to Robin to save the day in this DLC, and it is a nice change since you have played as Batman all day in the main game. ------------spoilers over----------Overall this game is really well designed and it is a fantastic story, that have twist and turns along the way, plus fantasitc sceneory, that only will make you love the game even more, thumps up. 8 out of 10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
												I've been playing games for many years and for the most part; I'm losing my passion for them - in that, I feel that games today, just don't fulfill the promises (that I) (imagined) were made years ago.With that being said, there are few games that truly hold my interest continuously until the game is complete.Batman: Arkham City is one of those games however (along with Arkham Asylum - but I consider them merely the same game in an ongoing saga - so far).Firstly, the game is incredibly polished in my opinion.Graphics, animation, sound, gameplay, story and the various gameplay mechanics.The story is a strong Batman style story and while I wouldn't say there are many twists or elaborate depth to it - it IS very involving and will keep you interested.The game mechanics, from travelling around the city via Cape-Glide, Grappel Gun, Zip-Line to the Combat is where the game shines.Often, in games, you are meant to be some Expert or whatever... Yet, from not knowing the controls very well, you'll find yourself not being very "expert" at all.In Batman, the controls are so simple, that it's easy to feel like Batman.Combat is simply a matter of positioning (moving about or jumping about) and a single button for "attack" and a single button for "counter-attack" (though there are also buttons for your gadgets and abilities that you can use.Pretty much you merely press the button once for an attack, and when it lands, press the button again, for a second attack and so on and so on - in this way, you can build up huge combos.The Counter-Attack button is used when you are going to be attacked by the enemy and works as a block and slight return attack.You simply point the camera in the direction you want to fight.. And then press the button.The combat animations and how it works are superb and never does it feel overly difficult - even when you get beat up, you are totally aware that you made a mistake and messed up the timing or used a button's ability poorly.Building up combos is how you regenerate health at the end of each battle - which I find works well - rather than finding magical health items around the map.There is an element of stealth too. You don't have to just jump into the fray and start using combos - especially since sometimes there are enemies with guns. However a skilled gadgeteer... Will be able to be in the fray, using his positioning and gadgets at just the right moment to deal with these armed thugs. But stealth is actively encouraged too. From swooping in and grappelling out - dealing with foes one at a time.There is so many good things to say about this game.. And, in my opinion, so few things to complain about.I would rate the game as outstanding and completely worth owning. Regardless of price - get the game as soon as you can afford to (though I'd start with Arkham Asylum - which DOES lack a few of the welcome improvements from Arkham City - but the story is a continuation and it's worth experiencing the entire saga).

content:
Posted: January 1
												I think i should get this out there. I haven't played the other games in this series with this game being my first so my opinion will completely be based on my experiences with this game by itself. If your hoping for a comparison between this game and the other you should look at the other reviews. If you don't want to hear the full review but just my thoughts just scroll to the bottom. Ok now let get started with the review ^-^.  The Long Review StealthAs a fan of stealth games, this game does have some elements of stealth to it, with specific segments dedicated to it. These segment provide a decent amount of stealth where you are required to work yourself around a room to take down a number of enemies which are all armed making them difficult to handle head on. Other elements are added on later in the game to make this more difficult so there is some need to vary your strategy. During these moments, you can truly feel like the dark knight as you make your way around the room taking them out one by one and making your enemies feel truly helpless or growingly paranoid.CombatThe more frequent encounters are where you're required to battle a group of enemies head on with the enemies mostly being unarmed near the beginning of the game. These battles are made interesting with the way the combat system works. The combat system is basically a combo meter that requires you to not make a mistake in a combo such as getting hit, countering early or missing a punch. All you have to do is keeping pressing the punch button (Right click for me) while pointing in the direction of your target (wasd for me). Later in the game you will be given the choice to buy a somewhat finisher that can be used at a high combo (12 hits generally). Also, the variety of weapons you will have to deal with will require you to strategies a bit making the experience a bit different each time.GadgetsNow, time for the gadgets. There is a large and healthy variety of gadgets that can be used in this game. From the classic batarang to weapons that batman made on the spot which is somewhat ridiculous but effective. These gadgets can be used to solve puzzles or the riddlers puzzles (which I'll talk about later). The gadgets are not just useful for puzzles. They can also be used in combat, helping to deal with various situations such as when your surrounded or if an enemy has a gun pointed at you. StoryFinally, the story. Without spoiling much, the story revolves mainly around the joker and another villain by the name of Strange. There are many other villains in the game such as Poison ivy, Catwomen, The Penguin and many others. You could play the entire game focused on the main story but after that there are still many other things to do so there is replayability if that's what your looking for. Besides the other Villains that can be interacted with in the game, there are also the collectables placed by The Riddler throughout the map which has it's ups and downs such as if you're trying to 100% the game.Final thoughts In my opinion, i feel that this is a great game and is something that you should definitely try playing if you're a fan of batman or you want to play a fun brawler with interesting stealth.Ques: Could you play the with little to no knowledge about Batman?Ans: You definitely can play it as the game does give you a little insight to the characters you're about to get involved with via the in game encyclopediaI'll admit the controls can feel a little clunky just due to the fact that some of the keys for some actions overlap each other eg. Running and taking cover are the same key there's a chance of doing one or the other when near a corner.There are other examples of clunky control but overall i think Batman Arkham City is a great open world game.I definitely recommend it <3

content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
												The most highly-marketed feature of Batman: Arkham City is the replacement of the small, confined corridors of the previous game with an open-world setting. Ironically, this feature is also the worst aspect of the game, and one of the primary reasons that the sequel doesn't quite live up to Rocksteady Studios' previous effort.One year after the events of Arkham Asylum, Bruce Wayne is abducted and imprisoned within Arkham City, a controversial prison within a walled-off section of Gotham overseen by private security forces led by a mysterious villain named Hugo Strange, who makes it clear up-front that he knows Batman's true identity. It's almost comical how quickly things escalate, with Bruce Wayne being captured by the Penguin literally at the front gate of Arkham City. Weirdly enough, just about none of the game has anything to do with the initial problem of Batman's identity being revealed, and Hugo Strange himself only really comes into villainhood in the game's final act, with the majority of the game's runtime dedicated to the Joker - an infinitely more interesting villain that any of Batman's other enemies, most of whom are regulated to minor, almost tangential missions early in the game. In fact, a lot of the plot is actually just tangents, with the purpose of leading the player on a merry tour of the big, gloomy world that's been constructed. It's lacking in focus for the most part, with one very specific MacGuffin loosely tying everything together. For sure, the villains are still just as good as they were in Arkham Asylum, and there are certainly more of them, but most of them are just minor acknowledgements of actual character, instead just displaying the characteristics for which they are most well-known. To make things even more dire on the story front, the game of the year edition incorporates the normally separate Catwoman DLC into the main story, spreading the missions throughout the game's length, serving only to completely break the flow of both the game and the DLC.While the story's a bit of a mess this time around, the gameplay is pretty spot-on. Most of the new stuff that's been introduced is simple and easy to use, and in general the combat just flows a lot better, making for an even more delightful experience in kicking impoverished homeless people in the teeth. Even better, efforts have actually been made to stop Batman from being incredibly overpowered in stealth segments, with new gear that scrambles x-ray vision and sees long distances, even in the dark. The combat is still a lot more fun - it's fast and surprisingly tactical considering the entire premise is punching large quantities of men. The introductions of new enemy types has done a lot to keep it all fresh and challenging, especially in massive brawls involving weapons and the classic giant mutants from the original game. In short, while Arkham City is quite a bit worse on the story front, and it lacks the tight focus and thick atmosphere that shrouded Arkham Asylum, though it makes up some lost ground with myriad gameplay and control improvements, coming together as a finished product that's overall worse than it's predecessor, but still a lot of fun.My review of Batman: Arkham Asylum

content:
Posted: July 18, 2013
												[9/10] – Quite possibly the best super hero game I’ve ever played, and for very good reasons. This title (as well as the prequel) is a masterfully crafted piece of art. It’s dark, mature and even scary at times. It is the exact incarnation of awesome that I always wanted out of this genre of game. If you ever thought for a second that you wouldn’t play this because it’s a super hero game, then I invite you to contemplate how much♥♥♥♥♥kicking, batarang throwing boss’ism you are missing. It’s very well-paced, with fantastic voice acting, an incredibly detailed and interesting environment. There are loads to explore and do, including awesome side quests and upgrades to collect, each as rewarding as the last. It also has a deceptively intriguing story coupled with one of the best combat systems I’ve seen a very long time. You are quite literally the awesome that Batman is when you play, and quite literally missing the ♥♥♥♥ out if you’re not.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												Batman: Arkham City is a third person action adventure game developed by Rocksteady Studios in association with Warner Bros Interactive Entertainment on the Unreal Engine. It follows billionaire playboy Bruce Wayne AKA Batman after getting arrested and admitted to a city sized insane asylum dubbed "Arkham City" by an enigmatic scientist, and has to fight his way out whilst simultaneously hunting for a cure to a mysterious TITAN side-effect that threatens to infect all of Gotham.Much like the first Batman: Arkham game, Rocksteady has managed to create a player-narrative experience that feels just as grand and exciting as it was in the first game, but this time the gameplay has been properly honed and the direction now turns toward a GTA-esque city dynamic with side-missions as well as story missions.And as sequels are Rocksteady has addressed the complaints given and now I'm here to report the state of all the problems I listed in my review of Arkham Asylum, to see if they're really up to snuff and to see if this game is worth it.Let's a go!Batman's Detective Vision has been downgraded in a few ways, now it's more difficult to tell which directions enemies are facing, as well as a much murkier style that encourages the player to switch between normal vision AND detective mode. The keyboard and graphical settings are still on a different program, and now you have to specifically look for it it doesn't open on start up like before. Killer Croc does show up in this game but as a cameo so I can't really comment on it, that being said most set-pieces are well placed and exciting unlike Killer Croc's overly slow and unchallenging game of red light green light. The opening of this game gives you almost all the weapons you had originally, which is exactly right for the games pacing.The setting of this game is still atmospheric but now has a lot more character, and feels lively. The final boss with Clayface is still a little bit underwhelming but it's fun and epic and leads to the conclusion that really sells the rest of the game so I'll give it a few points for that alone, and the other bosses are also incredibly fun and much better than the first game's, requiring strategy and variety (Highlights include Ra's al Ghul and Mr Freeze.) The combat is just as solid but now it's made a little easier to perform combos and the countering system is more responsive, but there's still not auto run. The disposal of Harley Quinn in this game isn't really a factor but a similar issue arises with The Penguin who's there from the very beginning but has what seems like frankly boring final encounter before pulling the rug from under you with a surprise boss fight that is anything BUT underwhelming. The attacks from Harvey Dent similarly have nothing to do with the plot and also kind of halt progression, and if you're playing as catwomen the exact same problem is there again with Poison Ivy. The story structure is yet again somewhat repetitive but this time it just works better for whatever reason, and the stealthing is much more varied with smarter enemies who will go so far as to pay special attention to gargoyles if they see you flee to one.The logic involving Riddles is more interesting and makes me really think about my surroundings. The riddler trophies do this really interesting thing where you see a lot of them before you have the tools to get them which makes finding them more gratifying, and sometimes when you DO get them you feel like a freaking genius the first time I figured out a puzzle using the remote control batarang and conducting electricity with it I was singing my praises higher than an egotistical ballad singer.The detecive vision is darker and murkier making key things stand out more, and the normal vision world around you is vibrant and interesting to look at no matter what you're doing. The maps inside buildings are at better scale with the buildings outside them, and overall this is one of them best sequels I've ever played.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												The Definitive Batman Gaming Experience.Batman: Arkham City is a masterpiece of a game which displays multiple levels of creativity and care, allowing players to become "The Batman". As the sequel to the criticlly aclaimed Arkham Asylum, Arkham City is rich with improvements from the previous entry while also adding new additions to the series aswell. Arkham City's voice acting is top notch, with many notable cast members; such as the recognizable inclusions of Animated Series Vets: Kevin Conroy portraying the ever "cheerful" Dark Knight, and the marvelous Mark Hamil as the Joker. From the MOMENT you start this game you will not want to put it down as every second within Arkham City is rich with content which will keep you on your toes till the very end. Just about every location within the game is full of nice nods and suprises which makes the long trecs around the city even more enjoyable. The plot of Arkham City is a rollercoaster of events (and even emotions!), that allow even a newcomer to the batman universe to achieve full satisfactory from the contents of the game, while simultaneously satisfying the greatest Batman Fanatics!After you finish the game, the Concept Art gallery, and Character Trophies are some of the best way to understand how much forethought and time went into making this game, which is possibly one of the most pleasurable experiences you'll ever have with a game!(well at least while playing a superhero game).Also, Good news! This is the comeplete edition of the game (Game of the Year), and as with the GOTY edition comes all the wonderful dlc content such as Characters, Challenge Maps, and Batsuits! (But don't play Harley Quinn's Revenge till you finish the main story...spoilers inside).Overall, Batman: Arkham City is a non-stop joyride with twists and turns which will turn you, into the Hero Gotham City deserves.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												Oh Batman: Arkham City, how I love thee.  I don't even know where to begin to explain how fantastic this game is.The story in itself is good, but where the game really shines is in worldbuilding.  The titular Arkham City is probably one of my favorite locations in all of gaming.  The art style and level design just brings the superprison to life, and even the simple conversations between inmates that you can eavesdrop on make the game incredibly immersive.  That's to say nothing of the excellent use of Batman's villian cast.  To go into too much detail would spoil many sidequests, but suffice to say that all are expertly designed, in character, and brought to life by their respective voice actors/actresses (the Riddler being my personal favorite).As for gameplay, it's just as excellent as it was in Aslyum, but has been improved upon like a good sequel should.  On the combat side, you now have the ability to counter multiple enemies at once, all gadgets can be easily incorporated into combat, new special takedowns, and the animations are just as well-detailed from each punch to counter to special takedown that give the combat a finese that few games can match.  And of course, we have the inclusion of multiple playable characters this time as well, from Catwoman to Robin to Nightwing, all of whom have their own unique gadgets and takedowns that shake up the combat.  Stealth as well gets some minor improvements (the ability to quickly end silent takedowns a very welcome addition), and the new gadgets available also offer new ways to neutralize enemies.  Some now take place outdoors as well, giving you even more verticality to the encounters and more tactical approaches and considerations.And of course, we have the challenge mode carried along from Aslyum.  There are now twelve individual maps (split evenly between combat and predator missions), and a new addition: campaign modes, where you tackle three maps back-to-back with qualifers chosen by the player that can either handicap or give you a helping hand.  Unfortunately, this is where I have one big criticism for the game, as the predator missions erroneously followed in the tradition of Aslyum by requiring you to complete specific objectives to beat a level.  On top of most of these objectives being completely arbitrary, and even pointless, then just restrict the player's opportunity to experiment and serve only to make the maps repetitous.  It's a shame they went this route, because the predator encounters in the story mode are fun precisely because they don't have such arbitrary requirements.  Thankfully, the combat challenges aren't structured this way, allowing you to actually experiment with the many combat moves and not be rigidly locked into a routine, and are genuinely fun, meaning you'll want to go back and play them many times over.Tl;dr Batman: Arkham City is easily one of the best games I've played in years, and I could not recommend it highly enough.

Some are better crafted than others but its amazing how they are linked to the comics' cannon.I can't recommend this game enough, one of the best games I ever played and I still pick it from time to time.Recommended!
