content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												Arkham City was a wonderful sequel to Arkham Asylum, not only story wise, but with litterally taking everyhting great about asylum and multiplying it by 20. Here we have a much bigger map to explore as well as lots of interesting characters and side quests. Playing through all the side quests doesn't feel like a hassle and in fact I found my self excited to play through them, they all features characters that i personally loved and they were lots of fun. The twists and turns of the story line in Arkham City will keep you hooked from the beginning and you wont want to stop playing until you finally reach the end and learn everything about Protocol 10 and The Joker. This game is a thrill ride from start to finish and should be a pick up if you're a fan of Batman or just looking for a decently sized action game. This game (for my system) had never dropped below its 62 fps cap and ran buttery smooth the whole way through expect for one crash I received at the end of the Harley Quinn DLC but booted back up and finished no problem. Side note: When doing the Mysterious Figure side quest, Azrael may not show up a the location he is supposed to, meaning sometimes he just wont be there, a fix is to simply exit the game back to the main menu and continue your story and he will be there. (figured I'd mention this as I was confused when it happened to me).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												This is the best game I've played in years and I believe a worthy successor to Arkham Asylum.I felt Asylum streamlined you a bit while City let's you do your own thing. Unlike the Elder Scrolls game though, I want to complete the main story line.Story/Writing:I loved the writing. I thought they kept true to the characters (small issue with Ra's). I loved how the little extra stuff you do unlocks bio's and tapes (like in the first game) that flush out the writing. The main story line is  good, not great, but good and the characters really do carry it.Gameplay:Flying around as the batman is such a satisfying feeling. I prefer predator mode (stealth) over the punch your way through, but they both feel really good to do. I enjoy the different gadgets and being able to use them in combat. I liked that i didn't need to complete everything in the game and could still play through. I enjoy the lvl up system (which is just upgrades).Bugs: I experienced one bug in which the map showed a mission location that had already been completed. That's it. No crashes, no characters phasing into walls. Nothing else in 50 hours of play.I'm just going to say this game improved the series and is one of the best games i've ever played. (10/10)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												A journalist once discribed Batman-Arkham Asylum as a love letter to the Batman franchise; and Batman Arkham City hands you a game that follows that exact MO. Unlike the portrayals of characters and events in the film industry, this game (as with Arkham Asylum) delivers you characters with motives and emotions true to the roots. It certainly isn't beating Superman down. An excellent example here is the sections with Mr Freeze, who isn't the moron that Arnie played, but a sad, desperate man willing to do anything and try any angle to save Nora. No spoilers, but you understand and relate to his actions and you unwittingly feel sorry for him and his fate.The game in itself is excellent, with an amazing cast of script writers, voice actors and level designers. It really gives you the feeling of being the Dark Knight himself.The only minor negative point I have is the collection system with the Riddler trophies. Although mostly brilliantly presented, it ends up becoming a grind with way too a large quantity, and with some trophies not making sense at all. Example: Why would Riddler want you to use a certain weapon a certain amount of time? How would he know and why would he care? Why should I?Regardless. Even as someone that does not nessesarily care for the franchise, this game is highly recommended as with Arkham Asylum. Get it now.

Posted: March 18, 2016
												Batman Arkham Asylum was a real surprise to me. I enjoyed every bit of it. However, when Batman Arkham City was released, I got I little bit confused with all the new things. After all these years I decided to give this game another chance and bought it on sale.  Here is my _personal_ list of pros and cons: Pros:- Very engaging world. Especially the radio transmissions- Beautiful graphics. The world design is very authentic - this is exactly how I picture Gotham city- Gameplay is very polished. This includes combat, stealth and movements- You can play Batman, Catwoman and even Robin- The Wonder city below :)Cons:- Well... the open world. Besides the stunning views, the ability to glide through the city and dramatically sit on gargoyles, the open world annoys me. This is the first thing that I disliked in comparison to Arkham Asylum. Also, the collectables- Characters.  I just don't dig into seductive Catwoman, Batman's problem with killing and other stuff. Well, I have never read any Batman comics, so I had hard time to enjoy this. But I watched two Burton's movies, the unspeakable third one and all Nolan's movies. I liked the atmosphere of the Gotham city in Burton's movies. But the characters are the best in Nolan's.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												Arkham Asylum had only one major flaw – the game was so painstakingly, overwhelmingly, wonderfully thorough in its depiction of the Batman universe, we couldn’t imagine what was left to cover or accomplish in a sequel. The developers at Rocksteady got every element of the character right, from his combat to his gadgets to his previously neglected detective skills. They featured half a dozen of Gotham’s greatest villains, then included hidden references to nearly 30 more just as fan service. They created a setting with enough macabre detail to capture the comics’ horror, but with enough epic scope to somehow fit a Batcave, Batmobile and Batwing.This was it. This was the perfect Batman game.Yet from the moment we started Arkham City, all we could think was: Arkham Asylum was practice. Compared to its sequel, the “best superhero game ever” and our choice for Game of the Year 2009 seems like a tech demo, a first draft, merely a blueprint for what the perfect Batman game can actually be. This is it.For an immediate idea of how much bigger and better Arkham City is than its already incredible predecessor, take a look at this list of the Batman villains mentioned in Arkham Asylum, but never seen. Half of those now play major roles in the sequel, in addition to return appearances by all except one of the rogue’s gallery introduced in the original. Throw in new heroes like Robin, Alfred, Vicki Vale and Talia al Ghul, as well as a bunch of surprise cameos we wouldn’t dare spoil here, and you have a cast numbering in the “holy cow, did Joel Schumacher direct this?!” range. That fear is unnecessary, however, because the game’s writers and developers have succeeded in fully developing and fully justifying every character’s place in a narrative that makes complete logical and dramatic sense. It’s really rather miraculous.Seriously, this story is special, combining the humanity of the best Animated Series episodes, the brutal darkness of a Frank Miller comic and the confident risk-taking of a Christopher Nolan film. There are no moments as subversive as the fourth-wall break in Arkham Asylum, but there are countless moments of awe, shock and squealing fanboy glee – hell, you’ll be overpowered by all of those emotions within the first 15 minutes of the game alone. By the last 15 minutes, you may honestly choke back some tears, and not for a reason you’d ever predict or ever expect a superhero game to deliver.Of course, the most obvious upgrade in Arkham City is, well, Arkham City. At the time the original game released, a small island asylum seemed like the only possible setting for a properly done Batman experience – attempt to render the sprawling streets and skyscrapers of Gotham itself and you’d sacrifice BioShock-level detail for GTA-style size, and might as well be developing a Superman or Spider-Man game. The sequel, though, proves that assumption wrong. The asylum remains on an island of sorts – a bordered, quarantined section of Gotham City – but is at least four to five times as large as before, and if anything, more detailed.Stand still at any point and the magnitude of both Arkham City’s epic scale and atmospheric intricacy will floor you. Endless rooftops stretching into the horizon, each with a different neon sign (Ace Chemicals, where Joker was born) or peeling billboard (“The Terror”, Clayface’s famous movie role) or deadly booby trap (left by the Riddler, no doubt). An apartment building that can be instantly recognized, not only because Selina Kyle’s cats are outside one of the windows, but because every building in the environment is unique. A gigantic carnival Ferris wheel that, when scanned with Detective mode, reveals a hidden body in each compartment. Snow falling as helicopter spotlights crisscross through the night sky and fire burns in the distant background, leftover from a battle that – at some point in the game – you fought.Who are we kidding? You won’t stand still. While Rocksteady hasn’t given players the keys to the Batmobile yet, gliding and leaping and diving and climbing and rappelling across this expansive playground with the use of Batman’s cape and tools offers just as much exhilarating freedom as tearing across Liberty City on a motorcycle. An example Achievement / Trophy: “Jump off the tallest building and glide for one minute without touching the ground.” Yesssss.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												Fantastic. I've just started on 1% of the game but I am already impressed. I'll add more as I keep on playing. At $5 on sale, with all the DLC, I think it's worth it. Will add more when I complete the game.Finished the main campaign, other than a few cons, most impressed with the details.PROS1. Graphics***So much detail. I must say that the artist really put in a lot of effort to design a dark Industrial-age like Arkham City. Kudos to the team. I felt like I was playing the comic.a. Arkham City (Especially the details and the inner design. Who's your artist?)b. Costume design (Even the thugs, but not Robin's)c. Villians (I liked Harley Quinn the most)2. CombatSo smooth, so beautiful. Even though I'm just tapping the Left and Right Mouse buttons, the combat moves so smoothly. You can even cause enemies to interact with the environment E.g. By smashing their faces into the walls3. Detective ModeReally fun pretending to be a real detective. Of course, I understand that this isn't a real CSI but I do appreciate simple realism. E.g. How they calculate the bullets trajectory from Joker's sniper rifle. The X-Ray vision and highlighting of important objects is vital as well.4. CharactersLove Harley Quinn. So wild, so cute, so attractive. Can't wait to see the rest. This is most surprising as I had already watched some parts of the game on Youtube. It's so fun. Even after the main campaign finishes, you get to find Riddler, Killer Croc, Bane, Posion Ivy and so on.5. Arkham CityIt gives you a really good feeling seeing the walls surround the giant prison which is Arkham City. The way it's built up just ties into the story so well.6. GadgetsI love them. I especially love the ingenious use of combat + utility. E.g. Using the Batarang for combat and hitting buttons. Using the Batclaw to disarm and open seals. Using the electric charge gun to stun bosses and turn on motors. It really makes the weapons so much more useful. Compared to other games, where a weapon is just a weapon and a tool is just a tool, this really provide another avenue for clever gameplay.7. ReplayabilityI never thought that I would enjoy going back to the same place twice but Rocksteady Studios really does make the game fun. I especially liked the old GCPD map where you can first go through Penguin's goons and later Mr Freeze's boss fight.8. AIa. Heartbeat monitor. I loved it. This is so much more realistic than other stealth games, where you knock someone out and no one notices he's gone for hours.b. Radio Communications. Great to get game information and to search for clues.9. Riddler's PuzzlesI appreciate the simple, yet thoughtful puzzles. It forces you to think just that little bit more without creating a full blown mental exam.10. Multi-charactersCatwoman was fun. Using the whip was a totally new way of playing. Robin was too similar to Batman to warrant anything interesting.11. StorySo interesting. Penguin's museum collection, the underground Gotham City, the Lazarus project, Hugo Strange etc... I still don't get why Batman doesn't kill though... It is extremely righteous but it takes a little of the suspension of disbelief away.... Practically, it seems totally impossible...CONS1. Button ControlsThe Left Control + Space command is extremely difficult to do and is intutitive. It's used for dropping off the edge but it's quite silly.2. Glide KickYou would think that dropping from a height + smashing a face into the ground would instantly KO an enemy, yet this game seems to create some peculiar situations where you have to link another KO move.3. Riddler Hostage RescueToo many puzzles to solve just to get to the end. 400/600 Riddler trophies plus challanges just to rescue the hostage. I couldn't take it at a 160. When I realised the next rescue required 320 trophies. That was too much and gave up.4. Balloons, Harley Heads, Joker Teeth, Penguin modelsReally silly to have to so many things to shoot that have no value, only a challenge completed. You need to complete them just to do Riddler's hostage quest.5. Dead end MapsSome maps just become empty voids after use. E.g. The Lazarus Pit. Once you finish with it, there's only a Riddler trophy to get. This guy is Batman, he comes from the direction you least expect. It is most silly to limit Batman to doors and watch him walk into an ambush.6. Thug BodiesIf you watch the Batman shows, the thugs usually disappear quietly into the darkness. There is no unconscious body. Batman would tie them up and leave them hanging and gagged. The thugs leaving their buddy hanging or unconscious bodies unable to wake up are super silly.SUGGESTIONS1. Multiple Entrances/ExitsThis is for CON 5. Once you finish with a location, there should be another entrance or instant travel to that area as a reward. It's necessary for maps that can't use the grapnel hook. E.g. Subway.2. Gang/Turf Wars3 major gangs, Joker, Two-Face and Penguin plus TYGER. I was hoping that there would be zones where there were firefights between the gangs. E.g. Joker's snipers shooting at Penguin's men who are hiding behind cover.3. Tying Up ThugsBatman would probably have an option of tagging, hanging and gagging the thugs. It would be more true to the Batman saga. He works on Stealth Mode not fisticuffs.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												Let me just start by saying that for me this is not only the best comic book game ever made, but just one of the best in general.Now that I've got that out, here's my review of Batman: Arkham CityPROS:-Nicely sized open world map with more than enough enemies to fight.-One of the smoothest and most fun combat systems in gaming.-Great looking game for the time it came out.-I controls really nicely with both gamepad and keyboard & mouse.-Well written Story.-The challenge maps are both challenging and fun.-Great voice talent (e.g. Kevin Conroy, Mark Hamill, Tara Strong etc.)-The gliding is incredibly fun.-The game has great replay value with a challengeing New Game + mode and all of the side quests.-The game really makes you feel like, and captures the esscence of, Batman.CONS:-There are some annoying things about the combat system (e.g. not being able to jump out of a ground takedown leaving you open to attack, having to double tap counter to counter two attacks at once)-There are quite a few wierd bugs.-Overly sexualised female characters.SUMMARY:As you can tell I couldn't think of too many cons for this game and the good stuff heavily outweighs the bad. I will always recommend this game.I have purchased this game 3 times (Xbox 360, PC & Wii U) and I don't regret a single one.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2013
												First off, if you've not played Batman: Arkham Asylum yet then you shouldn't touch City as City is a direct sequel, plus Asylum is an amazing game in its own right.Now I'm going to assume you've beaten Asylum  so that I can talk at length about City because this game not only lives up to the really high standard Asylum set, it surpasses it in every way.The main difference between Asylum and City is its pacing and game world. While Asylum had a very direct, linear path due to its constricted size, City throws all of that out of the window giving you a huge open world complete with various sidequests, ranging from AR training sequences to practice your gliding skills to you unearthing many villain's plots, ultimately finding them and incarcerating them, and last but definitely not least, the Riddler trophies and riddles, which make a comeback in an even grander scale.The story didn't lose any quality, the voice acting and overall feel of the game are as top notch as before, the combat has been further improved, with things such as multiple counters, and Batman can use several more gadgets than the previous game. However, Batman is not the only character you can play this time. Catwoman, Robin, and Nightwing are all playable characters, the latter unfortunately not being in any story related content, only present in the Riddler's challenges mode. Every single one of these characters plays quite differently to the Dark Knight, and all have their strengths and weaknesses. So while you will have to replay challenges four times, one for each character, it'll feel fresh thanks to their different abilities.Now that it has had its DRM removed, there's nothing stopping you from playing this game.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												Batman Arkham Asylum was a real surprise to me. I enjoyed every bit of it. However, when Batman Arkham City was released, I got I little bit confused with all the new things. After all these years I decided to give this game another chance and bought it on sale.  Here is my _personal_ list of pros and cons: Pros:- Very engaging world. Especially the radio transmissions- Beautiful graphics. The world design is very authentic - this is exactly how I picture Gotham city- Gameplay is very polished. This includes combat, stealth and movements- You can play Batman, Catwoman and even Robin- The Wonder city below :)Cons:- Well... the open world. Besides the stunning views, the ability to glide through the city and dramatically sit on gargoyles, the open world annoys me. This is the first thing that I disliked in comparison to Arkham Asylum. Also, the collectables- Characters.  I just don't dig into seductive Catwoman, Batman's problem with killing and other stuff. Well, I have never read any Batman comics, so I had hard time to enjoy this. But I watched two Burton's movies, the unspeakable third one and all Nolan's movies. I liked the atmosphere of the Gotham city in Burton's movies. But the characters are the best in Nolan's.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												Arkham Asylum had only one major flaw – the game was so painstakingly, overwhelmingly, wonderfully thorough in its depiction of the Batman universe, we couldn’t imagine what was left to cover or accomplish in a sequel. The developers at Rocksteady got every element of the character right, from his combat to his gadgets to his previously neglected detective skills. They featured half a dozen of Gotham’s greatest villains, then included hidden references to nearly 30 more just as fan service. They created a setting with enough macabre detail to capture the comics’ horror, but with enough epic scope to somehow fit a Batcave, Batmobile and Batwing.This was it. This was the perfect Batman game.Yet from the moment we started Arkham City, all we could think was: Arkham Asylum was practice. Compared to its sequel, the “best superhero game ever” and our choice for Game of the Year 2009 seems like a tech demo, a first draft, merely a blueprint for what the perfect Batman game can actually be. This is it.For an immediate idea of how much bigger and better Arkham City is than its already incredible predecessor, take a look at this list of the Batman villains mentioned in Arkham Asylum, but never seen. Half of those now play major roles in the sequel, in addition to return appearances by all except one of the rogue’s gallery introduced in the original. Throw in new heroes like Robin, Alfred, Vicki Vale and Talia al Ghul, as well as a bunch of surprise cameos we wouldn’t dare spoil here, and you have a cast numbering in the “holy cow, did Joel Schumacher direct this?!” range. That fear is unnecessary, however, because the game’s writers and developers have succeeded in fully developing and fully justifying every character’s place in a narrative that makes complete logical and dramatic sense. It’s really rather miraculous.Seriously, this story is special, combining the humanity of the best Animated Series episodes, the brutal darkness of a Frank Miller comic and the confident risk-taking of a Christopher Nolan film. There are no moments as subversive as the fourth-wall break in Arkham Asylum, but there are countless moments of awe, shock and squealing fanboy glee – hell, you’ll be overpowered by all of those emotions within the first 15 minutes of the game alone. By the last 15 minutes, you may honestly choke back some tears, and not for a reason you’d ever predict or ever expect a superhero game to deliver.Of course, the most obvious upgrade in Arkham City is, well, Arkham City. At the time the original game released, a small island asylum seemed like the only possible setting for a properly done Batman experience – attempt to render the sprawling streets and skyscrapers of Gotham itself and you’d sacrifice BioShock-level detail for GTA-style size, and might as well be developing a Superman or Spider-Man game. The sequel, though, proves that assumption wrong. The asylum remains on an island of sorts – a bordered, quarantined section of Gotham City – but is at least four to five times as large as before, and if anything, more detailed.Stand still at any point and the magnitude of both Arkham City’s epic scale and atmospheric intricacy will floor you. Endless rooftops stretching into the horizon, each with a different neon sign (Ace Chemicals, where Joker was born) or peeling billboard (“The Terror”, Clayface’s famous movie role) or deadly booby trap (left by the Riddler, no doubt). An apartment building that can be instantly recognized, not only because Selina Kyle’s cats are outside one of the windows, but because every building in the environment is unique. A gigantic carnival Ferris wheel that, when scanned with Detective mode, reveals a hidden body in each compartment. Snow falling as helicopter spotlights crisscross through the night sky and fire burns in the distant background, leftover from a battle that – at some point in the game – you fought.Who are we kidding? You won’t stand still. While Rocksteady hasn’t given players the keys to the Batmobile yet, gliding and leaping and diving and climbing and rappelling across this expansive playground with the use of Batman’s cape and tools offers just as much exhilarating freedom as tearing across Liberty City on a motorcycle. An example Achievement / Trophy: “Jump off the tallest building and glide for one minute without touching the ground.” Yesssss.

												I played Batman: Arkham Barkham Asylum before I played this, and at first I found the new Open World to be a bit overwhelming. I probably won't complete the extra challenges or riddlers math revenge whatever, but I will be checking back to talk to that fat guy in the basement. All and all, The legend of Batman: Return of the Jokie is an exellent game, well worth the pocket change I payed for it.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												I love this installment of Batman, very good story and intresting world to explorer. Really nice side missions along with the main story. It took me more then 25 hours gameplay to complete this game.. Arkham City is stuffed to the edge of with content and replay value (in addition to the gigantic campaign there's an expanded Challenge Mode and New Game Plus), is incredible amounts of fun, that will allow you more then 25 hours gameplay. Arkham City is by far a  better game in delivering an immaculately presented, rich, compelling play experience and very intresting and emotionfilled story while it is true to the Batman franchise and giving players imense feel of how it is being Batman. Enjoyed every bit of this excellent game. Sometimes the boss fights got on my nerve, but thanks to the hints after dying, I got the hang of how to kill some of the bosses. You would love the gripping fighting system, lots of diversity  as you have loads of choices to make and a great atmosphere since the world is a "open world", this is the best superhero according to me. I just loved it!

content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												Rocksteady has done it again!Without question, Batman: Arkham City is one of the most enjoyable video games I've ever played. Between its wealth of stealth and action, well-written story, memorable characters, and extraordinary production values, this game is definitely worth "clawing" onto. You can get away with some “button mashing” at the start of the game, but taking down tougher enemies and bosses later on will require some savvy melee or ranged attacks, use of gadgets, acrobatic dodges, and other tactics. Batman: Arkham City isn't just better than Batman: Arkham Asylum, it's better than most games on the market.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												I played Batman: Arkham Barkham Asylum before I played this, and at first I found the new Open World to be a bit overwhelming. But it didn't take long for the game to grow on me, and staying up late several days completing the main story, all the sidequest, collecting all the riddler trophies (accept for the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥te one that required me to do a 50 m vertical drop, I can't seem to do that one for some reason) and completing the bonus story, which I think was a nice thing to add, Robin is surprisingly fun to play. I probably won't complete the extra challenges or riddlers math revenge whatever, but I will be checking back to talk to that fat guy in the basement. All and all, The legend of Batman: Return of the Jokie is an exellent game, well worth the pocket change I payed for it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2013
												The first thing I noticed about this game was how well the motions are animated. If you block a kick you actually catch the kick in your hands. if you counter a punch you actually catch the punch and pull them off balance - or maybe twist their wrist. As an animator I highly approve!The overall game switches between hunting, stealth, and combat pretty regularly. Never really can I say I got bored.Wasn't very challenging though. Enemies have the capacity to learn, but only locationally. Take someeone out from a ceiling and people will watch out for ceilings, but only in that specific area you did it before. Mr Freeze aside anyway - he learns for real and takes out any advantages you used as he comes across them.Awesome game for the 7.50 I paid for it.The late-game challenges are kind of soul crushing. Not the combat challenges. Those are exciting! The predator challenges though almost always include a requirement that will leave the player waiting minutes upon minutes for the NPCs to just blindly crawl into a situation where you can just complete the challenge - like waiting for two thugs to stand side by side and face the same direction so you can sneak up behind them to deliver a double knockout. I've wasted 20 minutes on a map before waiting for that exact situation. By no means hard or challenging since all you do is wait which anyone can do, but boring as get out. There's no real need to do the challenges though unless you want achievements or just the sense of completion.Overall I would have to give this game a high grade. The story was awesome, most of the challenges are fun, and finding riddler trophies feels strangely addictive.

												Nice combat, good moves, good gadgets, a nice degree of freedom to be a city guardian in an open world  style game. This game has a deep, juicy dark story that enchants you since the first second you enter into Arkham City and play as Bruce Wayne.The GoodEverything mentioned earlier and CatwomanThe BadThe amount of Riddler Challenges in this game, compared with Arkham Asylum, this one game was a big pain in the **sThe ResultEverything in this game (unless you want a 100% complete file) is pretty good: graphics, combat, story, challenges, dlc's challenges, etc. With so many elements it gives a lot of replay value, is pretty hard to not touch this game after completing the main story. With just 5$ with the 75% discount sale, this game is worth at least 9/10. Have a good time!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1
												I think i should get this out there. I haven't played the other games in this series with this game being my first so my opinion will completely be based on my experiences with this game by itself. If your hoping for a comparison between this game and the other you should look at the other reviews. If you don't want to hear the full review but just my thoughts just scroll to the bottom. Ok now let get started with the review ^-^.  The Long Review StealthAs a fan of stealth games, this game does have some elements of stealth to it, with specific segments dedicated to it. These segment provide a decent amount of stealth where you are required to work yourself around a room to take down a number of enemies which are all armed making them difficult to handle head on. Other elements are added on later in the game to make this more difficult so there is some need to vary your strategy. During these moments, you can truly feel like the dark knight as you make your way around the room taking them out one by one and making your enemies feel truly helpless or growingly paranoid.CombatThe more frequent encounters are where you're required to battle a group of enemies head on with the enemies mostly being unarmed near the beginning of the game. These battles are made interesting with the way the combat system works. The combat system is basically a combo meter that requires you to not make a mistake in a combo such as getting hit, countering early or missing a punch. All you have to do is keeping pressing the punch button (Right click for me) while pointing in the direction of your target (wasd for me). Later in the game you will be given the choice to buy a somewhat finisher that can be used at a high combo (12 hits generally). Also, the variety of weapons you will have to deal with will require you to strategies a bit making the experience a bit different each time.GadgetsNow, time for the gadgets. There is a large and healthy variety of gadgets that can be used in this game. From the classic batarang to weapons that batman made on the spot which is somewhat ridiculous but effective. These gadgets can be used to solve puzzles or the riddlers puzzles (which I'll talk about later). The gadgets are not just useful for puzzles. They can also be used in combat, helping to deal with various situations such as when your surrounded or if an enemy has a gun pointed at you. StoryFinally, the story. Without spoiling much, the story revolves mainly around the joker and another villain by the name of Strange. There are many other villains in the game such as Poison ivy, Catwomen, The Penguin and many others. You could play the entire game focused on the main story but after that there are still many other things to do so there is replayability if that's what your looking for. Besides the other Villains that can be interacted with in the game, there are also the collectables placed by The Riddler throughout the map which has it's ups and downs such as if you're trying to 100% the game.Final thoughts In my opinion, i feel that this is a great game and is something that you should definitely try playing if you're a fan of batman or you want to play a fun brawler with interesting stealth.Ques: Could you play the with little to no knowledge about Batman?Ans: You definitely can play it as the game does give you a little insight to the characters you're about to get involved with via the in game encyclopediaI'll admit the controls can feel a little clunky just due to the fact that some of the keys for some actions overlap each other eg. Running and taking cover are the same key there's a chance of doing one or the other when near a corner.There are other examples of clunky control but overall i think Batman Arkham City is a great open world game.I definitely recommend it <3

content:
Posted: February 22, 2013
												*Gnome Seal of Approval*One of the richest games of 2012 in my opinion and it looks great. Combat is very rewarding and fluid. The only drawback is the use of the quickfire action. You can quickfire each gadget by double tapping its respective key. The trouble comes when you need to double tap keys like 5, 6, 7 or 8 mid combat. It's just not convenient and might cause some frustration. Wonder how the quickfire works on a controller...Anyway, it's a solid game all the way through. It has felt better to control one of the coolest superheroes out there. Not to mention you get to run around as Catwoman too. She feels a little weak compared to Batman and you don't get to use her as much as I'd like. She deserves a game like this of her own considering how good of a job they did with her.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												The main problem with Batman: Arkham City is that it improves so much on it's already excellent predecessor, Arkham Asylum, that it renders AA almost completely irrelevant (fortunately for AA it's so darn good that it can still hold it's ground, even against this beast).A great vision and insight into the Batman universe and a solid rounded story that manages to be affecting, poignant and intelligent while still keeping a familiar comic-book feel. The gameplay and graphics, again, are silky-smooth and almost flawless. There's plenty in this game to keep it fresh for two, maybe even three full playthroughs. Delivered with love, care and attention to detail, Arkham City is a solid and stand-up masterclass in how to make a AAA blockbuster game.

												You've probably heard this before but it's worth saying again: this game blows other action adventure third person games out of the water. Let alone actually allowing you to feel like you were the Batman, it features a rollercoaster story on par with best Batman cartoon stories, an amazing look no matter what kind of machine you're using, tons of different gadgets to try out, good learning curve in terms of AI and a completely different experience when using another character like Catwoman. I had fun with Assassin's Creed games for example but this one offers the level of fun of exploration and combat Ubisoft can only dream about making.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												I loved Batman Arkham Asylum so had big hopes for Arkham City, and I can say I was impressed. Its kept all the elements from Arkham Asylum that I liked and thrown in some improvements as well as a bit of DLC. The look of the game is even more impressive than AA, and the combat is just stunning to look at. The voice acting and soundtrack are just as great too. The plot is decent enough with some good "interludes" and there's plenty of side-quests. So its a definite thumbs up. On the negative side, I don't quite know why I didn't enjoy it as much as I thought I should. Perhaps because I've seen it before with AA?  Perhaps that a lot of game is within the challenge maps which just didn't grab me? Perhaps that when I'd finished the main plot I'd still only done about 2/3rds of the side quests, and had the opportunity to carry on playing despite the fact the game was "over". I can't put my finger on it but I didn't enjoy it as much as AA. Its still an awesome game though, so I have to award it a very respectable 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 18
												I really enjoyed this game.It is a great sequel to arkham asylum. The story is very good continuing on from arkham asylum. The characters are well represented with fantastic character models and the voice actors doing another amazing job. I only played the story and side missions and got a lot of mileage from the game without feeling bored or like the game contained a lot of useless padding content to lengthen play time. There is also a ton of challenge maps if you are interested in them and a new game plus mode that gives an even harder difficulty setting so the game is great value for money.I enjoyed being able to play different characters this time out although I have to say catwoman really isn’t for me. The lack of gadgets and abilities limits how you can tackle the cons, armed guards on hard wreck catwoman if spotted so it can be frustrating.I had a few crashes throughout my playthrough, 10 in all I think. None of them were at the same spot or seemed to be for any specific reason but it didn’t put me off playing the game. I also came across what I thought at the time was going to be a game breaking bug. Playing as catwoman when i jumped from a building to the ground she kept getting stuck in this pose in mid-air just above the ground being unable to move. I restarted the game multiple times to no avail then I put my issue on the discussions and was told to check the integrity of my files on steam. I did and it never happened after so I guess it worked.All in all, I think this game is awesome. really enjoyed it and would recommend it for sure. If you enjoyed arkham asylum this is more of the same only better.

content:
Posted: April 25
												Batman was always my favorite superhero, so naturally I fell in love with the Arkham games. After playing Arkham Asylum, I was excited to see that Arkham City was going to be a thing and I was going to be able to actually free roam the city. This game is now almost six years old, and I still get a kick out of playing it. I'd definitely recommend this to anyone who likes Batman. Out of all the Arkham games, I think Arkham City was my favorite. It has a solid story, fun gameplay, and there's a lot to do. I find myself coming back to this game often.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												As with Arkham Asylum, I got this through a Humble Bundle deal without realizing what I was getting.  As of right now, this is my third favorite Batman game.  My favorite being Arkham Asylum and my second favorite being Arkham Origins.  This takes the gameplay of Arkham Asylum and moves from a Metroidvania-type game to open world, and it works very well.  The story is interesting, although the boss fights are fairly bland.Apparently this game had performance problems at launch, but I didn't get it at launch so I didn't experience any of that.  It runs fine on max settings on my hardware, though not as smooth as Asylum or Origins.  Overall I give this a 9/10.  It's a great game, just not QUITE as great as Arkham Asylum or Arkham Origins.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Expanding upon the fantastic Arkham Asylum, Arkham City provides a bigger open world within which to be the Batman. Set after the events of Arkham Asylum, with Arkham now having spread to a closed off part of Gotham City. The game opens with Bruce Wayne petitioning for the closure of 'Arkham City' before swiftly becoming an inmate himself at the behest of Dr. Hugo Strange. Within the city walls Bruce meets one of the three 'gang leaders' vying for control, Penguin. Making a swift escape Bruce ventures to the top of Ace Chemicals and opts to 'Suit up' and become 'the Batman'. All your favourite villains are in this, including; Deadshot, Hush, Calendar Man, Mad Hatter, Zsasz, Riddler, Penguin, Two Face and of course, the Joker. The plot of the game involves a three way struggle for control of Arkham, between Penguin, Two Face and Joker. Each gang leader has thugs costumed appropriately to their style, particularly the half-n-half costumes of Two Faces thugs. The larger world gives greater opportunity to explore Arkham City and fly around as the Batman, scouting thugs from the roof tops before Glide Kicking them into next week. The combat system is largely unchanged from Arkham Asylum, where timing your attacks takes precedence over button mashing and you're given a wealth of gadgets to deploy against your enemy. The combat feels very fluid, even if it is sometimes ridiculous as Batman punches one thug before leaping across a room to kick the next. Similar to Asylum the game also features 'predator' areas where Batman must systematically eliminate a group of thugs from the shadows. These sections provide a nice change of pace from combat, where you have to plan out your attack before removing thugs one-by-one. The challenge maps are a mix of combat challenges and preadtor challenges where you are given specific instruction for taking down your opponent, being awarded three medals if your complete all objectives for the map. Combat challenges are a simple, beat the score but the predator challenges force you to utilise the breadth of gadgets available, making you be a bit more creative with your takedowns and dramatically adding to their challenge. The challenges are also grouped in campaigns where you need to complete three maps in a row (with 3 retries) meeting the medal goals for all 3 to get the maximum 9 medals. The campaigns have modifiers that must be used on one of the three maps that can give the enemies guns, booby-trap gargoyles or even reduce your health. Side activities include collecting Riddler trophies of which there are a huge amount (Maybe too many) by using your gadgets to complete tasks (Like moving a globe through a maze or just sliding under a fence). Some of these trophies are very easy to attain, some require a bit more thinking. There are other side activities that will pit Batman against other foes including Deadshot, Mad Hatter and others, The DLC packs included with the Game of the Year edition include three extra characters (Catwoman, Robin and Nightwing), a mini-story for Catwoman (Which plays out in interludes during the main story) and 5 extra challenge maps. Also included are alternate costumes for Batman and the three DLC characters. Overall, Arkham Asylum provides plenty to do (It took me around 85 hours to do absolutely everything) and maintains the fluid combat, and shadowy predator sections. The story itself is fantastic and a really enjoyable ride! Thoroughly recommend this to anyone who was a fan of Arkham Asylum or just Batman in gerneral.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												If you've ever played an action-adventure game and loved it, this one will trump it. Batman: Arkham Asylum and City are easily in the very top of my favourite games, not just because I like the Batman character (I'm really not that into comics, after all), but because the gameplay is accessible and very responsive. The freeflow combat-system is probably one of the most fun features I've ever seen in a game of this genre and keeps me playing much longer than I usually intend to.The story of the game is also very enjoyable, and even though it is a completely lineair experience, aside from the occassional side-quest, the city that you navigate in gives off a definite open-world experience. And flying around as Batman is just awesome in every way.

												I have played through Batman: Arkham City twice. Arkham City throws you right into the action and a twisted storyline! I love how they include almost every Batman villain, and I also enjoy the Catwoman parts! She's hot, I mean, well, the game is great! If you have played Arkham Asylum, then I strongly recommend you buy this game immediately! You will not be disappointed. Even after the main story and side missions, there's an awesome DLC called "Harley Quinn's Revenge" which is also pretty well done.I have to say, out of the Batman: Arkham series, this game is by far the greatest of them all. Second greatest being Arkham Asylum. This game really captivates you to actually BE the Batman and kick some criminal♥♥♥♥♥ From all the gadgets, cutscenes, plot twists, and everything, I truly love exploring Arkham City! Definitely a game everyone should play.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												This game is fantastic! I got the game from a friend and was really curious about the series. When i saw gameplay videos of the game, my biggest concern was the combat system: It seemed like it was optimized for controller play. I looked like it would be pretty hard and gamebreaking to play with mouse and keyboard (yes, i don't own an xbox controller). But damn i was wrong! When i played the intro battle, with catwoman, i was very pleased and surprised to find out how perfect i worked with mouse and controller.The history takes you Arkham City, an encapsulated part of Gotham, which works as one huge prison. This is an open world game, and you can glide with your cape and swing your batarang all across Arkham City. The city is not huge, but it's big enough to not getting tired of the place. Throughout the mission you'll meet a lot off Gothams' classic super villains. Of course they all have their own charme, but no one beats the Joker, who plays a major role in the game.The game's graphics looks great and makes Arkham City come to life (even better at 40-60FPS :P). However it's not Battlefield graphics, but still very beautiful and athmospheric. It is rarely i experience so fluent gameplay in a game, there is usually always some small bugs that annoys. But that is not the case with this game: Haven't experienced a single bug, glitch or anything. The game simply feels perfect.Is this a game i would recommend? YES! The game was an absolute joy to play through, and i feel like i will return to it many times in the future.As a gamer, this game stole my heart.

												Arkham City is everything that Arkham Asylum was but improved in almost every way. largely fixing the control problems of Arkham Asylum on PC, Arkham City takes you and throws you into a large environment that allows you to explore and fight in many different interesting and entertaining ways. Arkham City makes the improvement of creating a more open world and adding well-integrated side missions that have some meaning to the main story and makes the game feel less linear. Again the voice acting is top-notch and the pacing and progression of the story is a high-point of this title.

Posted: April 26, 2015
												If your a Batman fan you MUST get this game, This game is the greatest superhero game in all time and in my opinion even better than Arkham Knight, unlike the first installment of the Arkham series this adds a new bigger open world experience that will make you want to play for hours fighting crime without doing anything productive, the intro to this game will immedately lift you off your toes and give you goosebumps and compared to Arkham Asylum it has massively added new features to the game, such as dive bombs, sliding, side missions, way more riddles, new gadets, new villians, and new playable characters, and more The campaign this game has to offer is a amazing experience that keeps you on your toes the whole time with many unexpected twists and turns and a extremely shocking ending, that changes the next arkham game intensely, even after you beat the campaign which I've done multple times on Xbox and PC the game has lots of replay value that you can play for a year and yet not have everything, and even if you somehow do manage to get everything this game is easy to mod with hundreds of amazing mods and skins, the DLC in this game is 100% worth it with 3 new playable character Robin, Catwomen, and Nightwing, 2 of which have campaigns that are just as great, this game is a must have for Batman fans or anyone in general, I absolutly give this game a 10/10 if you don't trust me then look online to find out that this game has a average rating of 97 out of 100, so make sure to get this game or you'll regret it

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												Oh boy, not quite such a wonderArkham Asylum was a groundbreaking game for me. I loved the atmosphere, the varied and highly imaginative gameplay, the problem solving, and the superbly animated and free-flowing combat. It was engrossing, compelling, and had a far better storyline than most games. ARKHAM CITY promised more of the same and I looked forward to it immensely. Well it delivered in some respects but disappointed in many. The overarching fault with CITY is that Rocksteady have crammed too much into one game. It’s the game equivalent of bloatware. Combat is less fluent due to too many new moves, some of which you are forced to use. The short, somewhat underwhelming main story is interrupted too often by side missions and the ridiculously numerous riddler challenges and trophies. And the open world structure, coupled with the often intrusive side missions, diminish the sense of urgency in the narrative. There are also too many villains jammed into one story. It may seem odd to criticise something for doing too much but sometimes less really is more. On the plus side you get to play as Catwoman and Robin as well as Batman and some of the enhancements do improve gameplay. In conclusion, CITY is a good game and is fun to play, but it’s not as impressive as Rocksteady’s admirable original. Oh, and good luck trying to get at all 440 Riddler trophies!3.5/5

												The first game where you truly feel like THE ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ BATMAN. Leaping through rooftops, punching baddies, and a belt full of useful gadgets, all seemlessly integrated together. number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												The first Arkham game I played. To not put this at the top of your list would be a disservice to such a fine fine game. Like any great artwork though it does have some flaws. The most obvious being the map of City itself - though an improvement on Asylum, even when it was new it didn't really FEEL like a city. The claustrophobic map - while good - could have been better or at least larger with more variations in terrain and areas. The story - while good - never really reached a state where you would call it great. Asylum, Origins and even Knight have a moment that can be remembered instantly whenever you talk about it to Arkham fans. City never really seems to have a moment that you want to remember or watch over and over again on YouTube. The thing that makes City special though is that you will only find those flaws if you go LOOKING for them - and even that you have to do HARD. City was a truly special achievement. The launch was perfect. Rocksteady didn't have it's balls so tightly in WB's grip yet and could be counted on to deliver a quality product. The characters were real. Mark Hamil as the Joker. The DLC actually added something to the feel of the game and expanded the story without leaving you hanging. The random enemies on the street would sneak in snipers and shield-holders and other types of enemies that made you think before crashing in fists swinging (something Knight SORELY lacks) meant that every fight was VERY intense whether it was against a goon or against a boss. I could go on and on about this game but - if they ever put games in a preservation vault like they do film - this would be a game I would preserve.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												Better than Arkham Asylum because of the openness of the game. Graphics slightly more demanding; my five-year-old laptop experienced a slowdown every time I entered detective mode, which was a lot. Sometimes it's unclear where you're supposed to go, especially entrances to large buildings can be frustrating. I was disappointed at how little the other playable characters are in the game, and that they're significantly less powerful. Last, the city was so "riddled" with green question marks that it detracted from the beauty of the cityscape.Other than those complaints, it's basically a perfect fighting game, very satisfying, not too challenging (I imagine New Game Plus is a lot harder). The expansion Harvey's Revenge is also excellent. I like puzzles so I found 250/400 of the Riddler Trophies. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 6, 2015
A Slice of GothamTake Batman Arkham Asylum's linear sandbox, tear down its four walls, and what do you have? A beautiful sandy beach, loitered with easter egg goodies and villainous surprises! Batman Arkham City does everything Asylum contained so well: a paced and fleshed out Batman mythos. There are so many villains, you'll be glad to fight them and make their fanboyish acquaintance. A number of Combat and Predator challenges as well as side missions (one reminiscient of a Nintendo 64 Superman title!) from the main game keep City fresh long after its completion. If you want to know how resilient Batman is, again, and what it's like to glide like a bat, continue his journey of justice in Batman Arkham City!

												This game is masterpiece. Very immersive and atmospheric missions, smooth gameplay. It has a lot of stealth and requires thinking how to take out enemies one by one. Full walkthrough of the main story took about 14 hours, and that includes time for retries from the last checkpoint since the combat sometimes is hard. I think it should be easier with gamepad though.After finishing main story you can switch character at will (Batman, Catwoman, Robin, Nightwing), free roam, do side missions, collect Riddler's trophies, etc. This adds a lot of replay value. And I'm not even a fan of DC universe.I'd rate this game 8.5/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
												Note: I'm going to split this review into two parts, the first covering the base game and the second covering all the DLC.After the success of Batman Arkham Asylum, Batman Arkham City improves almost everything to make this game one of the best of all time. For me, the only thing that's a downside it's the story. While Arkham Asylum was more focused with some villains, Arkham City tries to put plenty of new villains into the main story, creating a mixed bag in the end. Penguin, Mister Freeze, Ra's al Ghul and Hugo Strange are some of the new cast, along with the returning Joker. But it got one thing right: other villains appear briefly in side quests, like the Mad Hatter, Hush and Deadshot. Those feel more well-placed. This time around, you explore Arkham City, which is old Gotham turned into a mega prison. It has the right size and ambience, and feels like a good way to navigate the story or just to kick some random inmates♥♥♥♥♥ This time there's more gadgets, and the combat and predator sections are improved. The combat now feels more fluid, with more combos and enemy types. The predator (stealth) sections are now easier and more enjoyable. And the riddler trophies return, much more improved. This time, many of them require you to solve a puzzle using your gadgets instead of just laying somewhere and waiting to be found; and this time collecting them will get you closer and closer to Edward Nigma himself, saving hostages in the process. This time the bosses are way more interesting, especially the atmosphere in Ra's al Ghul battle and the strategy needed to defeat Mister Freeze, one of the best boss battles ever made. So, this game is more disperse (in a bad way) than Arkham Asylum, but the core mechanics are much improved. After beating the game, you can replay it in New Game+, which is harder but you start with you gadgets. And the challenge mode returns, with more combat and predator maps. The combat maps are easier and more enjoyable, while the predator feels the same as in Arkham Asylum, being harder and requiring patience. One thing that i didn't like was the "campaings", which is basically 3 challenge maps that you'll need to beat in one session, with a max of 3 retries. It feels very cheap for me, because it's recicled content with cheap difficulty, especially in the hardest predator maps. There's also character models and artwork to collect with the riddler trophies. And the soundtrack is really amazing in this game. This is definitely a must buy for any comic book fan, or even anyone that likes action games.The DLC has 3 parts:The catwoman story, in which you'll sometimes play as catwoman in the main story, with her own moves and feel. It's a nice addition and doesn't fell rushed, except for the very last sequence.The Harley Quinn's Revenge is a short epilogue where you'll also play as Robin, but this one has a weak story and it's basically just recicled content.And you can also play as Catwoman, Robin and Nightwing in all of the challenge maps, which is cool because you can play as those characters, but that also means completing all of the campaings again. The additions are cool, but they are implemented in yet another cheap way to increase replayability.Overall, the DLC feels a bit rushed and cheap, adding little to the main game.But don't let this prevent you from playing the main game, which is really awesome in almost every way.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2015
												Ah yes. Batman. I say that he is the most awesome superhero in the DC Universe, heck, he even gives the best of Marvel a run for their money, and he is one of my favorites. There are numerous reasons for this, but the reason I bring up today is that he actually has cool and fun video games. All of the Rocksteady Batman Arkham games; Asylum, City, and Knight, were enjoyed by critics and gamers, excluding that last one on PC as of the time of writing, but they are planning on releasing patches soon to fix that. I've played City before on the Xbox 360 and enjoyed it a lot, so I figured to take another look at it on PC. So what did I think? Well let's take a look at it.STORY: You play as Bruce Wayne, AKA Batman. While on a campaign to shut down Arkham City, a newly opened mass prison that houses the greatest threats to Gotham City, Bruce Wayne is arrested by the guards of the jail and brought to the head of the prison, Hugo Strange, who brings up that he is planning to unleash a mysterious plan only known as Protocal 10 upon Arkham City, and that he knows that Bruce Wayne is actually Batman. After getting free from the holding area, Bruce makes it to the dropoff point of the Batsuit, gears up, and prepares to go after Strange and the mysterious Protocal 10. Along the way you encounter numerous of Batman's enemies, including The Penguin, Two Face, and The Joker, the latter poisoning Batman with the same poison he was infected with and forces him to look for a cure to save both of them. The story is pretty good, I enjoyed a lot of moments in this story, the ending was strangely sad, there are a lot of fun side missions, and you get to play as Catwoman in a side story as she goes after the Arkham City vault, which is also interesting and fun. The story will keep you occupied for around 14-16 hours with extra time if you go after collectables or do the extra challenges included, as well as an extra story DLC which I'll talk about after my rating since it contains spoilers.GAMEPLAY: Combat is fun, it feels satisfying, the only bad thing I can say of it is that I can see it getting a bit repetative. The gadgets are unique enough and let you do some fun stuff in and out of combat. The open world of Arkham City is fun to explore and there are some neat little easter eggs to look for if you're in the mood to find them. Overall, it's pretty fun to play as Batman, as well as Catwoman, who, while having less gadgets and less damage resistant as the Bats, is a lot more agile and is a lot of fun to play as as well. Just make sure to play this with a gamepad, it feels a lot better than a keyboard and mouse.GRAPHICS AND PERFORMANCE: The game looks really nice. I ran it on High Settings well enough at a playable enough framerate, though since my rig is kinda crappy it stutters a bit, though not as much as I thought it would. However, if you have a good PC, or at least anything better than mine, you will have no problem with it at all. The game looks good.CHARACTERS AND VOICE ACTING: Batman is voiced by the same actor who played him in the animated series back in 1997, Kevin Conroy, and he does a decent enough job in the role. Another notible reprisal from the animated series was Mark Hamill as The Joker, who was probably my favorite actor out of all of them, since Hamill did such a good job with him, being a crazy nutjob who's strangely enjoyable even though he's poisoned Batman. Other notable voice actors I have to point out were Corey Burton as Hugo Strange, Nolan North as The Penguin (who I didn't even realize was the voice actor of him until the credits, which is really impressive), Tara Strong as Harley Quinn, Grey DeLisle as Catwoman, and Troy Baker as Robin. All of the characters I mentioned and any notable ones I left out well acted and their character models are nice.EXTRAS: There is a Riddler Challenge Mode, which you unlock maps and miniature campaigns when you collect Riddler Trophies. You get the option to play as Batman, Catwoman, Robin, and Nightwing in these challenges, each having special objectives for you to go for. This can bloat your playing time out quite a bit if you want to go for 100% for all of the characters. I personally didn't care for this mode, but it can be amusing for some. The Riddler Trophies I mentioned earlier can also increase your gametime, and in order to get some of them you'll have to use gadgets and upgrades you'd get later on in the game, which is also neat. There are Riddles as well, which unlock stories of Arkham City and the characters in the game, and these are the most interesting collectibles for me.FINAL VERDICT: Batman Arkham City was an awesome game with a lot of awesome moments. If you want to feel like Batman, this is a good place to look at it. 9.5/10, just shy of perfection. The game is absolutely worth getting, it usually goes on sale for $5 on a big sale, which is totally worth it. Heck, it's worth the $20 it costs now.The following spoilers contains my review for the DLC included with the GOTY edition, Harley Quinn's Revenge, and, though I do not spoil the plot of what I look at, I will have to do it for the main game here, though none for the story DLC. These aren't minor spoilers either, this is the ending of the game here. If you finished the main game or if you don't care, go ahead and read on. If not, then just know it's a good DLC and you should play it since it's included with the GOTY editionSTORY: Batman is sent in to the Steel Mill, the former home of Joker's gang and the final area of Arkham City that the GCPD has not taken back due to resistance from the goons and the hostage taking of multiple police officers. When Batman goes in to rescue them, he is kidnapped by Harley Quinn, who blames Batman for the death of The Joker. The Batcave sends Robin in to rescue Batman from Harley and save the hostages. It isn't as grand as the main story, but it's fine enough and it has some neat moments and is some of the better story DLC I've seen. It'll give you another hour, maybe two, of gameplayGAMEPLAY: Batman is the same, nothing really notable to say about him. Robin, however, is not a Batman clone like I figured. He has some unique gadgets that you don't have as Batman that are pretty neat, he feels a lot like Batman with a bit more agility like Catwoman, and overall he's fun to play as.CHARACTERS AND VOICE ACTING: Harley Quinn gets a bit of a redesign, dressed up like a mourning widow, which is actually kind of sad. All notable voice actors return to this and do great jobs, Batman, Harley, and Robin's actors notably.FINAL VERDICT: It's a really good story DLC, it has some neat moments, and it does a good job overall. I'd say buy it, but it's included in the game anyways. Make sure to play it once you finish the story.  Had you ever considered that all this is your fault? Your presence creates these animals...

content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												Anyone stuck between buying this and the Return to Arkham remasters, I recommend you grab this version instead. The PC release remains the definitive version as the Return to Arkham remasters are absolute crap. I bought it for PlayStation 4 and it rarely exceeds 30fps, 1/3 of the time dropping into the low 20's. It's awful. While some lighting and textures look a bit better, the buttery smooth framerates you get on PC still outweigh the small graphical improvements the remasters bring. The framerate is unlocked on the console remasters so they do occasionally achieve 60fps in interiors but, again, the majority of the time it's 30fps or below. So stick with the PC version - it's the best. It also goes on sale like four times a year where you can usually pick it up for five bucks instead of paying fifty dollars an inferior console remaster.UPDATE:So they just patched Return to Arkham to 1.02 which puts a 30fps lock on Arkham City where it ran unlocked before. It's sad because, before this new patch, the PS4 Pro could run Arkham City around 45fps average, hitting 60fps in some interiors. So now you're stuck with 30fps forever. So, again, the PC version is still the best way to experience this game and the rest of this great series. I'd also like to recommend you give Arkham Origins a chance if you avoided it because of the reviews. I really think it's under rated. It's the first time The Joker and Batman meet in the series and they wrote it really well.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												It was okay. Initially I wasn't very happy about it, but it made up for that in the end. Recommending it because the ending and the Harley Quinn DLC were pertty good!Pro'sVisually the game really puts a nice dark tone, fitting for batman. It's really in a nice spot.The story's nice. It was entertaining enough to keep wanting to progress, which other games in this genre tend to have more problems with!Combat system was quite nice. I like to compare it to Assassin's creed and Shadow of Mordor, but I think those played out more nicely. But that's really nitpicking in details. More on that in the cons.The Harley Quinn DLC totally makes up a lot. It's got a completely new character to play (Robin) which plays awesomely, and it's actually relevant to the story (unlike the mandatory Catwoman side-missons that didn't really matter at all but you had to do anyway). It's also got a timed bomb defuse part which was actually tense and fun. This DLC really added a great deal to my view on this game entirely.Much attention to detail of the DC universe & fanserviceConsIt's not always clear what you need to do. For example, I ended up wandering around Dr. Freeze's laboratory for ages, clueless on what to do, when it simply turned out I had to leave the building.New skills are introduced often and in rapid succession, but really most of that is optional. I basically performed the same combo as in the first five minutes of the game. Counter and mash the attack button, easy wins.The combat animations (especially finishers) don't give you an invulnerability window, meaning that you can get hit if you want to finish somebody off. That only further fuels my previous arguement about counter & mash attack. You might say such a window would make it easier, but I don't think a mechanical point like that should be the the factor that makes this game harder. That leads me to my next point...Often times a boss battle or harder encounter, the game simply throws more bodies towards you to fight. I'd rather see 4-5 tough enemies than 30 essentially the same enemies. I realise that must be tough to make though.Lack of worthwhile puzzle elements. The only real puzzles in the game are riddler trophies, which by itself only unlock worthless challenge missions that aren't fun at all. I would have liked more puzzles in the actual storyline.There are like, a billion side missions in this game. I could literally not move from A to B without being thrown a whole lot of sidequests towards me all the time. After I finished the main storyline (and a little of the side-quests), the game says I only completed about 22% of the game. Whoah. Now if only those side-quests were interesting! Because the ones that I've tried really weren't. I'd much rather have liked a bigger, even more fleshed out storyline, making the storyline:sidequests ratio 80:20 instead of the other way around like it is now. The "stealth" system, if you can even call it that, was one of the worst ones I've played to date. Maybe I just didn't understand it (there is no explanation), but most moves, especially from hiding make a lot of sound which triggers everyone in the current room to run towards the victim. There is really only one move "silent takedown" that is a stealthy solution. Why give us so many gadgets and so many awesome moves, but leave stealth hanging with one move? Enemies would constantly notice me in impossible situations, but if I crash-landed right behind them, they wouldn't notice whatsoever. Oh and if you get caught? Just spam RB on your controller to grapple away, because obviously an enemy can't move his head and follow where you're going. Totally weird evasion tactic and the game even advises you to use it. Stealthy kills give you less XP than regular combat, and there are barely any riddler challenges for it. The detective system is essentially a wallhack which you turn on for 90% of the game if you're going for a stealth approach. That is a shame as you don't see the great attention to detail that has been put into Arkham City.The game is padded with a huge amount of extra stuff. Outfits, missions, challenges, new game plus, maps, and a whole lot more. That's great for a GOTY edition. However I think the Harley Quinn DLC should've been part of the main game (not that it made a difference for me specifically, but it really added to the game and it's a shame if you missed out on that). I'd rather have seen more attention and polish to the game itself than a lot of additions like this. Ideas would be a talent system, good/bad alignment system, currency system for gear, or a turf war system (between all the gangs controlling areas) et cetera.I'm totally aware people are going to bash on this review, because it's got a lot of criticism. Still, I think I'd recommend other games to people, unless they said they wanted to play a batman game specifically. But this game is not bad. It just didn't have the "WOW!"-factor for me.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2015
												Another great game by Rocksteady that is Batman: Arkham City. It is an action packed game and a great adventure along with some good writing.The core mechanics of this game are pretty much the same as it's predecessor Batman: Arkham Asylum. Nevertheless, it  feels great as some new additions were included like some more gadgets in your arsenal and movesets. It is set in an open-world, which is great as developers tried something entirely different from the concept of a limited asylum in Batman: Arkham Asylum. You again will feel like the Dark Knight as you overpower most of your enemies. Riddler's trophies are challenging and time consuming and they are not everyone's cup of tea but puzzle-solving is well doneThe main-story is very well told, the opening is great and the ending is very surprising. Overall. the story from the start to the middle and leading to the epic ending is told in a great way. Very good plot is there too. There are some side missions, most of them very well written and are engaging as will keep you occupied. Voice-acting is superb. Also since it's a Batman game one might expect great boss fights but like it's predecessor it lacks solid boss fights for the most part. The game looks great, as it is dark and gritty yet has comical art-style. It is a good-looking game for sure. Then there are challenges which are fun, they are there to show how slow the version of most people's Batman is. They are indeed challenging and are great for those who would like the arcade style of gameplay but those who don't like arcades might find it repetitive and boring. New Game Plus that you unlock after completing the main campaign is good as the enemies are more aggresive and the indicators of enemies are turned off but still in the end you know what is gonna happen so unpredictability factor in terms of it's story might not be liked my many but it still is more challenging than the main campaign. As you progress through the game you will earn rewards as character trophies and concept arts, which is decent.The DLCs like extra skin and challenge maps are not anything special but the Catwoman's DLC is pretty fun though it doesn't really add up to the story but it's a nice addition to the overall campaign. Harley Quinn's Revenge is a good DLC and continues after the events after the main campaign, and playing as Robin is really fun with different moves and gadgets.Batman: Arkham City is a well written game with fun brawlings and stealth as well.

												Arkham City took what made Asylum great and does it on a much grander scale. However, I feel the fan base would be split on whether Asylum or City is better. Asylum had a great atmospheric setting but City places Batman in a much larger world, full of things to do and discover. I personally prefer City, I feel it has a better plot and I prefer having a bigger open world over a small claustrophobic asylum. Having the City also allows you to use Batmans cape and gliding to full effect. Something I felt wasn't really used in Asylum.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												The combat system in this game really is unparalleled and bringing vigilante justice to large groups of criminals using an array of gadgets and jumping around beating them senseless is just pure fun. Guns, stun batons and armoured enemies all add a lot of variation to the combat and keeps it interesting and challenging. Playing as Catwoman also feels very different than batman as she has her own moves and bags of tricks.Gliding around in the open world of Gotham is both fast and fun and the games stealth system is very satisfying as well.The story is really good and has some really stellar voice actors that brings every character to life. You go up against plenty of the well known villains and Mr. Freeze is a special and very memorable boss fight.If you aren't already a fan of Batman, this game will make you one.
