content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
REVIEW: BATMAN: ARKHAM CITYHaving already played Batman: Arkham Asylum and been impressed, I found its sequel, Batman: Arkham City, for as cheap a price as its antecedent. So it was inevitable that, sooner or later, I’d play Batman: Arkham City. But would it be as good as its predecessor? Would it fall short of the mark? Or would it surpass it?Quincy Sharp, former warden of Arkham Asylum, is now the mayor of Gotham City, and he has authorised a daring plan: Arkham City, a walled-off part of Gotham where prison inmates have been left to fend for themselves. Bruce Wayne tries to stop it, only to find himself arrested and put into Arkham City by one of its leaders, Dr Hugo Strange, who knows that Wayne is none other than Batman. Thrown into a world where every criminal wants a piece of him, Wayne must become Batman once more, and find out what is going on. But every crime boss within the city has their own agenda. Two-Face and Penguin are vying over territory. Rumours abound of the Joker suffering from a terminal illness. Mr Freeze is locked away in an old GCPD building, working and researching. And the Riddler is making sadistic plans of his own. And behind it all, Dr Strange, the true power in Arkham City, is waiting for the opportunity to become a hero, even at a terrible cost. What is Protocol Ten? Will Catwoman help Batman? And can Batman untangle a web of lies, conspiracies, and destruction before it’s too late?Coming to Arkham City after playing Arkham Asylum, I find that the latter is almost like a proof-of-concept for the former. Arkham Asylum is an excellent game on its own merits, but now, it feels like I am playing the real game. The story is certainly more epic than that of its antecedent, and while it’s good by itself, it’s the extras that you can unlock that add even more depth to the story and its background. The story has more than a few shocking twists and turns, with a truly shocking ending that could mean the end of an era. The story of the DLC, Harley Quinn’s Revenge, is a little less satisfying, with Batman turning into more of a♥♥♥♥♥♥than is tolerable.I was impressed by the graphics of Arkham Asylum, but Arkham City is just that bit better. Once more, the character design is excellent, though the fetishisation of the female characters does happen once more (to a lesser degree at least) to Catwoman. However, the new incarnations of the other members of the rogues’ gallery, like Two-Face and Penguin, are quite enjoyable. Arkham City itself is a vast, sprawling part of a city that feels right, even if confined.Sound-wise, the game once again takes a jump forward. The voice acting is stellar, with Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill once more reprising the roles of Batman and the Joker, with Maurice LaMarche, Corey Burton, Martin Jarvis and Stana Katic also getting some pretty damned good roles. The music and sound effects are also all good, with Nick Arundel and Ron Fish’s score reminiscent of Hans Zimmer’s work on the Dark Knight Trilogy.Gameplay is where the game takes two steps forward and one step back. The game overall is far more enjoyable, with effectively a sandbox to explore, more gadgets, and more things to do, and more freedom when to do it. Unfortunately, the fact that the game was originally meant for a console comes back to bite it in the controls department, especially combat. Maybe it’s because I played on a higher difficulty this time, or maybe it was the new elements added (like armoured enemies), but I found combat harder than usual, and spiking in difficulty towards the end of the game. I lost many a battle, and had to have the extra edge of the health restored before going back into combat. In addition, the crouch controls, used for dive bombing, meant that I had to use my hand rather awkwardly for puzzles needing that, giving me RSI in my little finger. This made things unnecessarily frustrating, and took a point off what could have been a perfect game otherwise.This annoying tarnish aside, Batman: Arkham City is nonetheless an immensely enjoyable game. I certainly recommend it to any Batman fan out there, and certainly to any fans of a sandbox game with a difference.RATING: ****½

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												To keep it short: BUY THIS GAME.If I had to write a full report on it, I could easily fill at least two A4-pages and still there'd be stuff worth telling about.So I just point out some details I think are worth mentioning.The graphics is pretty nice. Lighting, atmosphere, textures, effects... They may be not as perfect as Crysis, but it still is a reference for most games.One thing I really have to mention, is the realistic animation of the characters. I think so far I did not see this kind of game, especially those featuring melee combat, with such perfect fight animations. Check out some videos on youtube or something, where you can see catwoman in a fight and you get the idea of smooth animation captioning.The mission design is also really good. There are some minor points in the story, where an unexperienced player, who does not listen to the dialogs, might not know exactly what to do... but for all others with a brain, the missions are really enjoyable.Although some mechanics get used again and again, I still did not end up bored, because the surroundings or the main story itself were such a motivation, I never thought "come on, I need something to do".Level design is pretty good, two. Although there is the one or another unexplainable venting shaft, the levels mostly feel organic and are always fair. Batman has enough possibilities and gadgets to give one the edge in every fight and to enable one, to make really cool looking fights, and withougt having to remember 100 button combos like in other games. The fighting system of Arkham Asylum was adapted and polished and is easy to learn (although it takes some time to master) and just looks awesome.Also the balancing is, in my opinion, great, too. On easy, even a newbie is able to complete the main story and on hard and/or the New Game Plus (after finishing the campaign once) you really have to think on what is the most efficient way to beat those thugs and you have to use most of the gadgets to succeed..Also noteworthy: On New Game plus, the enemies are not just "stronger" (more health that is), like in most games. But they are more, they have better equipment and - most importantly - you are missing the "attack" icons over their hads. That nees some training first, but in the end it really adds immersity to the game, especially due to the fine character animations, which always gives you a fair amount of time to react accordingly to the situation.The dialogs. The dialogs...The main story itself is gorgeous (and I won't spoiler a thing about it). But those commentaries from Joker are really the best. There are so many puns and wordplays, I ended up laughing on nearly every "call" from Joker.And not only him: The "idle" dialogs of all those thugs standing around in Arkham and (story) dialogs with other characters like Catwoman are really worth listening. I catched myself upon just standing around for some time after entering a new region to just listen if there are some funny comments from those brainless guys.I recommend playing this game with a Xbox 360 controller.On my first play through, I used mouse and keyboard, which are implemented really good. But to give one an edge is some of the harder fights, the controller is still the better choice; this is mostly to the easier (quick-)use of all those fine gadgets of batman.If there ever was a game, which I'd have to give 100/100, it would be this one.Of course there are litte, tiny things, a game QA could still find. But you'd have to really search for them and, since they do not interfere with the game experience in any way you can easily make it a 99/100 ;)So don't think about it too long; buy this game and ENJOY!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2014
												While still a good game, with an "open world" setting, I found it inferior to Asylum. Sometimes bigger just means more filler, and that's what a lot of the game unfortunately felt like for me. Combat, and especially the SOUND of punching dudes, was a lot worse than in AA, and felt really unsatisfying at times, although I liked a lot of the upgrades. It seems the devs forgot everything that made the sound of Asylum great and did something "else" in City. It's just "off", like a lot of the punches are softened up, sounding like rubber hitting against rubber, while in Arkham you could almost hear the bone shatter when punching people. I also completed the well enough put together main story (too?) quickly, resulting in me doing some Riddler and Side Mission "chores" after the big reveal/ending of the main story, which became quite boring after a while.Anyway, happy to finally have completed it and I would definitely recommend it - I guess it's just a case of Asylum setting the bar so high, that to follow up with something better is almost impossible. Definitely worth your time and money.

content:
Posted: January 27
												I really enjoyed Arkham City. It's a lot like Asylum, but set in a larger open world environment, and the plot is absolutely insane/nonsensical. I used a controller this time (I used keyboard/mouse in Asylum) and found it much better for this game, since it's basically an open world cinematic fighting game and you don't really have to precisely aim at anything, ever. Flying around the city as Batman is fun, though the banter of the thugs is kind of annoying; they are all very chatty all the time. No one ever just shuts up, it seems. Also, they aren't afraid of Batman. Random inmates even taunt Batman if they see him, trying to get you to come down and fight them for some reason.I really enjoyed the game, though I think Asylum has a much better plot and is more focused. This game has more refined combat mechanics, though. The game has a lot of side quests where you fight various random Batman series villains, which is odd because Batman is (per the story, anyway) in quite a rush to finish the game before dying. I didn't do many side quests. The combat was fun, especially once you get a variety of gadgets and fight different enemy types.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2015
												I wish I could give Arkham City a 10/10; I really do, because I really love the game. It took everything Arkham Asylum did beautifully and refined it to the point of perfection--except for one thing.The camera. Just look at my profile and for the two Arkham City "Broken Camera" videos to see what I mean. When you're in intense combat, you can pretty much count on the camera doing little more than spinning around in circles, with no disregard at all for where enemies are located, which can and will cause you to take cheap hits. That's especially a problem in things like Joker's Carnival, but it's an issue in the other challenges, too. Turning off Camera Assist, from what I've experienced, has no effect at all; it changes nothing. If you somehow haven't played Arkham City, what are you waiting for? I've 100%'d the game on 360, and here I am again, going through the trouble again. It's THAT good of a game. 9/10.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
REVIEW: BATMAN: ARKHAM CITYHaving already played Batman: Arkham Asylum and been impressed, I found its sequel, Batman: Arkham City, for as cheap a price as its antecedent. So it was inevitable that, sooner or later, I’d play Batman: Arkham City. But would it be as good as its predecessor? Would it fall short of the mark? Or would it surpass it?Quincy Sharp, former warden of Arkham Asylum, is now the mayor of Gotham City, and he has authorised a daring plan: Arkham City, a walled-off part of Gotham where prison inmates have been left to fend for themselves. Bruce Wayne tries to stop it, only to find himself arrested and put into Arkham City by one of its leaders, Dr Hugo Strange, who knows that Wayne is none other than Batman. Thrown into a world where every criminal wants a piece of him, Wayne must become Batman once more, and find out what is going on. But every crime boss within the city has their own agenda. Two-Face and Penguin are vying over territory. Rumours abound of the Joker suffering from a terminal illness. Mr Freeze is locked away in an old GCPD building, working and researching. And the Riddler is making sadistic plans of his own. And behind it all, Dr Strange, the true power in Arkham City, is waiting for the opportunity to become a hero, even at a terrible cost. What is Protocol Ten? Will Catwoman help Batman? And can Batman untangle a web of lies, conspiracies, and destruction before it’s too late?Coming to Arkham City after playing Arkham Asylum, I find that the latter is almost like a proof-of-concept for the former. Arkham Asylum is an excellent game on its own merits, but now, it feels like I am playing the real game. The story is certainly more epic than that of its antecedent, and while it’s good by itself, it’s the extras that you can unlock that add even more depth to the story and its background. The story has more than a few shocking twists and turns, with a truly shocking ending that could mean the end of an era. The story of the DLC, Harley Quinn’s Revenge, is a little less satisfying, with Batman turning into more of a♥♥♥♥♥♥than is tolerable.I was impressed by the graphics of Arkham Asylum, but Arkham City is just that bit better. Once more, the character design is excellent, though the fetishisation of the female characters does happen once more (to a lesser degree at least) to Catwoman. However, the new incarnations of the other members of the rogues’ gallery, like Two-Face and Penguin, are quite enjoyable. Arkham City itself is a vast, sprawling part of a city that feels right, even if confined.Sound-wise, the game once again takes a jump forward. The voice acting is stellar, with Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill once more reprising the roles of Batman and the Joker, with Maurice LaMarche, Corey Burton, Martin Jarvis and Stana Katic also getting some pretty damned good roles. The music and sound effects are also all good, with Nick Arundel and Ron Fish’s score reminiscent of Hans Zimmer’s work on the Dark Knight Trilogy.Gameplay is where the game takes two steps forward and one step back. The game overall is far more enjoyable, with effectively a sandbox to explore, more gadgets, and more things to do, and more freedom when to do it. Unfortunately, the fact that the game was originally meant for a console comes back to bite it in the controls department, especially combat. Maybe it’s because I played on a higher difficulty this time, or maybe it was the new elements added (like armoured enemies), but I found combat harder than usual, and spiking in difficulty towards the end of the game. I lost many a battle, and had to have the extra edge of the health restored before going back into combat. In addition, the crouch controls, used for dive bombing, meant that I had to use my hand rather awkwardly for puzzles needing that, giving me RSI in my little finger. This made things unnecessarily frustrating, and took a point off what could have been a perfect game otherwise.This annoying tarnish aside, Batman: Arkham City is nonetheless an immensely enjoyable game. I certainly recommend it to any Batman fan out there, and certainly to any fans of a sandbox game with a difference.RATING: ****½

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												The last great Batman game to be released. Everything is vastly improved from the original with expanded combat mechanics, abilities, looks better. The story is still as intrigueing and compelling as the original was. I did feel that there was a little bit missing or different thanks to the more open world approach to the game over the older, more linear first game as it felt more contained and/or polished. That's barely a nitpick to concern yourself. If you want a great brawler with beautiful graphics, smooth gameplay and very responsive controls. Batman Origins is a massive step back, a step back so much it's more like a running leap to very unpolished in comparison to this game. That is why Arkham City is a game I'd consider the last, great, Batman game.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												The combat system in this game really is unparalleled and bringing vigilante justice to large groups of criminals using an array of gadgets and jumping around beating them senseless is just pure fun. Guns, stun batons and armoured enemies all add a lot of variation to the combat and keeps it interesting and challenging. Playing as Catwoman also feels very different than batman as she has her own moves and bags of tricks.Gliding around in the open world of Gotham is both fast and fun and the games stealth system is very satisfying as well.The story is really good and has some really stellar voice actors that brings every character to life. You go up against plenty of the well known villains and Mr. Freeze is a special and very memorable boss fight.If you aren't already a fan of Batman, this game will make you one.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2016
												Alright, Arkham City and a comparison with Arkham Asylum:Pros:- The core gameplay is better. Animations and combat are more fluid. You will also fight a lot more enmies now, several at a time even. Pretty cool actually. You are also able to play as Catwoman at certain points.- Gadgets and movement: Almost all of the gadgets from the first game are back and some available from the start. Others are upgraded. You can easily forget you have a certain ability, because there are so many...- The story is pretty good and acted very well- Boss fights are even better than Arkham Asylum- Cool side missions- Interesting riddles are back   Cons:- The game is a bit bloated imho. There are 400 (!!!!!!!!) riddles and trophies and "destructibles" like Joker teeth and other stuff + about 50 Catwoman trophies. What is "worse" is that the Riddler side quests are again linked with finding a certain amount of riddles and trophies (all for the final confrontation). That confrontation is cool, but it's just too much wasted time. Half the number of stuff would have been sufficient. Instead you're stopping every 5 meters to try and grab another trophy. To do so you have to use your gadgets and/or Riddler pressure plates and other stuff. They are cool, but just too many.- These trophies also unlock character art, background stories and Strange interrogation tapes, but again, you need to find all of the trophies...kinda. *sigh* Too much ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.- Some parts of the map are hard to get to if you're just trying to gather trophies.- Finding all the trophies either requires a very very good eye and dedication or you need to find all the "green" guards and extract the locations from them. Finding the Riddler map in Arkham Asylum was a lot better and less stressful.- Respawning guards. This is majorly annoying. Enemies just keep respawning and respawning. You can dispatch them pretty easily, but it still gets old after several hours.If you're just here for the base game and some side missions, great game. If you want to 100% that♥♥♥♥♥♥ omg, prepare for a long slog of trying to find all the stupid stuff.Apart from that there's only the "riddler challenge missions" outside the base game. Just as in Arkham Asylum you have to complete a series of combat or stalker missions and you can earn medals for that. You unlock these challenges through gathering the Riddler stuff in the game...again. Imho that's still not very compelling, but if you're desperate for a bit more fighting, go ahead.DLC Edit: There's more Riddler combat DLC, letting you play as Catwoman, Robin and Nightwing. To be honest the characters don't control any differently. They have some moves that vary (gadgets only really), but apart from that it is the exact same combat flow, so I don't really see the point. Fun for a few minutes but nothing more.Harley Quinn's Revenge: A solo DLC, extremely linear. Takes place at the Steel Mill. There's no level ups, no free roaming, nothing. You have to beat certain enemies, do certain things, etc. All in all about 2 hours of content, alternating between Batman and Robin. In the actual game mode Robin is fun to play since he does solve problems differently than Batman, just as with Catwoman in the base game. Too bad you couldn't play him and Nightwing in the base game. Might have been some compelling story telling as well. Missed opportunity. But a decent DLC detailing the events after Arkham City.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												Batman: Arkham City was my introduction to the Arkham series and I have absolutely loved playing it. It has very nice graphics, an interesting story, multitudes of familiar characters, engaging dialogue and voice acting, and a well designed open world that is large enough to enjoy exploring, yet small enough to become familiar with. It can take a while to get between objectives on the map, so I would expect to spend at least 1-2 minutes in transit everytime you need to cross the map.On the other hand, I was miserable with some of the combat. I found in this game that the most challenging thing was appropriately timing my counters and evades amidst my strikes and other moves. I played all the way through on Normal, then completed New Game Plus mode on Normal, and I would have liked to get the Perfect Knight 2 achievement for 100% completion, but I cannot stand the combat scoring. Riddler's Revenge (other than the predator maps) is the least appealing part of the game for me. However, I did like playing a DLC of the batcave and would have enjoyed more interaction with the batcave. If you enjoy this game's style of combat, there's a lot of rich content available for you to explore and personal records to set and break.Overall, I loved getting to know the story arc and I found myself really motivated to play New Game Plus, demonstrating a fair amount of replay value. There were a lot of delightful dialogue parallels that I had failed to notice in my first playthrough, such as when Batman repeats Catwoman's "broke a nail" line. Also, I enjoyed optimizing my routes across the map and through levels as well as my combat strategies and boss fights. Despite my significant dislike of and struggle with the combat system, I found the game fun and really worthwhile.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												I was batman at first flying everywhere. Then I did some major stuff to become the dark knight and at the end I rose to be the best. xD This game is amazing. Batman simulator 2011 and its really gives you a great feel of being batman. You have all the cool gadgets and can do the amazing things that you could only see in the trilogy and comics before. The story fits in pretty accuratly to both the movie and the comics. The progressions makes it so interesting that you want to know whats gonna happen next. Most importantly, you can never have nothing to do in this game. Even if you finish the story the side missions tie in so well that it seems like a continuation of the life of BatmanThe other aspects of the game are great to. The graphics work even on a laptop and are streamlined yet stunning. The scenic takedowns made you satisfied with your hard work. And, the levelling up system was great for variation in tactics. You can be sneaky bat or muscle bat both payed off. As for the DLC:It's like a practice during the competition maps and the Catwoman sections were pretty exciting and the opportunity to have 2 metas is definately great. They tie in well and each of the characters are interesting in their varying gadgets.cons:nothing to major to report except for if you have a touch scroll mouse. (can't use middle mouse for some weapons)theres also the fact that sometimes the ai becomes to strong with excessive guns(but thats my opinion it makes sense story wise)Reccomendation:If you dont have it yet, a) its not too late b) your missiong out on life c)cmon its BATMAN NANANANANNANANANANA BATMAN

content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												Author's Notes: I've just recently replayed Arkham City for the 4th time (Once on PC and the other three on Xbox 360) so, I think it's time for me to review this. Batman: Arkham City is a sequel Arkham Asylum and really captures what a sequel should be. For starters, the story was absolutely fantastic. I won't go into a lot of detail with the story, but basically Batman is in Arkham City, trying to prevent it from falling into utter chaos because of the forces that threaten it (Mainly the Joker and Hugo Strange). Along with a fantastic story, the game also brings awesome voice actors (Such as Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill) and brings some great soundtrack work along for the ride. The Batman Arkham series is known not only for its awesome actors and great story, but also for its great fighting mechanics. The fighting mechanics that are present in this one feel even better than Asylum's. The fighting feels a little more fluid and also is even more responsive. There are even new fighting skills to unlock and the moves have been spiced up. The AI in this game is pretty great as well. They aren't your average stupid AI at times, which adds some difficulty to the game. Just like Asylum, City has some stealth segments that are really well done and are very fun! You can hide in the floor vents, blow up a wall behind a thug, and even preform those awesome inverted takedowns from the 1st game.Being that this is a Batman game, there are indeed gadgets. If you've played the previous game, you'll recognize some of them, such as the iconic batarang and grappling hook, along with the batclaw and explosive gem. City also adds some new gadgets, such as a remote gun jammer and freeze grenades. These new additions add some fun moments and provide more variety for taking out thugs. Along with fighting thugs, you'll also fight Batman's villains. There are a fair amount of boss fights in this game! None of them are really hard, but they are fun. Each boss has a weakness so, it's just a matter of finding it. The boss fights provided here are probably some of the best in the series! Another awesome element added in this game was the open world aspect. The city is filled with thugs to beat up, side missions to complete, and Ridder trophies and riddles to find and solve. You really do feel like Batman gliding around the city when you play through the game! The open world aspect adds a lot of fun to be had and a lot of replayablilty. The side missions are really good and are definitely worth checking out. Now, since this is the game of the year edition, it comes with all of the dlc. There's a story dlc for Harley Quinn, which is really fun and well made (I recommend playing it after you defeat the main story though). Also, the Catwoman dlc is present in the game. The Catwoman dlc adds a different dynamic to the game and allows you to play as a different character, other than Batman. It provides a nice break in between segments and gives you a good look at what happens in other parts of the city when Batman is off doing his thing. Also, when you defeat the main story, you unlock all of the skins, which are nice to mess around with. (There's also a way to get them before completing the main story ;) ). In all, Arkham City is what a sequel should be, it improved upon what was previously there and also added new mechanics and really spiced things up. If you haven't played Arkham Asylum, I recommend playing it first, but this one is definitely the best in the series! This game is easily one of my favorite games I've played ever. I highly recommend checking it out (There's even a demo), because who doesn't want to be Batman?

content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												Author's Notes: I've just recently replayed Arkham City for the 4th time (Once on PC and the other three on Xbox 360) so, I think it's time for me to review this. Batman: Arkham City is a sequel Arkham Asylum and really captures what a sequel should be. For starters, the story was absolutely fantastic. I won't go into a lot of detail with the story, but basically Batman is in Arkham City, trying to prevent it from falling into utter chaos because of the forces that threaten it (Mainly the Joker and Hugo Strange). Along with a fantastic story, the game also brings awesome voice actors (Such as Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill) and brings some great soundtrack work along for the ride. The Batman Arkham series is known not only for its awesome actors and great story, but also for its great fighting mechanics. The fighting mechanics that are present in this one feel even better than Asylum's. The fighting feels a little more fluid and also is even more responsive. There are even new fighting skills to unlock and the moves have been spiced up. The AI in this game is pretty great as well. They aren't your average stupid AI at times, which adds some difficulty to the game. Just like Asylum, City has some stealth segments that are really well done and are very fun! You can hide in the floor vents, blow up a wall behind a thug, and even preform those awesome inverted takedowns from the 1st game.Being that this is a Batman game, there are indeed gadgets. If you've played the previous game, you'll recognize some of them, such as the iconic batarang and grappling hook, along with the batclaw and explosive gem. City also adds some new gadgets, such as a remote gun jammer and freeze grenades. These new additions add some fun moments and provide more variety for taking out thugs. Along with fighting thugs, you'll also fight Batman's villains. There are a fair amount of boss fights in this game! None of them are really hard, but they are fun. Each boss has a weakness so, it's just a matter of finding it. The boss fights provided here are probably some of the best in the series! Another awesome element added in this game was the open world aspect. The city is filled with thugs to beat up, side missions to complete, and Ridder trophies and riddles to find and solve. You really do feel like Batman gliding around the city when you play through the game! The open world aspect adds a lot of fun to be had and a lot of replayablilty. The side missions are really good and are definitely worth checking out. Now, since this is the game of the year edition, it comes with all of the dlc. There's a story dlc for Harley Quinn, which is really fun and well made (I recommend playing it after you defeat the main story though). Also, the Catwoman dlc is present in the game. The Catwoman dlc adds a different dynamic to the game and allows you to play as a different character, other than Batman. It provides a nice break in between segments and gives you a good look at what happens in other parts of the city when Batman is off doing his thing. Also, when you defeat the main story, you unlock all of the skins, which are nice to mess around with. (There's also a way to get them before completing the main story ;) ). In all, Arkham City is what a sequel should be, it improved upon what was previously there and also added new mechanics and really spiced things up. If you haven't played Arkham Asylum, I recommend playing it first, but this one is definitely the best in the series! This game is easily one of my favorite games I've played ever. I highly recommend checking it out (There's even a demo), because who doesn't want to be Batman?

content:
Posted: March 15
												If you are checking reviews to see if this game is worth buying or not, I would advise you to stop and buy Arkham Knight, if your computer can handle it of course. As of writing this review it is priced the same, and Arkham Knight is a lot more in depth and is all around better, but this game is still a must have and will go down in history.Arkham City is the game that fully got me into playing video games. Granted, I played minecraft once or twice when it first came out, but it just wasn't my game and at the time it made me assume I wouldn't like any video game. I still remember going over my friends house, who at the time was the only friend of mine who had a PS3, he liked to brag about it even though he just got it and a lot of other people had it too. (this next part is a huge spoiler for the story so don't put your mouse over it if you don't want a spoiler)  I remember ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ my pants when Freeze attacks you and I made my friend play through his fight for me I remember all the times I went over his house and played, and I never really did much after the story missions. I just restarted the game, over and over again. I've beaten Arkham City about 50 times and I decided to come back a little bit ago. Of course, I had to adjust from playing Arkham Knight to Arkham City, they are very very different. I didn't want to buy the Return To Arkham, because even though it has Arkham City and Asylum, the improved graphics and bad times on Arkham Asylum drew me to just buy Arkham City.As soon as I started up the game, the nostalgia was so intense, I could still remember most of the puzzles at the first few missions and their answers, helping me to get some riddler trophies easier at the start. Although, what really made me want to share how good of a game this is was the parts I didn't remember. Doing whatever you can, wether it be stupid or smart, to try to solve a puzzle is so much fun. Some of the puzzles are pretty difficult and fun to try to get through, especially because they don't hinder your progress in the story.Another amazing feature of this game is the flawless execution of stealh. One reason I would recommened Arkham Knight over this game is that in Arkham Knight you startle enemies when you appear out of nowhere, giving you a second to react, wether it be attacking them or preforming a takedown. Although, in Arkham City, they instantly react to you, which is one of the only stealth flaws. There are many options on how you take people down, wether it be attack and run away, silent takedowns, or knocking them out with one of your many tools, this game is very in depth. You can even play "Riddler Challenges" which let you play different stealth and combat missions with added objectives.My final reason to buy this game is the amazing combat. Its not flawless, but it is very well put together. You have a second to react to being attacked, and there are multiple kinds of enemies. There are thugs, thugs with shields, thugs with shock batons, titans, brutes, armored thugs, and sometimes you even fight armed thugs head to head. All of the different types of enemies are taken out differently, making combat more than just button mashing. Any thugs with nothing in their hands will pick up bats, shields, shock batons, and really anything dropped by their allies that you took out.Overall this game is amazing and I would give it 9/10

content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												Arkham City is a rare sequel that is better than the original game. It takes everything that worked well in Asylum, improved on it, and added more of everything. More puzzles, more villains, more interaction with characters from the comics, etc. I enjoyed the Catwoman DLC woven into the main storyline, as it served to break up the monotony of playing as Batman.I like that at the end of the game free roaming mode is unlocked as well as the ability to swap characters in and out. But, I think that it sucks that both of the other DLC characters aren't also implimented in free roaming mode without mods. There's a character swap mechanic already in place, so I doubt it would have been difficult to do.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												A game which is kinda cool in that it's Batman in an "open-world" environment, but unlike Asylum, it's not really as well-designed? There's a lot of dumb moves in here that just leave me groaning (or in a couple of cases, screaming in rage because they just suddenly 'turn on' an ability I've had all game that never worked prior), and I won't lie: this game has serious issues with women.I'd say get it if you dug Asylum, since it's got a lot of the same gameplay, tightened up... but mother of god, this is one of the few times I'll say a game has TOO MUCH content. Puzzle-based collectables everywhere! An ever-increasing number of challenge modes to take on and score attack! Sidequests that range from really cool (some of the actual detective work for the "World's Greatest Detective", the Bane arc and its final fight rocked) to abominably bad (the Hatter, Hush, and Calendar Man can go screw off, those were blatant filler).

												Batman Arkam City is the sequal to Arkham Asylum.  If you like Asylum you'll love City.  An entire section of Gotham City has been turned into a prison.  What could go wrong?  Now villians are trying to take over and Batman must stop them.  Loaded with new gadgets and larger world you'll have lots to do.  In Arkham Asylum you had to pretty much run to everything but in Arkham City you have the skyline as your playground and you can glide and mount rooftops.  There's secrets to find and it has a great storyline.  Also, a certain clown didn't forget what happened at the asylum.Pros:+Gameplay+Graphics+Gadgets and Fighting+Music+Voice Actors+Able to take out enemies in stealt+Larger world / open worldCons:-Calender Man achievement takes forever to get, unless you know how to fool the game into cheating time.

Posted: June 14, 2015
												A great Batman game, but I still feel that it is somewhat inferior to Arkham Asylum. Not by much, I just simply feel the first game was better. The city is vast, but uninteresting, unlike the small, compact, density of the Asylum.All in all, a worthy successor. But I feel that Arkham City trades 'open world' for quality. And in my opinion, quality over quantity is always the winner. If you're a fan of the first game, then you'll love Arkham City. If you are a fan of Batman, ditto. Basically anyone should be able to enjoy this game, there's absolutely nothing wrong with it.So yes, I recommend this game. I wouldn't say it's a must play, but if you like good games, here you go, here's one of 'em. For $20, you'd be hard pressed to find something too much better.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												The second game in the "Arkham" trilogy. The combat system is pretty simple. If you don't already know you have one button to "strike" and another to "counter" with the ability to mix various gadgets in your combos rather fluently. There are also stealth sections throughout the game though they are pretty bland and don't have very much depth in my opinion. You are offered various methods of taking people down in the stealth sections, but I don't see much reason to use them when a silent takedown is the simplest, most effective way of taking enemies down. Basically, this game is a continuation of the story of Arkham Asylum with a few improvements of gameplay. There are more gadgets,upgrades, and collectables. As well as an open world setting and much more side content than Arkham Asylum. The atmosphere of the game is fantastic and I even 100% the main game. I say "main game" because this game has a♥♥♥♥♥♥load of DLC characters that can only be played in "challenge maps" which in reality are more frustrating than fun to play. There is only 1 story DLC, but it's short and rather unfulfilling. I still think this is a good buy as nothing in the game except the DLC is conceptually worse then Arkham Asylum. A good buy for people intrested in the series.

												It's hard to top an already good game.But it's even harder to top a near perfect game.But Arkham City does exactly that.It takes the all the mechanics of the Arkham Asylum and applies it on a whole city with perfection.If you haven't played this game by now...then you either don't like superheroes or games in general(thus rendering my review pretty much useless).Pros-+An exciting,varied and exhilarating campaign.+Stellar cast of voice actors.+Story and writing is remarkable.+Traversing the city is sheer joy.+Improves a lot features of it's predecessor.+Boss fight's are splendid (I am looking at you Mr.Freeze).+Decent amount of side missions.+Mainly it preserves the feeling of being Batman like it's predecessor and adds toppings.Score-10/10If you somehow haven't played this game by now...you really really really should.It just one of those games that make you proud about your hobby.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												While I admit I prefer RPG's such as Final Fantasy (Ok, more like old school Final Fantasy), I do love a good Action/Adventure game when done right. The Batman Arkham City game drew my interest because it's Batman, one of the best DC characters of all time. And they did an awesome job making the game, it has dark but great graphics, an interesting (mostly in a good way) fighting system and little challenges sprinkled throughout the game with the Riddler trophies. For the most part the game is pure awesome, though it does have it's bad parts. You can't officially play as Nightwing or Robin in the main game, only in the little challenge maps which is kind of annoying as I kind of believe that they would have made a great addition to the main story of the game. Also, Batgirl (I know Barbara is still Oracle in this game but there was more than just barb as Batgirl) would have been nice to have to.The biggest gripe I have about this game is that it can seem a little repetitive at times which may be more me than the game as many people don't find the game as repetitive as I do. Still, there is plenty to do in the game and it is kind of cool to be able to play as Catwoman later in the game which helps break up the monotony a bit. Still, the game deserves at least an 8 out of 10 for everything that it does right and all of the cool gadgets you get to play around with.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
												Batman Arkham City GOTY is perhaps the greatest superhero video game ever to be released. It is very hard for me to find words to describe just how beautiful this game (a dream come true to any batman fan).The free-flow combat is absolutely superb, it is by far the most well-made in any video game of this genre in my opinion and is guaranteed to give you tons of fun if you like these type of games.The graphics and sound of this game are just outstanding. I mean for the time it was released (back in 2011), the game was absolutely magnificient. This is just my opnion, but i think even to this day, the game still looks superb.As i said above, this game is a dream come true to any batman fan. You can find almost every well-known hero/villain (batman, robin, catwoman, joker, two-face, mr. freeze and more, riddler and more) in this game, and the story that you go through is very good.If you are a batman fan like me or if you just want a good superhero game, i recommend this game with all my heart. It is truly a masterpiece in every way.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												Batman Arkham City is the second installment in Rocksteady's Batman Arkham series and it had a lot to live up to following it's predecessor Batman Arkham Asylum. It improved upon almost every aspect of the game and lived up to its expectations receiving 2011's Game of the Year award.What I liked: Big new map to explore as Batman and Catwoman Excellently written sequel that is of better quality and longer than the original Improved combat system with more moves, more upgrades and more awesome Same incredible attention to detail as the first Riddler returns with more riddles and his own side missions Twice the content as the first gameWhat I didn't like: The combat and predator challenges can become quite tedious after having to play them over and over again as 4 different charactersRocksteady have done it again with more quality content and added DLC characters, challenges and a short campaign you'll easily clock up 50+ hours if you want to 100% this game. 10/10

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												It's hard to believe that the first game could be improved on so much but it is. This game is just like the first but better in every area. The first and biggest thing I noticed was how much more fluid the controls and movement are. Arkham Asylum had some of the most fluid controls I've ever seen and this is even better. Even more fluid combat, faster grappling, and all around more precise easier movement. The graphics are better too. Asylum was really grey and dull throughout most of it but this one looks a little more colorful and lively. The whole city's layout is designed very well. Another big-time improvement: the overhead map is filled with challenges and side missions that you can select as waypoints now. The first game was pretty good but this one is great. They took great care and put great detail in these games to show the Batman universe and all the characters. It really feels like they left nothing out, so hardcore Batman fans will love this stuff. These Batman games are some of the best action beat-em-ups of all time. Simply some of the best combat and gameplay that money can buy. 9/10

content:
Posted: October 18, 2013
												Batman arham city is the sequel to the great arham asylum game but is it as good as the first one ? This time the caped crusader is held captive in a squared off part of gotham city called Arham city where all the criminals roam free. Joker catches batman and infects him with the titan virus and plus Hugo Strange wants to iniciate a plan called protocol 10. So Batman must stop Hugo Strange and get the cure for himselff. The gameplay is similar to the first game with the addition of new gadgets that can make up for a good time. Also this time there are side quests to be completed and Riddler trophies to be found. This game is a better game than the first for sure if you have the money you need to get this i give Batman arham city 10/10Now the Dlc Harleys quinns revenge. This dlc takes place after the events of Arham city and you play as Robin on the travel to find out what happend to batman. This is a great story pack for batman arham city and its fun as hell and Robin is a badass in this one so overall a great piece of content i give this dlc a 8/10

content:
Posted: April 10, 2016
												This is my first review for a steam game as I only like to review games if they are either really, really bad or really, really good. As you can probably tell by the thumb up, this game is really, really good! Some reviewers are complaining that the game doesn't run well or keeps crashing on them but with my play through of the main story the game only let me down twice due to it crashing. This only happened from about 5 minutes in on the game and was probably caused from myself running multiple applications in the background. Arkham City is probably my favourite Batman game, alongside Arkham Knight (which I have 100% twice now with all achievements on Xbox one) and I wish to 100% this game too, once I bring myself to the fact that I have to collect all of those damn riddler trophies! Please just buy this game and play it!!

												Batman Arkham City is way better than its predecessor. The gameplay mechanics has been improved, the combat system has been refined, and it's pretty hard if you play it on the max difficulty. The villains are very characterized, and the story is great (I loved the gothic atmosphere). The world is not huge, but you're free to explore it between the main missions. From a technical point of view the game is just amazing. I'd definitely recommend to buy this game.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												The epic, soaring music. The arguably greatest graphics of the year. The predictably stellar voice acting, but with a particularly perverse performance by Mark Hamill as the Joker and especially enjoyable take by Nolan North on the Penguin. The menus filled with bonus short stories that address any questions you might have assumed were left unanswered. The Riddler’s Revenge mode that challenges you to clear a room of enemies using specific equipment or strategy. The clever little choices, like having the Bat signal be your custom waypoint marker. Even the bosses are cool this time.Batman: Arkham Asylum was the greatest superhero game of all time. The sequel, Batman: Arkham City, is five times bigger and about a billion times better. You do the math.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												It's a great Batman story and it's a great game. I don't know why I ignored it for so long.The combat feels like some cinematic beat em up. I initially found it a bit simple, but it gets more and more varied as the game goes on and by the end you feel like a total badass Batman as you beat the crap out of hordes of Arkham inmates.The longer you can dish out punishment without taking a hit yourself, the more XP and rewards you get. The result are fights that feel not just satisfying, but seriously fun as well. Though stealth is also a viable and encouraged option too.Being Batman, there's a ton of gadgets you use to advance through the game and solve Riddler puzzles that are scattered like completionist crack all over the city. These puzzles break up the combat in a nice way, and together with the side-missions, form a great open world.The devs not only seem very up on their Batman mythology, they also managed to get the actors from The Animated Series to lend their voices to the game. The result is an experience that feels right, feels like a Batman game should, and is thoroughly addictive.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2013
												Objectively the best western action game ever made.The core gameplay is compromised of a simple but excellent combat system, a very active and satisfying stealth system, and some very decent platforming aspects that make movement feel fluid and interesting.The combat system is built around hitting enemies with combos and countering and dodging their attacks. Eventually, once you get your combo multiplier up to a high enough point you'll be able to do a powerful combo move, like one that stuns a whole group of enemies, or another that you can use to instantly knock out a single enemy. Or, you can save your combo multiplier and get it even higher in order to benefit from a passive buff to your attack and movement speed, allowing you to tear through entire clusters of enemies if you're good enough. While the core combat is relatively simple, a lot of depth is added to it by the gadget system. The player is given 12 gadgets to use, and they all have at least one role in both combat and sneaking, and many are even useful for general exploration. Proper use of gadgets can make or break fights in this game.On the topic of sneaking, Arkham City is also a very good stealth game. The stealth gameplay is both engaging and difficult, and the player will never find a moment where they are left without something to do in a stealth scenario. The speed of it, combined with the utility of gadgets and the neatly implemented detection and noise mechanics provide the stealth with a very high skill ceiling, and plenty of space for the player to master and exploit advanced mechanics.Usually, stealth and combat encounters are clearly segregated, however there are points in the game where the player can make a decision between either as they see fit. This ties in to the free-form nature of the game. Arkham City is a sandbox game, and a very good one at that. The entire map is open to the player from the get-go, with the player free to explore, fight and do side-missions as they see fit.On top of the quality of the core gameplay, Arkham City also has loads upon loads of content. The main story itself lasted me well over 30-40 hours, and it's got very good replay value given the caliber of the gameplay and the open-ended nature of the game. Besides the main story, there is also a very large amount of challenges for each character, in both combat and stealth varieties, truly pushing players to their limits in all aspects of the gameplay. There's four (that's right, four) playable characters, each with their own gadgets, combos and challenges, and there's also an (albeit poor) official DLC extension to the game's story.Speaking of story, Arkham City's plot and writing are pretty good. Many famous Batman characters are given roles in the game, everything makes sense and is in-character, and there are even a few interesting twists at points. The game even pays very good homage to classic Batman characters and media, such as with the costume pack that includes costumes from classic Batman entries like Batman Beyond and The Dark Knight Returns, and the heaps upon heaps of backstory provided for characters and locations within Gotham.The game also exceeds in almost every other aspect. The soundtrack is atmospheric and fitting, even dynamic, matching the gameplay. The graphics are very advanced, with detail including visible snowflakes on your character's body. The artstyle (and architecture) is a very excellent combination of staple entries in the Batman franchise. Even the voice acting is top-notch, with performances by Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill, among others.Overall, Batman: Arkham City is easily one of the best games I've ever played, and I'd go as far as to say that it may be one of the best games ever made. Also, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, dat cat♥♥♥♥♥

												After Arkham Asylum here comes the next entry of the franchise: Arkham City.Exchanging the confined spaces of Arkham for a big part of Gotham City, you play again as Batman (and Catwoman, once in a while) to punch and kick bad buys to the face. Once again you can use lots of cool stuff, fight bad dudes and solve crime. Again a fanatastic looking game with yet even more fantastic voice actors (Hamill takes the cake again, though)!Be Vengeance. Be the Night. Be BATMAN!

content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												Story: With Batman: Arkham Knight on it's way, what better way to prepare than review one of the best, if not the best, superhero games out there. Batman: Arkham City is a direct fallow up to Arkham Asylum, where the Mayor of Gotham, with the help of Dr.Hugo Strange, have opened up Arkham City. A section of Gotham walled up and made into a prison with some of Batmans most challenging villains. Bruce Wayne inevitibly gets thrown into Arkham City and must uncover the conspericy of what "Protacal 10" is.Gameplay: If you played Arkham City, it's a very well updated version of that. The combat and stealth mechanics are what make this game one of the most replayable story games, as you dodge, kick, punch, and glide through Arkham City and its inmates. Another popular feature is the Detective Mode, in which you examine a crime scene to find your next objective. It helps move everything along at a nice pace. That being said, Arkham City is free roam, allowing you to grapple to the top of the Church and soar over The Sionis Factory, with various side missions avalible.Soundtrack: One of the most badass soundtracks ever. Even the main menu has an epic theme.9/10Go buy it, the DLC isn't half bad either.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												The game is much the same as Arkham City, just with the added central hub of Arkham City to play around with. Though the core of the game is exactly the same, just with a few added gadgets, i feel the game isn't quite as good as the first. Combat is generally as fluent as ever but the camera loves to swing around a lot during the big fights which results in you attacking the wrong thug more than you would like to. The exploration becomes really repetitive very quickly, the game has you returning to the same spots a good few times and just changes it up slightly. Though i wanted to progress, i really couldn't be bothered going over the same territiory again and just getting into the same fights with just bigger mobs of thugs. I also mainly like to stay in detective mode and this game just pulls you out of it all the time...really bothered me after a while.Great game but can get boring real quick and doesn't quite capture the same feel as the first game.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												Arkham Asylum was objectively a masterpiece as far as previous Batman games before it and even superhero games in general are concerned, but Arkham City successfully managed to expand and improve on the game changer that was Arkham Asylum.Complete with a enourmous and gritty open world, 400+ riddler challenges, 200+ challenge medals to obtain, suprisingly interesting and intriguing side missions and a great main story, there's just a whole lot more to do in this game than in the first. Replayability is massive, voice performances are stellar, main story is great and the combat is better than the great combat system of Arkham Asylum.This is definitely in my top 5 games of the 2000s, you'll like it if you're not a Batfan, you'll love it if you're a casual Batfan, and you will adore it if you're a hardcore Batfan.10/10

content:
Posted: November 6, 2013
												Personally my favourite of the Arkham series. A fun to traverse open world and a tight combat system. Despite not being a Batman fan I really enjoyed seeing all the characters and reading up their bios. Playing as Catwoman is quite interesting too and has some similarities to Batman yet plays like her own character.Plenty of things to do in the game and there is even a tonne of challanges to do as Batman, Catwoman and Robin.Also to take advantage of the costumes without having to beat the game first, when you are on the main menu press "Left, Left, Down, Down, Left, Left, Right, Up, Up, Down". You should hear a swarm of bats and be able to select costumes when selecting continue. you have to do this each time you load up the game.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												Story: With Batman: Arkham Knight on it's way, what better way to prepare than review one of the best, if not the best, superhero games out there. Batman: Arkham City is a direct fallow up to Arkham Asylum, where the Mayor of Gotham, with the help of Dr.Hugo Strange, have opened up Arkham City. A section of Gotham walled up and made into a prison with some of Batmans most challenging villains. Bruce Wayne inevitibly gets thrown into Arkham City and must uncover the conspericy of what "Protacal 10" is.Gameplay: If you played Arkham City, it's a very well updated version of that. The combat and stealth mechanics are what make this game one of the most replayable story games, as you dodge, kick, punch, and glide through Arkham City and its inmates. Another popular feature is the Detective Mode, in which you examine a crime scene to find your next objective. It helps move everything along at a nice pace. That being said, Arkham City is free roam, allowing you to grapple to the top of the Church and soar over The Sionis Factory, with various side missions avalible.Soundtrack: One of the most badass soundtracks ever. Even the main menu has an epic theme.9/10Go buy it, the DLC isn't half bad either.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												It's a great Batman story and it's a great game. I don't know why I ignored it for so long.The combat feels like some cinematic beat em up. I initially found it a bit simple, but it gets more and more varied as the game goes on and by the end you feel like a total badass Batman as you beat the crap out of hordes of Arkham inmates.The longer you can dish out punishment without taking a hit yourself, the more XP and rewards you get. The result are fights that feel not just satisfying, but seriously fun as well. Though stealth is also a viable and encouraged option too.Being Batman, there's a ton of gadgets you use to advance through the game and solve Riddler puzzles that are scattered like completionist crack all over the city. These puzzles break up the combat in a nice way, and together with the side-missions, form a great open world.The devs not only seem very up on their Batman mythology, they also managed to get the actors from The Animated Series to lend their voices to the game. The result is an experience that feels right, feels like a Batman game should, and is thoroughly addictive.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												One of the greatest open-world action and adventure games ever created. It follows a brilliant plot with equally thrilling characters. It has a fully fledged world filled to the brim with collectables and secrets. The gameplay is crafted to perfection, fixing any slight flaws from the first game and adding new features to the second. Every fight, moment and cutscene feels alive and unique. The voice acting, graphics and all the aesthetics to the game are superb, giving it a clear advantage above stock standard games. It is, in my opinion, one of the most fufilling open-world games to date.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2013
												Objectively the best western action game ever made.The core gameplay is compromised of a simple but excellent combat system, a very active and satisfying stealth system, and some very decent platforming aspects that make movement feel fluid and interesting.The combat system is built around hitting enemies with combos and countering and dodging their attacks. Eventually, once you get your combo multiplier up to a high enough point you'll be able to do a powerful combo move, like one that stuns a whole group of enemies, or another that you can use to instantly knock out a single enemy. Or, you can save your combo multiplier and get it even higher in order to benefit from a passive buff to your attack and movement speed, allowing you to tear through entire clusters of enemies if you're good enough. While the core combat is relatively simple, a lot of depth is added to it by the gadget system. The player is given 12 gadgets to use, and they all have at least one role in both combat and sneaking, and many are even useful for general exploration. Proper use of gadgets can make or break fights in this game.On the topic of sneaking, Arkham City is also a very good stealth game. The stealth gameplay is both engaging and difficult, and the player will never find a moment where they are left without something to do in a stealth scenario. The speed of it, combined with the utility of gadgets and the neatly implemented detection and noise mechanics provide the stealth with a very high skill ceiling, and plenty of space for the player to master and exploit advanced mechanics.Usually, stealth and combat encounters are clearly segregated, however there are points in the game where the player can make a decision between either as they see fit. This ties in to the free-form nature of the game. Arkham City is a sandbox game, and a very good one at that. The entire map is open to the player from the get-go, with the player free to explore, fight and do side-missions as they see fit.On top of the quality of the core gameplay, Arkham City also has loads upon loads of content. The main story itself lasted me well over 30-40 hours, and it's got very good replay value given the caliber of the gameplay and the open-ended nature of the game. Besides the main story, there is also a very large amount of challenges for each character, in both combat and stealth varieties, truly pushing players to their limits in all aspects of the gameplay. There's four (that's right, four) playable characters, each with their own gadgets, combos and challenges, and there's also an (albeit poor) official DLC extension to the game's story.Speaking of story, Arkham City's plot and writing are pretty good. Many famous Batman characters are given roles in the game, everything makes sense and is in-character, and there are even a few interesting twists at points. The game even pays very good homage to classic Batman characters and media, such as with the costume pack that includes costumes from classic Batman entries like Batman Beyond and The Dark Knight Returns, and the heaps upon heaps of backstory provided for characters and locations within Gotham.The game also exceeds in almost every other aspect. The soundtrack is atmospheric and fitting, even dynamic, matching the gameplay. The graphics are very advanced, with detail including visible snowflakes on your character's body. The artstyle (and architecture) is a very excellent combination of staple entries in the Batman franchise. Even the voice acting is top-notch, with performances by Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill, among others.Overall, Batman: Arkham City is easily one of the best games I've ever played, and I'd go as far as to say that it may be one of the best games ever made. Also, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, dat cat♥♥♥♥♥

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												Arkham Asylum was objectively a masterpiece as far as previous Batman games before it and even superhero games in general are concerned, but Arkham City successfully managed to expand and improve on the game changer that was Arkham Asylum.Complete with a enourmous and gritty open world, 400+ riddler challenges, 200+ challenge medals to obtain, suprisingly interesting and intriguing side missions and a great main story, there's just a whole lot more to do in this game than in the first. Replayability is massive, voice performances are stellar, main story is great and the combat is better than the great combat system of Arkham Asylum.This is definitely in my top 5 games of the 2000s, you'll like it if you're not a Batfan, you'll love it if you're a casual Batfan, and you will adore it if you're a hardcore Batfan.10/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												First, if you haven't played arkham asylum then do so before playing arkham city.This game takes Rocksteady's vision of Batman to the next level. We got all the cinematic glory of a true Batman game in Arkham Asylum and now we get a full feature series incarnation in Arkham City. This game should be played over the course of weeks to absorb all the incredible gems both in the story and homages to the Batman universe. Rocksteady is clearly staffed with many true fans who wanted fans to find easter eggs everywhere.This shows in the craftsmanship and level design. Every building, npc dialogue and story event is credible and feels like a real plot device in the Tim Burton movies. Thanks to the larger map, Rocksteady has created the most immersing experience of superhero flight and gliding. No doubt their interpretation of the grappling hook could be used in any other superhero game design. Already the Rocksteady vision for combat and story telling has been copied in countless games including Mad Max and we will see it for at least a full decade.This game is the ultimate fusion of movie and game, a living contribution to the DC corpus and one of my favourite games in my entire life.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.Just if the crazy 3rd person camera wasn't so messy, this game would be a master piece.To be honest, I hate Batman's comic and, even Batman's films but, this game is a really good one!.Movements of Batman and Catwoman are awesome. Funny action, variated combos, nice acrobacies.I even prefer Catwoman to Batman, her movements are perfect and, she can hung from ceil also.Story is bit simple, as usual in Batman stuff but, the game itself is awesome.Imagine the freedom of exploration of Assassin's Creed, acrobacies of Prince of Persia and, several layers of game in one.You alternative play with Batman or Catwoman (meaw, what a kitty). There is some of puzzle, there is some of arcade action, smashing everyone, some nice gadgets, some of stealth, some of attack planning, some of RPG (experience earning to change for enhancements). Well, it has everything that builds a solid and funny game.I would suggest to developers to create a game dedicated just to Catwoman. She's awesomely characterized and plays like heaven.I wasn't expecting too much from this game but, I am greatefully surprised. I am loving it.POSITIVE SIDE:Graphics, Map s (huge) and Level design.Characters, and this includes all "bad boys" which are very well characterized.Interesting story board, with high variety of "bad boys" and, interesting combat challeges.Fluid movements of Batman and (specially) Catwoman.Several parallel games or challenges and side quests, which bring you a lot of hours of playing.Alternativelly playing with Batman and Catwoman. Really interesting.The curve of learning is nice and, every step gives you a new gadget or combo which makes your character everytime more powerfull (as well as the enemies).Situations were you have to remove a bunch of armored enemies using stealthing technics is awesome. Hunging your batman and silently neutralizing one by one.Gadgets (even that takes a while to master them).Awesome voice location, nice interpretation, very film like.NEGATIVE SIDE:Weird behavior of camera on this kind of 3rd person games. Usually not a mess, until you fight on a narrow space then, you can completely loss control on your character.Remote controlled batrang. This is a real mess the whole game. Flying controls are so abrupt, that it's quite well impossible to drive your batrang in the good way.Being a non-linear game, you can feel sometimes lost and, having not clear idea on what to do.Puzzles are somewhat impossible with these uncontrolled controls.Once again, controls. This makes difficult to hack computers and door locks.I still didn't find Freeze's woman!.Side quests aren't clear. You don't know what to do next, most of times.BALANCEBut, honestly, even with those flaws that can be sometimes frustrating, this is a HUGE game, with lot of fun and, great hours of playing. Re-playable, with all the gadgets and stronger enemies.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2013
												This is a game in which you really feel like Batman. Just gliding around a walled prison city waiting to break some limbs. The damage Batman does, you pretty much kill them. Fine with me. The story is really good, and you really feel like you get to know Batman. For gameplay, you might be beating up a gang of well, gangsters, and making them wish they were never born one minute. The next, you're in a museum or church, sneaking around armed thugs, taking them out silently, one by one. Many iconic Batman characters appear, like Commisioner Gordon, Joker, and Two-Face, with a cast of lesser-known characters, like Jack Ryder, Azrael, and Ra's al Ghul. Small spoiler, but in the last boss battle against Clayface, Batman uses a SWORD. The DLCs provide tons of replayability, with challenge maps, skins, and even story content. Playable characters are expanded to include Catwoman, Robin, and Nightwing. This stealth/combat/open world game is definetly worth buying.

Posted: February 5
BackstoryBatman is incarcerated in Arkham City, he must uncover the secret behind the sinister scheme, "Protocol 10", orchestrated by the facility's warden, Hugo Strange.InformationAt the time that you may be reading this you may think to yourself "Isn't this a really old game" or "i swear i heard of the game ages ago" well you are infact right that this games is getting on abit now in terms of it's age and you may be right if you have played this game before, on whatever that platform you played it on may be.Well i'm here to tell you that you should definatly check this game out or revisit it 100%. This game is so much fun not only if you are into games based on the comic books, movies, TV shows etc. or if you are a fan of open world games with a variety of quests to do and a lot of collectibles to be collecting THIS GAME IS FOR YOU!!!Pick this game up and you won't be able to put the controller down or take your hands off of the keyboard and mouse. Trust me, you won't regret it.Pros:- Fighting mechanics are great, super cool and really entertaining - Voice actors for characters such as Batman, Catwomen and Joker are amazing- The storyline is really easy to follow, interesting and emersive- The gadgets and weapons are EPIC- The DLC's that are available with the GOTY Edition are awesome- To run this game you do not need a s high-spec system meaning its good for budget gamers- Did I also mention that the Joker is voiced by Mark Hamill (Luke Skywalker)Cons:- Dialogue from characters like the goons/henchmen is often repeated due to lack of lines- There are only a few voice actors for the goons/henchmen making the lines and voices stale Want my opinion in numbers? - 8/10I hope this review helped you, Game on & Stay Awesome

Posted: December 20, 2016
												Arkham Asylum was objectively a masterpiece as far as previous Batman games before it and even superhero games in general are concerned, but Arkham City successfully managed to expand and improve on the game changer that was Arkham Asylum.Complete with a enourmous and gritty open world, 400+ riddler challenges, 200+ challenge medals to obtain, suprisingly interesting and intriguing side missions and a great main story, there's just a whole lot more to do in this game than in the first. Replayability is massive, voice performances are stellar, main story is great and the combat is better than the great combat system of Arkham Asylum.This is definitely in my top 5 games of the 2000s, you'll like it if you're not a Batfan, you'll love it if you're a casual Batfan, and you will adore it if you're a hardcore Batfan.10/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												First, if you haven't played arkham asylum then do so before playing arkham city.This game takes Rocksteady's vision of Batman to the next level. We got all the cinematic glory of a true Batman game in Arkham Asylum and now we get a full feature series incarnation in Arkham City. This game should be played over the course of weeks to absorb all the incredible gems both in the story and homages to the Batman universe. Rocksteady is clearly staffed with many true fans who wanted fans to find easter eggs everywhere.This shows in the craftsmanship and level design. Every building, npc dialogue and story event is credible and feels like a real plot device in the Tim Burton movies. Thanks to the larger map, Rocksteady has created the most immersing experience of superhero flight and gliding. No doubt their interpretation of the grappling hook could be used in any other superhero game design. Already the Rocksteady vision for combat and story telling has been copied in countless games including Mad Max and we will see it for at least a full decade.This game is the ultimate fusion of movie and game, a living contribution to the DC corpus and one of my favourite games in my entire life.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2016
												For a game to define a genre is one of the highest acheivements a game can accomplish, in my opinion. Batman Arkham City does just that. With a revolutionizing combat system that I can't get enough of and the slower, more puzzle-like predator mode - Rocksteady knew what they were doing. While this is arguably one of the best Batman stories told to date, this does not mean you have to love Batman to love this game,The soundtrack, the characters, the brawling combat system, the predator combat system, the story, and the good 'ol Gotham City atmosphere are all reasons to love this game.And one top of that - Kevin Conroy's and Mark Hamill's voice acting talents are without comparison to any other. Hamill's performance as the Clown Prince of Crime easily makes this Joker one of my favorites.11/10 easily - no doubtStop reading this and play this game
